content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Don't judge this game by its combat system. It's serviceable. Ok. Nothing at all fantastic. Reminds me a bit of Metal Gear Solid Peace Walker but actually marginally fun. But that's all just filler. My recommendation is to level stealth and pistols because they're absurdly overpowered and you can get through the game very quickly with them.The real gameplay is the dialogue system and your interaction with characters. It's really something else. Every dialogue choice is timed and you have to have you options picked before the other character finishes speaking. There are no awkward pauses between lines and it all flows like good dialogue in a film. That might sound like you don't have control or you won't be able to react fast enough but that is not true. Your options are presented in a succinct but clear way. Usually they are just provided as a single-word description of your overall tone that allows you to quickly process your choices and decide how you want to respond. Sometimes your choices don't have obvious consequences and how the player character acts may catch you off-guard, but those situations are very rare.But as important as your breath of choices in these encounters with characters are the consequences of them. While the game follows a somewhat fixed revenge story your relationship with each character will change your experience of that story hugely. There is a multi-layer conspiracy for you to uncover and if you do not play your cards right there will be parts of it and roles played by characters that you won't even realise you missed. Everyone has secrets and your relationship with them will affect what you learn about them.And that is not to say you should buddy up with everyone. Having characters hate you can be to your advantage. A poor relationship with one character may actually endear you to someone they dislike. Making them angry may cause them to make poor decisions that benefit you.There's a huge depth to the story and it really does react to everything you do. Characters will reference your past decisions and attitudes and it will shape the details of the story you find yourself in. Your choices matter. Your relationships matter. That is what Alpha Protocol is all about.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Without a doubt the best modern spy game I've heard of. I'm not a fan of wordiness, so here's the basic rundown, pluses and minuses and stuff.+ brilliant stealth system. People notice gunshots (but not silenced ones), dead bodies, themselves being shot... loads of stuff+ skill customization is wonderful. By end-game of my stealth build I could walk into a room invisible, kill 5 people and walk out without anyone seeing me. Leeroy Jenkins run: kick in the door, empty the clip, everyone's dead before the alarm's raised.+ boss fights were pretty good. They all had features to make them unique, and it was fun to fight all of them except non-spiked Brayko+ dossiers were super useful, both as flavor-text and in-game. I loved pausing before the end to read all the stuff I'd learned about everyone+ cutscenes were well-done. Most were skippable (BRILLIANT) and I loved Mike's various responses to things+ special mention for letting me Punch Marburg as a dialog option+ also: "refuse" "kiss my♥♥♥♥♥quot; "♥♥♥♥ off" is the best set of options I've ever encountered.+ There were so many things I could do. The devs coded in a lot of secrets and stuff- dialog choices could've been more descriptive. I wasn't expecting Mike to insult someone when I pressed Suave.- I wish Sis got more involvement in the game- there were an unfortunate amount of glitches, such as Mike trying to hold an Assault Rifle like an SMG, or slowly creeping up a wall* Positive or negative: the Chain Shot's final upgrade is incredibly overpowered. This would be completely negative, but it allowed me to destroy forced aggro fights (bosses) and continue on my merry, crouch-walking way.* Some of the glitches were hilarious. I managed to stick a guard through a wall, and he wouldn't stop vibrating.* Security minigames. I loved the Digital Keypad, was neutral on the Lockpicking, and despised Hacking, because of mouse sensitivity.* The characters could emote really well! ...could be a little higher-rez, but it was originally for consoles, so whatever.Overall, wonderful game! I'd easily give this a 9/10 on a standard scale, and wish there was a sequel in the making.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I'll start off by saying this game was an unexpected gem. Alpha Protocol is one of the best RPGs I have every played. The premise of the game is original, the dialogue is superb, and the story kept me interested. I felt that the characters were quite easy to get attached to after a few dialogues. There is one major flaw this game has, and that is the combat and stealth systems.Combat and stealth, or just interacting with enemies in general, is extremely clunky in this game. At times it is frustratingly bad (for example, shooting enemies from <20 ft away and missing with half the magazine), but in my opinion the excellent dialogue, story telling, and decision making all make up for it. As other reviewers have said, another notable aspect of this game is that the decisions you make in this game actually change the way the story unfolds, unlike most games where they only change the ending. I think this gives the game more than a little additional replay value.Other notes: the graphics are excellent compared to other games released around the same time. The sounds are of high quality. The voice acting is great, in my opinion. The level design is rather simple, but it works. The AI are pretty stupid, but that can be a pro or con depending on how you look at it.If you are looking for a game that is rich in story and is addictive, this is the game for you. If you are looking for a combat oriented game with developed combat mechanics, you may want to try something else. I have to take 1 off for the crappy gameplay, but this game still gets a 9/10 from me.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												I usually make the main conclusion of the game in the first sentence. But Alpha Protocol is so suave, that it needs personal and quite thorough preparation to make an appropriate statement.This game comes from the Obsidian studio, which is known for taking already acknowledged action-RPG systems, and then remaking them into much deeper, truthful RPG. It scares many old fans of those previous games, but undoubtedly earns some new admirers from those who can see farther than one step ahead. It was with Neverwinter Nights 2, Fallout New Vegas, Dungeon Siege III...Alpha Protocol was the first game released by Obsidian which was not a part of a big franchise. It was made with limited resources, powerful publisher (who overhyped the project, but made it un-cool), and on the engine of Mass Effect. While limited resources were not a problem to make an outstanding game, other two biases its fall in the release.People were expecting another Mass Effect, in cloak-and-dagger setting. But Alpha Protocol had much less pathos and shooting, than in the beloved and iconized sci-fi world, and much more responsibility for every action, than everybody was expecting. So for some time Alpha Protocol became a pariah in the world of the Mass Effect fanboys, who kept a majority in the gaming trends and patterns.I admire Mass Effect for huge and rich on details sci-fi universe. I enjoyed playing ME games. But even more I am enjoying some pen-and-paper games based on ME universe, but using different mechanics. GURPS is good, Savage Worlds - even better. I’m telling you, that mechanics in the ME games is far from desirable for the immerse RPG play.However guys from the Obsidian took it and turned into a quite decent and even bright thing. They added a timer to dialogs (field agents supposed to think fast) and they added perks, events and consequences to almost every line we are speaking and every turn we are making in the game process.While Alpha Protocol is relatively short, it is so hard and intense in terms of character development, that many players just failed with good choices there, made a weak set of skills and were forced to leave the game unsatisfied. Of course, they all made thumbs down reviews, and that drowned the game on the market. Only now, after 5 years after release, the tide is finally turning. The numbers of players who managed to played it like it was supposed to is growing, so the Metascore is slightly raising better. You can see current state of minds just by look for combination of Phil Owen+Alpha Protocol (see commentary). Although I’m not totally agreed with that fella point of view, well, yeah, generally, Alpha Protocol IS one of the greatest RPG of the given time.It is a great RPG – if played right. And how are you supposed to do that? When making choices in that game, just make it like a responsible, adult man, who really can play in the cloak-and-dagger games. As always, there are two main approaches, one silent, other is assault, and as a third option, you can try to mingle and twist (sometimes speaking saves much more bullets than stealth). But please! Please, do think beforehand doing something! Even when you have to think very fast, you still Need to Think, and not just picking lines and turns occasionally.Summarizing:Alpha Protocol is one of the best current-gen RPG I’ve played, I’ve paid for it twice, and I don’t think it was wasted. Quite opposite, it is one of those rare titles in my book, which totally worth the money.As of gameplay, you got a skill tree and dynamics from Mass Effect, but greatly enhanced towards wagering a given role of a field agent of US secret service. You hack computers, breaking locks and skulls, you mastering pistol and sniper rifle, but, the most significant, you collecting info on your opponents, and that info, used at the right time, is your strongest feature.As of bugs, so commonly commemorated as a game’s main fault… I must make a statement that I didn’t see any significant and game-breaking flaw by all 5 years I’ve known that game. I’ve played it from its release, with quite a humble hardware, on the 4 different PC systems, and everything was working smoothly. Always! Well, AI of the opponents sometimes was performing some questionable tricks, but that’s not a bugs pattern.Overall mark is 9/10, and I’d really like to see some more stuff like this. From Obsidian, or from some other inspired and gifted people – that’s irrelevant. As long as it's at least that non-linear in choices and consequences, it's fine.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is a single player action RPG game with branching story dialogue based on your choices that will affect the way your game progresses and ends. The game has a modern spy movie setting ala James Bond/Mission Impossible. There are dossiers to read through, webs of secrets to uncover, and enough cloak and daggery to make you question who’s side you really are on and who is playing who, typical spy stuff. HOW IS THIS AN RPG?:This type of action RPG game has a single hero, third person camera. You will earn level ups and have dozens of skills to choose from and have different weapons and gear to upgrade. Depending on how you approach some missions you will have access to side quests within your current mission that could potentially benefit you afterwards in areas such as the black market for example.IS THIS A SANDBOX RPG?:The game is not a free roamer and is fairly straight forward to keep the story moving along, it is broken up into the main hubs of Saudi-Arabia, Rome, Moscow and Taipei. However the order of what areas you decide to visit are entirely up to you.EXTENDED REPLAY VALUE!:Completed the game as the sneaky, non-lethal, silenced weapons, computer hacker, suave, smooth talker type? Why not try playing as the shoot first ask questions later, shotgun toting, explosives expert, confrontational, hard headed type? Or a mixture of both or something completely different. The game has multiple dialogue choices and event outcomes depending on what type of play style you go with. You will definitely get your money’s worth from Alpha Protocol if you decide to do multiple play throughs.Admittedly most of my time spent on Alpha Protocol was on the PS3 and I basically did a speed run for nostalgia’s sake on the PC/Steam version. If this is your first time going through Alpha Protocol you are realistically looking at around 20+ hours give or take per go through.It’s too bad SEGA didn’t commission a sequel to Alpha Protocol due to poor initial sales showings, but that shouldn’t deter you from experiencing this gem of a game, very underrated.

Posted: August 30, 2014
												Imagine, if you will, a combination of early Splinter Cell and Deus Ex: HRs little brother, with a drop of occasional Saints Row humor choices in your dialogue options - all presented in a janky but "holy-$h1t-this-is-fun" package.That's Alpha Protocol, a game where your actions and attitude actually impacts the story and peoples' reactions to you, for good or worse. Yes, this is the game that actually DELIVERS on the promises of so many other RPG-likes.My first playthrough ended with me maxing out my stealth skill, enabling me to knife party my way through enemies as a ghostly apparition. My dialogue choices consisted mostly of flirting when inappropriate, threatening with executions (sometimes before enforcing them), and punching people who I believed deserved it.I have 400+ games in my backlog, and all I can think about at the moment, is how I'm gonna play THIS game again next.Also, when in doubt (as I had to learn the hard way, and with a little help), remember that the answer to:-world hunger-environmental pollution-the financial crisis-your John Smith small p3n1s that needs 3 inches RIGHT NOW-space exploration-and a happy life in general......is Chain Shooting.So write that down for when you're gonna play Alpha Pro...Oh, who am I kidding, you're gonna play it right now, of course!

Posted: November 25, 2013
												One of the best executed third person shooter out there.  The stealth mechanics are flawless.  The skill tree is detailed without being cumbersome and I don’t need to learn how to use a pistol before I can shoot a shotgun (that’s right Mass Effect, callin’ you out.)The story is better than average and they’re not afraid to call the bad guys out.  The Saudis, Russians and Chinese are key antagonists (sure that helped international sales.)  The evil corporation trying to start a global war is a little silly (evil corporations don’t start wars, they sell virtual trading cards.)Enemies react logically to seeing or hearing you, rather than letting you have a running gun fight through the intergalactic U.N. headquarters without anyone batting an eye (burn two! ME), although they are a little quick to get tired of looking for you after they find the dead body of one of their buds.  The boss fights are challenging without the bosses being overpowerd into super (or Metal Gear Solid) villains.  The fight with the Russian drug lord is classic.In conclusion (that makes me sound smart,) if you like TPS/RPGs it’s a must own and it’s 5 bucks less than some other TPS/RGP (needs some Aloe Vera for those sick burns Mass Effect?)

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Alpha Protocol is a Third-Person Action RPG which feels like it was maybe a half year's polish from being the best game of the previous generation. In it, you play as a recent recruit to Alpha Protocol, a secret intelligence agency of the United States. You carry through a series of missions, some of which can be played in any order, in order to drive the story of what happened to cause an airline to be shot-down to its conclusion.The primary thrust of Alpha Protocol's novelty is its choice mechanism. In many conversations, there will be multiple options available to the player (typically suave, aggressive, and professional). Different characters will react differently to you depending on what you use, and the player builds a reputation over time. This leads into gameplay perks, new initial reactions from characters which previously haven't been met, and many other branching storyline options. Furthermore, what order you choose to do missions can provide additional intel which can unlock FURTHER branchings in missions, optional objectives, and may other items.The game is not without fault - depending upon what sort of focus you choose to give your character's skills, some boss fights can prove to be very difficult, and this is where the polish could have been most beneficial. That being said, it's hardly enough of a flaw to remove a recommendation for this game - it's absolutely worth the asking price. Rarely have I finished a story-driven game and immediately felt the desire to go back and play through it again while making different choices.Highly, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: February 19
												I'm surprised I haven't written a review for this before.If you've heard bad things about Alpha Protocol... let's be fair, there were MAJOR issues when the game originally launched.  The game was unstable as heck on PC, the framerates were terrible on ATI cards, and the load times were unbearable.  It was really terrible technical experience.But even back when the game launch, I endured those technical problems and found quite possibly my favorite FPS/RPG hybrid.  This one ranks up there with the original Deus Ex, folks.  It's *really* good.These days, it's much better.  Alpha Protocol has been patched up, any modern hardware is way more than powerful enough to run it smoothly.  So now you can pick it up and enjoy a fantastic FPS/RPG experience without the terrible technical issues.Cutting straight to the heart of the matter, Alpha Protocol offers you absolutely insane amounts of choice, and every single decision awards you with a different perk that provides buffs to certain playstyles.  And I do mean every single decision.  Did you complete the mission without doing side objectives?  Did you complete the mission doing only a specific one?  Did you complete the mission without: knocking anyone out, killing anyone, or even being seen?  There's different perks for each.The most refreshing part of the dialogue system for AP is that it's both "in-depth" (classic ME-style drill downs) without the silly "top choice is good person, bottom choice is bad person, middle choice is neutral person" crap.  Intead, Good/Neutral/Bad are broken into Suave/Professional/Aggressive.  Effectively, choose your own spy action hero stereotype.  Are you the suave James Bond?  The professional Jason Borne?  Or the brutally effective anti-hero John Wick?  And based on that stereotype you get - you guessed it - different perks that provide different playstyle bonuses.  Even the personality type isn't purely for decoration.  Different characters like different personalities.  But what if you don't commit to a style?  Well, the game is paying attention to THAT, too.  And if you're picking responses to get people to like or hate you specifically, you must be bluffing to manipulate these folks - gasp, your character is a charismatic mastermind!  And there's a perk for that too!Really, this is a legendary title that was very poorly received due to massive technical issues.  If you've overlooked it before, I can't recommend enough giving it a spin if you're a fan of "0451" games.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
tl;dr -> Realized almost every main character you interact with has a friendship gauge, so I opted to play as James Bond. 69/10 tried to get into every female character's pants.NOTE: You can read my full review here[theroguereviews.com]I had originally played this game years ago on my Xbox 360, however, my rented copy was damaged and I could only play through the first few missions. From what I was able to experience, the game was a lot of fun, and I was very excited to try it on the PC. I completed it in ~17 hours, but be advised – my character was pretty broken, so I think you can easily extend your playtime to 20+ hours. I was very satisfied with my gameplay experience.If you like stealth-based (or not) espionage action, third-person RPG gameplay (like the Mass Effect series), lots of choices and potential consequences, and a fluid storyline, then you will really enjoy this game. I would have loved for this title to be picked up for a sequel, as it has massive appeal and all the right gaming elements.The aesthetics are pretty good – on maximum settings the amount of detail in the characters and background is high. You can customize Agent Thorton’s appearance using a small pool of options, even deciding whether he should wear civilian clothing or armor on each mission. The countless cutscenes seamlessly integrate dialogue/action-trees (using a wheel of options, similar to those seen in the Dragon Age and Mass Effect games), and the special effects are well-done. The music and sounds are great, adding to the intensity of each mission and making you feel like an actual spy in a high-stakes situation – in some levels the music matched the scenery so well I would pump up the volume to immerse myself even more. The story is well-written and engaging – something I especially like is how, depending on the mission order you select (you can pick missions from 3 countries), the story and gameplay experience will change accordingly. For example, you can complete all of the available missions in Rome, or you can do a few, finish some missions in Taipei, then continue the Rome mission-line. Differences in mission order will affect things like available resources (intel, handlers, etc), possible interactions/choices, and character dialogue.The controls are fairly typical of a third-person shooter and easy to familiarize yourself with. There is a (partially) skip-able tutorial segment that is very helpful at teaching you all of the gameplay elements. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with third-person espionage (or shooter, depending on your preferred playstyle) games. The most difficult part of the game will probably be boss fights, since you can easily stealth (or kill) your way through a majority of the missions. In-game achievements and perks are a plenty, and you will constantly receive nice bonuses like an experience gain for picking 10 locks. These bonuses will keep you strong enough to survive most missions.Gameplay is very fun and consists of you moving through a mission area, attempting to complete a variety of goals like “destroy an objective” or “obtain information.” Along the way, you will have to stealth (or kill) your way past different enemies and cameras. Your actions during each mission (and during dialogue scenes) will influence your relationship with any accomplices, who may each be a potential handler in your missions. Depending on your relationships, handlers will provide different bonuses. An interesting component that I really liked is how handlers will provide bonuses even if they dislike or hate you – encouraging you to really play how you want to. For example, one handler will give you +10 endurance (health), and +15 if she really likes you; on the flip-side, she will grant you a 5% reduced cooldown to your abilities if she dislikes you, and a 10% reduction if she hates you. Allies are more likely to help or forgive you if they like you, and enemies who you frustrate may make more mistakes. Each individual responds to your dialogue differently – for example, some characters may prefer a professional agent, while others like a laid-back, funny one.Overall, the game is a lot of fun and will bring you many hours of enjoyment if you are interested in any of these genres. Even if you do not like espionage (or action), you can play on an easier difficulty and just enjoy the story, cutscenes, and dialogue/action options.Highly recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												If you are playing this more than 5 years after release, you probably read enough reviews to know what features make this a great game: The dialogue system, the decision tree and how both shape the story. If these things interest you, give it a go. The action mechanics are mediocre, though. Don't play it for that. Also, there are a few bugs and no community patch to fix them. So it is really not about getting the most of a stealth action game, it is playing a remarkable story game that happens to use stealth FPS action.And that's all that constitutes my review. Let me now tell you how to enjoy this game: Suffer through the missions in Saudia Arabia - they introduce you to the limitations of the world and the engine. Those are tremendous. The mission design gets a bit better afterwards, and hopefully you got used to the limited freedom of movement.  Chose stealth and either pistols or martial arts. Without stealth movement and a matching fighting skill to chose from, you'll miss out on half of the game otherwise. Chose the easiest difficulty: The AI is not good and you'll simply get less annoyed this way. You're here for the story. Also, reloading produces a bunch of bugs, so not having to reload often is a good thing.♥♥♥♥♥♥off characters if you do not like them. Really, it is okay and makes the game interesting. Read up on the bugs of the game, mainly before the embassy mission in Moscow Keep at least two manual savegames around: One in-between missions, one during the current mission.

												A really awesome and flawed game that i really loved and i really recommed to those who loved choices-based story and some rogue agent action Pros: - It has a really good story involving secret organizations and agents going rogue- The choices that you make and your actions in the game really effects your reputation  towards different enemies and allies later in the game- The enemies that you will fight and the allies that will help you in carrying your mission will be decided by the reputation you have toward a certain enemy/ally- A pretty deep leveling up system Cons:- Graphically speaking, it looks bad- It does have tons of bugs and glitches throughout the game- A really simplistic combat and stealth system- Braindead AIs with VERY limited vision- Some boses were very easy and could be defeated within minutesOverall, if you could withstand the terrible gameplay and lots of glitches, it really have some of the most interesting story i have ever found

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is either the most underrated game ever or the most unknown game ever. Seriously, take a second: Have you ever heard of this game before?SEGA and Obisidian Entertainment?Espionage RPG?It was mentionated on Rock, Paper, Shotgun?Yeah. I guessed that. With this intruduction, let's game to the game itself:Graphics: Pretty good. Facial expressions and overall quality of the game's scenario is pretty good to look at. It doesn't try to be the most beautiful game ever at the same time that it tries to don't look awful. Since they are a little dated, you don't need a powerful machine. Gameplay: Overall presentation to gameplay tatics and mechanics are self-explanatory and how YOU will use them is pretty much up for the player. The game let's it quite clear: If you fail, the failure is your own fault, not the game's fault. If i can say one bad thing about the gameplay is the key biding: The Space Bar is, at the same time, the button used to run and to go on cover. No, really, i'm ♥♥♥♥ing serious. Now imagine this situation: You need to go stealth because you're on low health, but then, suddenly, your characters run and now everybody is just going to f*** you up. It's quite frustating to say the least (But at least the death animation is so funny that i can't get frustated when i die).Stealth system and hacking/lockpicking/etc overall works great and in a good amount of difficult. You WILL need to be careful in this game to not die. Dying is easy even for the hardcore stealth game fans (I'm playing on Hard and believe me: It's gets REALLY hard).Multiple pathways and overall level desing helps a lot the player and are a good touch in a game that works like this one. Same goes for the RPG system. It's quite balanced and the upgrades are self explanatory and really helpfull at many situations. So, save your AP (Experience Points) and get's what suits you better. Because this game is going to put you at your maximum.This game also have boss fights and, man oh man, they WILL REALLY PUT YOU TO THE MAXIMUM. You will have to be twice as careful when fighting bosses and they have a relative amount of HP (Depending on your difficult. I'm on Hard, so you guess). If you want a comparation for instance: Imagine Deus Ex: HR. Pretty much THAT.I have to say this: This is a game that isn't made for casual gamers. And i really mean it when i say that they try really hard to make this clear.Sounds: Voice actting is okay, nothing special. Soundtrack of the game is quite good and always does a good job at putting you in the mood of the mission/warning you when something is going on (Like being detected).Story: Many people liked it because of the beliavable characters and the construction of relationship through the game (Mostly because of the multiple dialogue choises). It's not really something new, but it does a good job at letting the player wanting for more and more, and keeping going through missions. Overall, you may not know Alpha Protocol™, but he exists. And is a good game for what it is, and pretty inovative too. I have to say that this is the first action/stealth RPG that i've ever played (I think) and it did a pretty good job at trying to start this new kind of genre. It's a shame that it din't really made a lot of sucess and the sells weren't good enough for a sequel.But hey, it's still purchasable on Steam. Give it a try, you will find a good challenge with this game.PS: On Steam i will have just some minutes, but i've played it for 3-5 hours in offline mode because my internet just felt down at the time. Damn good job sycing my play time, uh , Steam? GG WP.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												The story is gripping and the way that it branches really gives the player the power of choices that matter. You really feel like the decisions you make have an impact on the game world and that there are consequences, both positive and negative, for the things you do and say. Some people may not like the dialog system, but I think its absolutely genius! Limiting the time you have to choose dialog responses makes you have to think on your feet and pay close attention to detail. Not to mention, it allows for great replayability of the game. The characters are also really well constructed, each with their own personality, likes and dislikes, that you have to find out to successfully navigate conversations. Voice acting is pretty good too.Another large aspect of the game is the RPG element: choosing your skills, specializations, weapon loadout and customizations. Although the interface could use some work, it isn't the most cumbersome of console-ported interfaces. That said, I think the mechanics are well done. The skill tree is reminiscent of Mass Effect 2 except you have more individual skills to choose from which is nice. I've read that the skills can be unbalanced and lead to "power-leveling", but I've chosen to ignore reading what particular skills those are because I like finding out for myself. I'm going to defend the game here and say that unbalanced skills in an RPG is perfectly acceptable; Of course not every decision you make is going to be the right one and that is the beauty of having choices--having consequences to those choices.The weapons customization is also slick and adds a good bit of depth to gameplay since you can customize your weapon mods to suit your play style. For example adding a silencer may decrease damage but gives you the advantage of stealth.I also like the experience/achievements system which rewards you differently based on your approaches to situations in the game. I never felt like I was missing out by not making a particular choice, because the game would reward me either way, but the rewards would differ.Now for the bad parts: Enemy AI is lacking. For example, anytime you sprint, guards have the uncanny ability to hone in on your location. Also, this isn't Splinter Cell: Enemy bodies disappear almost instantly and guards don't really get suspicious when you kill their friends as long as they don't directly see you doing it (or hear you). Also, the alarm system is kind of broken. The game works on a checkpoint system so even if you trigger the alarm in one checkpoint, there are no negative consequences for the following checkpoint area. This means the game is very forgiving when it comes to stealth. Trigger the alarm? No problem, just bust out your assault rifle and kill everybody in the area then continue to the next checkpoint.The other large annoyance is the save system. The game uses checkpoints for saves and overrides each checkpoint save when you reach a new one. This can be frustrating when you want to go back in time, only to find your last manual save was 2 days ago because your checkpoints were overwritten. Now when I first found out there was no ability to quick save, I thought it was a stupid design decision. But now, I see that it falls inline with the rest of the game's design philosophy: You're choices matter and there are consequences to your actions. Allowing you to quick save whenever you want takes away from the gravity of your actions since you can redo them infinitely without consequence. Overall if I could change it, I would keep the checkpoint system, but have it save each checkpoint separately.That said, I think the save system and the poor AI are excusable, given the very engrossing story and the very well executed branching and dialog system. That's not to say that the action and actual gameplay are not fun in their own right, just that the former elements steal the show. I'm sad to hear Alpha Protocol received such poor reception from the press and initial users, but I hope others will give this diamond in the rough a chance. And just hopefully, Obsidian will be given the chance to do a sequel.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												A decent Rpg set in the espionage world. While the concept seems original the execution could have been better, in short this is an Obsidian game, so it has all the trademarks of that developer, and they are: Great story with interesting characters, a very innovative dialogue system, good Rpg mechanics and a lot of decisions to make that affect your story in a hard way. But as all the Obsidian games there are a lot of problems concerning gameplay. It has a stealth system that is very rough around the edges making it hard to go through a mission without being detected, a bad camera (which can be fixed for most of the time if you have a controller), a very basic level design and some bugs. Graphically i found the game to be inconsistent, while some characters are very well modeled some textures of the levels seem outdated.With all the problems i still say that this one was one of the most original games i ever played, if you are looking for an different type of RPG to play give this one a go and you can buy it cheap nowadays.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												As a preface, I've gotta say that Alpha Protocol is one of those games that does a hell of a lot of things. But then it does a hell of a lot of those things really badly. It's like a 2:1 ratio of good features to bad features.For those of you who like RPGs, and making a character from the ground up, Alpha Protocol offers that pretty well. There's plenty of perks and a full set of skill trees to invest in as you level up, allowing you to make completely different characters each time.BUT. You can easily make your character overpowered by investing all your points into select abilities that make you excel at your playstyle. About halfway through the game, playing as a stealth/tech guy, I had an ability that let me sprint around completely invisible for 25 seconds, with a 90 second cooldown. During that period, I could knock out anyone without getting spotted. This meant literally every stealth section of the game became as simple as using that ability. Also, the ability that lets you line up critical hits from cover meant I could just take down an entire room of enemies without even aiming a weapon.Then there's the dialogue system. It's ♥♥♥♥ing phenomonal. No other game really gives you such a feeling of choice, and entire missions can be locked behind certain dialogue options. You never know what you're missing out on or what you've just gotten yourself into. For example, at one point in the game, I spared this one assassin, who shall not be named. I didn't have to do that at all, but when I did, it gave me good rep with a faction I didn't even know existed, access to some extra black market goods, a new handler and some extra support for later missions. Quite a lot just for one seemingly meaningless choice. Then again, I could have denied this other faction if I didn't trust them and I would skip all those other benefits entirely. The dialogue system is surprisingly extensive and you actually do make some meaningful decisions with it.BUT. It's like Fallout 4. i.e. You pick the option "Dismissive", and suddenly your character has made some really condescending remark, while you were expecting him to say something completely different. On more than one occasion I've ♥♥♥♥ed up dialogue choices purely because I had no idea what my character was to say. A real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ It should be done Deus Ex style, where you can see a brief sentence of each option before picking it, because as is, there are plenty of important decisions you can ♥♥♥♥ up by just not knowing what your character is going to say.I do like that the game has a full fledged reputation system for each character, and depending on what you say or do, each character will gain a different view of you. Depending on if someone hates you or likes you, they'll alter what happens later on.BUT. The game really likes to drive home this whole "Reputation" system. On more than one occasion, the game will face you with a pretty laughable decision. "This person will be killed, but this other person can be stopped. You can only do one of them, but not both, for reasons. Why have I even given you the opportunity to only do one of these things? Well, err..." The game really likes to remind you that this system is in place and really drive home the "moral decisions" narrative.The stealth gameplay in Alpha Protocol is pretty nice. It's very Splinter Cell-ish, but also gives you a lot more versatility. I found that I just levelled Martial Arts right up very high. That was enough for me to just beat my way through every area. Hell, it was even effective against bosses.BUT. It's really unpolished. Enemies will spot you through cover in certain places. Maybe because the cover isn't adequate and they can still see you over it or something like that. The game doesn't really give you any indication of when you're in effective cover or not. Cover that doesn't seem to be effective, like hiding behind a chair, suddenly works like a charm. The alert phase is messed up as well. Enemies will head straight to full alert after seeing you for less than a second. There's no real period of grace or timeout. Once they see you, you're spotted. Luckily, this is counterbalanced by the "Evasion" ability, which makes you invisible for a certain amount of time after being spotted. To add to all that, distractions barely work. You're given a distraction device, but whenever you use it, the enemy will seemingly sprint right towards you anyway, even if they don't know you're there.In terms of story, it's actually pretty good. I expected it to be another Splinter Cell type of story where "Jamal Rafiq Bumbaclot the Second" does something that violates national security so a bunch of spec op guys find him and realize he's actually just working for someone else, and it was all a ruse. Then the game introduces a different twist that turns the game more into Deus Ex. Now Jamal Rafiq Bumbaclot is still there. He's just been Deus Ex'd a little. I quite liked it, even if the ending was very simplistic.On another note, the game is horrendously unbalanced. Just investing in a few different skills will suddenly make you overpowered af tbh fam. This one ability, when upgraded fully and used in a creative way, can be used to kill pretty much every boss in the game in less than 3 hits. Even the final boss, with his body armor and everything, was reduced to half health from one blast of this ability.Also, the game's got a fair few weapons you can kit yourself out with, and a lot of interesting minigames, such as hacking and lockpicking.All in all, it's a very Deus Ex-like game, story-wise and gameplay-wise. Alpha Protocol is definitely unique, but despite its flaws, I really enjoyed it.Also, there are a few moments that don't really make much sense lookingatyoumarburgandyourfancyvilla

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is 3rd person stealth shooter with RPG elements. You play a new recruit to a secret spy organization, and travel around the world fighting terrorist plots and other threats. The game is very open in that you get choices on where to travel next and how to act, which can have drastic effects on how exactly events unfold in each particular area.Alpha Protocol allows the player to choose their approach to being a spy, according to one of three archetypes: James Bond, Jack Bauer, and Jason Bourne. Your decisions and dialogue options reflect how those particular agents would respond to any given situation, and the story unfolds in reaction to that decision. I have played through this game before both on console and on PC (non Steam), so I have witness just how drastically different your experience can be throughout the storyline. It's a game that holds up on repeat playthroughs because of this variation.Alpha Protocol both benefits and is harmed by having Obsidian as the developer. The story is one of Obsidian's finest, with the dialogue and voice acting as some of the high points. However, Obsidian is not known for developing stealth shooting games, so the gunplay does suffer as a result. Alpha Protocol also has it's fair share of bugs, which we've all come to expect from the studio.The gameplay is not a strong point of this title. You will have to put experience points in to weapons to actually be able to hit your enemies, which can be frustrating at times. You'd expect a secret agent to be able to at least hit a target 10 feet away reliably. The good news is that you don't really need any weapon besides your pistol, so you can put points in that while freeing up more for other abilities.I really cannot stress enough how enjoyable the story and writing is in Alpha Protocol. You will meet a variety of interesting characters, and your choices within the game feel like they have a real effect on the overall story. That is pretty rare, since a lot of titles just seem to give you the illusion of choice. While the gunplay is not polished, it's enjoyable enough to keep you going until the next bit of story. The abilities work to give your playstyle a bit of flavor, so not everyone has to fight their enemies the exact same way.I give my full recommendation to Alpha Protocol. You get the sense that you are playing through a genuine spy movie, and you get to decide what type of spy your character is going to be. This game has become a bit of a cult classic recently, and it really deserves that attention. It did not get a stellar reception upon its release, with most reviews focused on the bugs and mediocre gunplay. Many of those bugs have been patched since release, and the real star of this game is the story.Grade: B+

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												If you can look past its rough edges, Alpha Protocol is the most exhilarating spy adventure in gaming.-----------------------------------------------------------------------It's not hard to see why Alpha Protocol was critically panned on release; the combat is clunky, visuals are mediocre across the board, and intrusive mini-games disrupt the game's flow. If there is one thing I want you to take away from this review, it's that none of these issues should stop you from experiencing this thrilling action RPG.You play as Agent Michael Thorton, an operative working for a secret United States organization known as Alpha Protocol. This organization is responsible for many of the shadier aspects of the U.S.'s foreign policy, and you'll be tasked with traveling the world to be its hand. As the premise suggests, you'll become involved in many international conspiracies and meet many important people along the way.The game features light customization options, with the ability to slightly change Agent Thorton's appearance as well as how he plays. There is a skill tree where you can dump points every time you level up, but the choices you make here aren't compelling at all. If you want to play as a stealth character just dump all of your points in stealth and call it a day, the points have to be allocated linearly so you won't be allowed to choose which aspects of stealth you want to pursue first.Each country you visit will have its own safe house. From here you will see all available missions and be able to equip yourself for them. Alpha Protocol agents are not funded by the U.S. in order to minimize paper trails, so you'll be responsible for purchasing your own gear through local black markets. Each country will have a "big" mission where all of the smaller objectives you've completed culminate into a big finale. You're given some freedom in how many of these smaller missions you choose to pursue and in which order you want to do them in.Perhaps more important than being well equipped for your missions is being well informed. You will acquire dossiers on every major character in the game and you flesh these out as you learn more and more about them. Many games feature an in-game glossary as a complimentary feature for those who want to learn more, but in Alpha Protocol they are near essential to the gameplay. Understanding all of the characters and organizations you will be working with will help inform your decisions in dialogue sequences. Some characters are lax and would prefer conversation to be softened up with jokes, while others have little tolerance for anything but the utmost professionalism. The visuals are unlikely to win anyone over. Character models are average and animations are stiff, the games textures haven't aged very well either. Thankfully presentation is saved by great voice acting, which is crucial because the game's dialogue is fully voiced.The dialogue system is the star of the show. The dialogue wheel displays the tone of the responses you can give (i.e. Aggressive, Professional, Suave) instead of writing out lines and lines of text; this is important because all conversations are timed. I was initially put off by the system, I generally like to take my time when responding in RPGs, but it didn't take long for me to see the brilliance in its design. What it essentially does is turn dialogue into part of the action. You have to be quick on your feet when you respond in high pressure situations, and your responses can carry weight throughout the entire game as you build or burn bridges with major characters.Alpha Protocol's fun dialogue system wouldn't mean much if it didn't feature a strong cast and and interesting story, and as you might expect from Obsidian it delivers on both of these fronts. The story unravels in a non-linear fashion depending on which missions you choose to pursue first. Every character has their part to play in the game's complicated narrative, and learning more about each of them will give you one more piece of the puzzle. The gameplay that exists outside of dialogues and dossiers is really what pulls this game down. Missions take place in relatively linear levels where you shoot or sneak your way through your opposition. The AI of the enemies is poor; walking into another room will get them to completely forget about the fact you just killed someone in front of their faces. The shooting is also clunky, aiming requires you to stay held onto a target for a few seconds in order to land a completely accurate shot. What does this mean for the player? Your bullets don't go where you point them unless you hold your aim still for a few seconds. The end result is that the shooting feels completely unsatisfying, I ended up putting the game on its easiest difficulty setting and plowing my way through the combat sections so I could get to the next dialogue sequence as fast as possible.Unfortunately, awkward shooting and stealth aren't the only issues plaguing Alpha Protocols missions. The game shoves in random mini-games for hacking computers, unlocking safes, and disabling alarms. Each is a tedious endeavor and isn't satisfying at all to complete. They could have all been easily achieved by a simple button press and I'd be far happier.Though it may appear that I have had more bad to say than good, I overwhelmingly enjoyed the time I spent on my first playthrough of the game. As I reflect on my experience with the game, I don't think about my qualms with its combat and stealth mechanics, instead I think about all the characters I interacted with and all the decisions I made. If you don't mind the fact that Alpha Protocol looks and plays like it was made by a B-List studio, then you're in for the best James Bond game ever made.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
The Good:* Alpha Protocol is a unique 3rd-person-action/RPG hybrid. Truthfully, though, it caters more to the "twitch" side of stealth than the "methodical" side. Keep this in mind if you like your Stealth games slow or medium-paced.* Alpha Protocol laid the groundwork for some of the games that you are playing right now. It is the reason current-gen iterations of Deus Ex, Borderlands, and Fallout exist in their current form. And, because of this groundwork, AP has similarities to all three of these series, but it is unfortunately a worse game.* It is widely-reported that the game has a number of game-breaking bugs. This may have been true upon release, but is NOT true now. I did not encounter any game-breaking bugs.* The method of gameplay caters to the players' choice: it can be played multiple ways: run-n-gun, stealth, etc. However, playing with stealth is quite difficult compared to games like Metal Gear, Splinter Cell, or even Oblivion. This difficulty leads to many more twitchy fire fights than you would typically desire in a stealth game. And it's not a "good" difficulty. It really feels cheap or unfair when the enemy detects me while I am in full camo in the dark, crouched and not moving.The Bad:* Most levels are essentially hallways, with only one or two alternative routes that can be used.* Some animations are a bit stiff. For example, the open scene features your avatar's bicep and forearm occupying the same space at the same time. Enemies will also "slide" into cover at times, and the normal guard's walking pace is way too low for the length of his stride.* Character animations are incomplete. Most games feature some sort of "turning" animation as your avatar changes direction. Turning is automatic in Alpha Protocol: your character is facing one direction and suddenly faces another direction.* The computer hacking feature is definitely the dated relic of a game developed for a console. Rather than allowing a click and drag interface using the mouse, the player must move two "passwords" across the screen using the keyboard for one and the mouse with the other. Although I have done a poor job of describing it, believe me that the interface feels dirty and and the controls are alarmingly poorly-designed. * UI Features, such as the item selection menu, are a little unintuitive. They are confusing but are not hard to get used to.* Pausing while in the middle of a conversation is really inconsistent. Sometimes the game allows you to pause, other times it doesn't. This is especially frustrating because the game allows you to choose what to say, and if you step away from your computer to give the baby a bottle, you may come back to a conversation headed in the completely wrong direction, essentially ruining your game up to that last checkpoint.* On one mission I was instructed several times to use dust storms to hide my approach. There were no dust storms. On another mission I was told the sound of trains would disguise the noise of my bullets. The trains: they did nothing.* Bugs encountered: (1) after dying, I loaded my last checkpoint and the game crashed. (2) On one mission, I found an invsible wall in the middle of a hallway, got my foot stuck in a rock, and found a health dispenser floating in mid-air. (3) It is impossible to do a stealth takedown on an enemy near a door, you will simply knock the door down instead of killing the enemy.The Ugly:* Alpha Protocol's method of encouraging the player to be stealthy works by making the combat mechanics horrible. One example of this is that in order to shoot accurately, you have to wait 4 or 5 seconds between each shot. Deliberately making your game worse to encourage a particular playstyle is a horrible idea, why did Obsidian think that would help their game?* Playing the game 100%, or even "somewhat fully," requires lots of extra (boring) dialogue. Even worse, and the reason why I don't think this game will be remembered, is that the game "features" hours of reading extra dossiers to find clues.The Verdict:* Alpha Protocol is neither solid nor decent, but a game that you may enjoy if you are a fan of Bioware or Bethesda games. The game is an interesting combination of stealth, gunplay, and mind-numbingly boring conversations and reading segments. I only recommend picking up this game if you are interested in game design so that you can see how pacing, genre-hybrids, and player agency became such important concepts in newer games.  Alpha Protocol experimented with these methods and was successful in some ways and a complete failure in others.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												There is always that game. The game most people know is good, but never played. Alpha Protocol can definitively be put in that category for a lot of people.For the others, who actually played it, ask them what is the best spy game they played, and a lot of them will probably mention Alpha Protocol. Alpha Protocol is a lot less known than franchises suchs as MGS or Splinter Cell, which spawned multiple games, but it does a lot of things rights all while maintining a pretty realist setting.You see, Alpha Protocol isn't just your random stealth game. In its story telling and character developpement, it's a lot closer to a RPG. The story follows the main protagonist as he gets recruited into an secret agency working for the US goverment. After training and a few missions, for some reasons I won't explain, he is forced to go rogue, and work on unraveling the conspiracy which put him in that situation all while avoiding being hunted by his former colleagues. On the way he will meet numerous allies and ennemies, and take part in a lot operations in various countries until the thrilling conclusion of the story.But you see, even if I wasn't willingly leaving the details of the story vague, Alpha Protocol is a game where your decisions really matters. Who you will befriend, the ennemies you make, who gets to live or die, is all up to you via the decisions of your character. Dialogues often leave you a limited time to answer when you are talked to. So you need to respond in a pretty quick and instinctive manner. While some people may complain it's a bad idea, especially without a way to savescum easyly, I personnally find it gives the story a more organic feel. It does help the whole cast of character is really well done. Most of them have some pretty complex stories behind them, and their own psychology. Psychology, as such, is important when dealing with others. You need to understand the kind of person you're talking to and act accordingly. The character of Frank Heck, in particular, has become a fan favorite.The game has multiple endings, some being pretty amazing, like joining forces with the "bad" guy(s), and even betraying them just afterward to take over. Something which isn't seen pretty often in games.As for the gameplay, the stealth as well as the gunplay is pretty solid. And it's an other strength of the game, really. While you can go around relying on stealth on most mission(not all mind you), and/or diplomacy, you can also take a more direct approach, or being a tech wizard relying on gadgets to get the work done, there is even a hand to hand combat specialist path, depending on how you wish to build your character. Out of stat gains via missions completed, you  also get rewarded with passive bonus depending of your playstyle and your choices. Taking a lot of damage will grant you extra resistance, using a weapon a lot will make you better with it, going non lethal will make you better with non lethal weapons, etc etc. The good thing with such a system is, no matter how you play, you will get something out of it to suit your general playstyle, which is pretty good and clever.The only flaw I could find is the fact some weapons were a bit poorly balanced, to the point the best guns are actually the pistols, and everything else is kinda bad(which is mostly due to one pistol skill being really brutal).Some things are done via minigames, such as lockpicking, hacking and rewiring. A lot of people don't like the hacking minigame, but personnally I never had any problem with it. Overall, if you want a spy game with a good setting, a really good story, interesting characters and enjoyable gameplay, you can't go wrong with this game. Chances are, seeing it's getting old now, you will get it for a low price, even more during a sale, so by all means, get that game. You won't regret it.

Posted: April 8, 2014
												Take the choices and RPG elements of Mass Effect and the gameplay of Metal Gear Solid and you get Alpha Protocol. A surprisingly good game with a dialoge tree and choice system that actually dramatically changes the story. It may, in fact, be the most dynamic choice system I have ever seen in a game before. The story is your typical espionage story, but still very enjoyable. The stealth and shooting mechanics are both pretty well done and a wide variety of ways to complete a mission. This game may also have the distincion of the most OP pistol in a game ever. The first Halo has nothing on Alpha Protocol's pistol when the right perks are equiped, meaning you can finish any boss in a matter of seconds. Overall, this overlooked game definitely deserves more attention as it really is a very unique.

content:
Posted: February 27
												It's an Obsidian developed Espionage RPG. It's a real "diamond in the rough" situation. It plays like a third person shooter, but doesn't handle like one. This turned off a lot of people who tried to play it like Splinter Cell and realized just aiming a headshot wasn't enough to actually hit if your skills weren't actually high enough.The real star is the story and conversation system. You have a set timer on how to respond to conversations, keeping the flow natural and pushing you to role play on the fly, without a lot of time to judge your response.It's also, like many Obsidian games, *very* buggy. Expect to reload saves from falling through the floor more than once. When I originally played this on Xbox 360, I only had a couple of crashes through my entire playthrough.I really recommend the game if you're wanting something different from an RPG.

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2012
												Alpha Protocol is a cover based, over the shoulder shooter 'Espionage RPG.' While the shooting isn't amazing, the RPG elements and story are what pulls you in. I'm not a big fan of stories in RPGs, but this game pulls you in, because it tailors itself to your choices in conversations. Characters remember what you say, and what you say can not only come back to haunt you, but affect who becomes a friend or you later on. Not just that, but you can execute characters, but be prepared to face the consequences when their allies come for you.The graphics are great, but there is pop in every so often, the characters are believable. No one is a laughable stereotype and the dialog is fully voiced. You'll find dead serious characters, flirty ones, low key people and over the top ones. There's something here for everyone character wise. Since the cut scenes require you to make a timed choice, it kept me engaged more than other RPGs that I'd just skip cut scenes and dialog.The bulk of the game is an over the shoulder shooter, which has pitfalls such as coming around a corner with the camera to the right of the character, the enemies can't see you, but you can only see wall. Combat is simple, left stick moves, right stick moves the camera, hold one trigger to aim, another trigger to fire, You have one bumper for a special ability and another bumper for equipment such as grenades, health kits, EMPs, flash bangs, radio bombs, sound makers to attract guards. There's a button for cover, action and running. You'll have a button for melee, a quick switch weapon, since the game only lets you carry 2 at a time. While you can't pick up weapons from downed enemies, but you select and customize your weapons before the mission. You have your choice of pistols, shotguns, SMGs, and assault rifles. Several types of pistols, shotguns, SMGs, rifles and so on. All of the different types aren't really upgrades so much as side grades. You might sacrifice damage for reloading, accuracy or recoil. Then you can really tweak things with scopes, mussels and so on. You can buy clothes, armor, plates, gloves and they all have different stats. Sacrificing stealth for damage, endurance for upgrade slots. I didn't find myself clamoring for armors and weapons. On top of that, you have a lot of useful perks in the game that you get to buy with AP from leveling up. When you start out the game, you pick a basic class with default stats and perks. Things like stealth, martial arts (hand to hand), toughness (damage you can take), shotgun proficiency, pistol proficiency, and so on. The perks are nice, but can sometimes make the game too easy. Everything from more damage and accuracy to usable skills such as chain shooting a pistol, slowing time and being able to knock down enemies from a 'critical' hit with a shotgun.Between missions when you're buying weapons, armor and equipment, you can also buy intel and read emails from the cast of characters. Some have extra intel, unlock new things from the black market, other emails give you a chance to reply, simply to improve your standing with characters. The safehouse hubs are really nice and help with the immersion. You don't just pick missions, weapons and check emails you walk around the places, checking out little details and trophies like a glass eye from an enemy. They're big enough to be fun, but small enough to not get overwhelming.Once you complete the first operation, the game will open up to your choice of different locales. Each locale has a slew of different missions to chose from so you're not always pigeon holed into one mission. Each mission has a 'handler,' each has a perk that will help you on a mission. Sometimes you can vaguely select who you're paired with. Some handlers will grow to hate you if when you start killing or shooting civilians or soldiers you're aligned with.While the cover of cover based shooting is okay, other games do it better. You can roll out of cover, unstick yourself from cover, but you can't vault over cover or pull  enemies over the cover. The only times that you can vault over something is when a floating icon marks it. You can drop down off a ledge if its marked with an icon. The whole icon to do this or that makes the game feel very stiff and rigid when other games make it more free flowing. The game has regenerating armor, but not regenerating health. It is a nice compromise, and while you can get shot a few times on normal difficulty and live, any more than a few bullets will kill you pretty quick.Enemies will pace around areas and when they notice you they'll shoot, which will alert others and not just that, but they will trigger alarms to call others. It is a nice system and you can stealth kill or disable them. You can go through the game not killing 99% of the enemies. There is even a perk with stealth that will let you see arrows through walls with the direction all enemies are facing.The enemy AI is okay, but its not out for blood most of the time. The basic enemies can do most anything. They'll try to flank you, some of them will throw grenades to get you away from cover. The game makes good use of the enemy AI by having open areas with ladders so you can flank the enemies and they can flank you. If you can do things like climb ladders and use zip lines, so can they. It makes for an even playing field. Enemies will reload just as you do and then its a safe moment to take them out either through melee or shooting them. When you brawl with an enemy, they'll guard, so you'll have to time your strikes.The maps and AI do a good job to make things interesting and not just a straight forward hallway shooting spree. You'll be able to stealth around them in most cases if not gloriously zip line into them. You will also see different factions shooting on one another, which is always interesting, you can intervene in one way or the other if not just slip by unnoticed. The maps also allow for exploration and you're rewarded with finding parts, weapons, cash, intel and other things.There are a few types of mini games in Alpha Protocol, such as a simple wire hacking game where you need to select wires in a specific order. You'll see numbers attached to wires and the wires are all mixed together for you to select which one is attached to the number you're on. There's a lock picking mini game that has you moving tumblers up or down based on how hard you're pulling the trigger, then you pull the other trigger to freeze the tumbler for success. Finally, there is a computer hacking mini game that has you placing two lines of code amongst an entire word find. If time expires, the word find will shuffle and you'll need to find where the two lines match. If you fail these mini games so many times, it sets off an alarm, alerting enemies. It is a good punishment for failure, but a lot of the time, the enemies are already dead.To many the game takes 20+ hours to complete, but I manage to breeze through it twice on normal at 12 hours each and it was worth the replay a few years later. I explored all areas, the one thing that I didn't do was read all of the emails, maybe that's where the extra 8 hours comes in. The endings were completely different on both playthroughs, but again your alliances lead to things and you have ultimate control over what happens no matter what twists or turns happen.In all, its not a perfect game, but I can deal with it with a story that wraps itself around you. Everyone should play it once for the dirt cheap price. I bought it for $2. If there was a sequel, I'd buy that too.

number of helpful: 18 of 21 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I have nearly 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews.One Hour Reviews - Game 7Alpha ProtocolPurchase Date: 9/24/2011I picked up Alpha Protocol years ago in a good sale, but it's taken me this long to finally getting around to playing it.  Alpha Protocol seems to be one of those really unappreciated games that never reached the popularity of other games from Obsidian Entertainment, so I was never in a big hurry to pick this one up.I liked the way the game starts without any grand cutscenes to set things up.  Instead I find myself controlling my character right away, with no context as to what is going on.  I'm used to a lot of these role playing games having a slow start while you get some huge exposition dump setting up the game.  Instead I'm busy trying to escape from a building where I am seemingly a prisoner.Which of course brings up the other big difference with this game, is that you are playing a government agent.  There have been countless fantasy based role playing games, and more recently a lot of sci-fi based games, so this makes for a refreshing change.  The game quickly reveals that not all is as it seems, and I find I am in a training facility, which in turn leads to the tutorial portion of the game.  The tutorial does a good job covering the basics of combat and gunplay, along with stealth elements.  The game also provides an opportunity to customize the look of your character, at least to an extent.  It's not like some role playing games where you can completely customize your character and gender.  Here. the character is a specific agent named Michael Thornton, and the customization options are cosmetic.  I put on a beret and some aviator sunglasses before moving on in the tutorial.As part of the tutorial, the game introduces three minigames.  One involves picking a lock, which I found to be pretty easy (too easy really).  The next involves disabling an alarm, which brings up a circuit board where you have to follow lines arranged in a maze-like fashion to figure out which pins to clip.  This was my favorite minigame, as it felt like just the right level of difficulty.  The last minigame I saw came when I was hacking a computer.  You are presented with a sea of text, which I assume represents computer code, and you have to match a series of letters and numbers in the text.  So it's kind of like a word hunt except the board is constantly changing letters, except for the static text you are looking for.  For me it was really hard to spot.During the tutorial I found myself interacting with other agents, which brings up another major part of Alpha Protocols gameplay.  Conversation is a big part of most role playing games, and this is no exception.  Each conversation will provide a choice of several responses, which are in the form of attitude options such as 'aggressive', or 'suave', or 'professional'.  These choices drive the conversation and can influence your relationship with the other party for better or worse.  The game makes it pretty clear that this conversation mechanic will be important when you are out in the field.I didn't progress that far in the game before my hour was up.  Once I got through through the tutorial, I was hit with the exposition dump to setup the first mission, and then it was off to Saudi Arabia.From what I saw, this game looks pretty promising, and I'm definitely looking forward to spending more time in it.Overall Recommendation:  Keep

Posted: December 21, 2014
												This is one of my favourite games of all time, almost as good as the first Deus Ex. It has meaningful choices and consequences, good stealth mechanics similar to Splinter Cell, a hacking minigame and excellent Mass Effect style dialogue options where you have the choice of being a dou che, being an aggressive dou che, or being a horny dou che. You can also equip an epic beard and straw hat for massive sex appeal. The bossfights are ridiculous and I mean that in a good way. There's one that is absolutely hilarious. The only downsides are that the RPG stat-based shooting mechanic- he's a world class spy, but he can't hit the broadside of a barn at 10 paces to start with. It's such a shame Sega abandoned it not long after release due to a lukewarm reception from the critics and poor sales, but they did release one patch. It is such an awesome game and you really have no excuse not to pick it up as it's dirt cheap now. I have actually completed this game twice but for some reason the Steam game time was bugged.

												Really fun game - would like to see more games of this type. Similar to Mass Effect (/ etc) in that it has a dialog wheel to choose various responses from, but it has the timed element from Telltale Games in here, too, so you have to choose fast.The gameplay is fairly straightforward - you can run in and murder everything, or you can play in a more pacifist style, taking down enemies without killing them and without being seen. I feel this is probably the more "fun" way to play the game, but you can certainly play it murder-hobo styles if you want.Good variety of characters, though as I recall, it runs a little light on female characters that aren't also love interests.And as with a lot of games like this (see: Deus Ex: HR), once you get invisibility, it rather trivialises a lot (but not all) of the game.

Posted: February 11
												This is an aged stealth/shooter/rpg game with a nonlinear gameplay. As being a stealth game, it's just par. as being an rpg, it's below par. It's not a good adventure, yet an unsuccessful action game. But in total, it's Alpha Protocol. During the game you are a special agent Michael Thorton (not Mike, never Thornton). You will get some missions such as kill A, meet with B, gather intel about C etc. At some point you may feel that the missions are repetitive. The enemy AI is not good enoug for a stealth game but time to time they can easily outnumber you. The plot is very generic. A field agent who used in a tricky mission goes underground to stop the 2nd cold war. During the gameplay you will encounter o bunch of NPCs. You will be given 2 to 4 chouices during the conversations. Some NPCs always like the first opion, while others like second or third. Depending on your choices you can get new missions and/or allies. Boss fights are hard but all they have some tricks to overcome. There are 3 miniganes also.Llockpick, hacking a cımputer and hacking an alarm system. All are not so hard and repetitive but you can pass them by using extra tools purchased from the market. I really enjoyed my gameplay time. It's a good game for old fashioned lads like myself.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Though it suffers from the troubled development that so often befalls Obsidian, Alpha Protocol is nevertheless an amazing RPG; It could be described as a superior copy of Mass Effect, adding actual choices and consequences in a more modern setting. The stealth and action are mediocre but the real core of the gameplay is in manipulating people through your actions. You are given about 5 seconds to make all your choices, be they flirting with a journalist on an airplane or deciding whether someone lives or dies and the game responds wonderfully to each one.Do you extort the arms dealer or arrest him? Do you smash a bottle over your contact's head when he wastes your time or play it cool to get on his good side? Do you bluff your way past the guards or sneak in through the roof? Extorting the arms dealer will get you some cash and a reluctant mole in the area while arresting him will provide you a nice bonus and reduce arms smuggling in the area, the enemy will have worse equipment but you might have a harder time getting gear for yourself. Assaulting your contact might result in him phoning up a friend at the place you're trying to sneak into, resulting in better security. Bluffing past the guards may be frowned upon by a more professional handler you chose while a more aggressive or sly one would have approved.You can play Alpha Protocol half a dozen times (ignore my playtime) and still find plenty of new things in every playthrough, I   found an entirely new mission in one playthrough that exposed a new side to two characters I had written off before, at another point I antagonized a character so much that they attacked me and left. I can think of few games that even come close to AP's reactivity, characters will call you out for anything from wearing full combat gear in public to leaving a trail of bodies in your wake.If you enjoy RPGs then Alpha Protocol definitely deserves a try.

number of helpful: 15 of 18 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												In my humble opinion I consider this game one of the best RPGs that I have played in the most recent years.This is mainly due to the choice & consequence prevalent throughout the entire title, what you do, how you talk and dress echoes and reverberates throughout the narrative and shapes your relationships with the generally varied cast of characters.It's not a game with open environments, but rather a game that funnels players to key locations but then lets the player choose with what method obstacles will be approached, both on a macro- and micro-level (Do I go to Rome first? Do I equip myself with casual clothing for this mission? Should I respond with a snarky or professional comment? Do I sneak past or kill this guard?)Alpha Protocol also boasts a strong amount of replayability purely to discover the various ways in which conversations and characters actions are altered by the player's choices.However the game is not as polished when it comes to the actual missions and the combat in those, I feel there's a lack of depth in the stealth, bodies disappear almost immediately, enemies patrol almost like robots and for some reason bashing open locked doors immediately triggers an alarm, even if said door is just a rickety wooden one not visibly connected to anything.The combat is functional, but not fantastical, assault rifles and SMGs feel neglected compared to the awe-stopping power of a shotgun and the critical-hit-with-blindfire pistol method.Bossfights can be either annoying or terrible, depending on if you built your character around combat or stealth (and tech) respectively, this is simply due to the player being forced into combat even if the rest of the mission had been successfully approached with complete silence.Overall I'd very much recommend it if you enjoy choice & consequence, character interactions and generally being a special ops man who may or may not shoot gun a lot, just remember to put at least some points into one type of firearm.
