content:
Posted: March 9
												This game really is a mixed bag.To keep it short, this is a third-person shooter with RPG elements (conversations, relations, skills). The overarching story has to do with espionage and conspiracies and thriller stuff like that. You play the role of Michael Thorton, a new recruit in Alpha Protocol. You can pick different backstories that affect your starting skills as well as some conversations later down the line, a la Mass Effect 1.To highlight the good points, I really enjoyed the conversation system in this game. It was very similar to Mass Effect, and the voice acting was solid for the respective roles of the characters. The story seemed interesting at times, and enough to keep me going.However, that's where the good points end. This is an incredibly clunky game while in the shooting sections, and regularly glitched on my computer. It was nothing game-breaking, but very immersion-breaking. Also, the shooting mechanics seemed woefully half baked. You can improve your shooting skills, but your reticule never gets any smaller even when crouched and not moving, and its a big damn reticule which means this super secret agent f##king sucks at shooting.Also, its VERY short for a single-player-only RPG; probably about 9-10 hours. Tripling that length wouldn't fix all this games issues, but i'd still press on because I wanted to see how Thorton's story ended.I really wish I could give this game a recommendation. I really do like it, but this is disappointing coming from a studio as good as Obsidian. I'd definitely play a sequel if they made one, but they'd have to iron out the bugs and tighten up the story. I wanted to see deeper and more involved conversations and character development.As it is though, I cannot give this game a recommendation unless its on sale for $2. I REALLY hope Obsidian makes a sequel, because I will definitely be first in line to buy it.

content:
Posted: January 23
												The real star of the show here is the reactivity of the story.The story itself isn't really great or anything but it is very reactive, not only to your choices in dialogue but also during regular gameplay. Decide against killing mooks? The game will react. Decide to complete an objective a different way? The game will react. It's basically like having the story as a game mechanic.The gameplay on the other hand isn't really that good. It can be a little buggy or broken in places, but nothing show stopping. You can become somewhat over powered relatively quickly with the right set of skills so if things begin to become a slog try another skill set.Multiple playthroughs are necessary to really appreciate the story.Gets my "Replayability" stamp of approval.

												Sure, the game is far from polished and will never be anything more than a rough beta.But it's one hell of a rough beta.This is THE 1990's Spy Action-RPG you've been waiting for. Every trope, from ninja invisibility to incredible martial arts to sniper pistols to shooting rocket launchers at bad guys to stereotypical terrorists to evil corporations to disco-rock coke addict mafiosos - It's. number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												More greatness from Obsidian but this time in the form of a third person spy rpg and I must say there's so much right about this game with just a few minor technicalities. Firstly, the story was very well done and I liked how it went full circle from start to finish with a few non-linear points in the game that leaves you asking questions of how your actions affect the future and the repercussions they have.  Speaking of actions, the dialogue and choice system in this game was one of the best i've witnessed personally and I've seen a few people complain about the timer on the choices but I really didn't mind it and I felt it added to the realism of Alpha Protocol. The choices definitely have consequences and carry weight and I felt guilty at times in the game when I felt that I made the wrong decision and it actually made me want to go back and settle the score.  My main gripe with Alpha Protocol is the combat as it felt messy and bareboned at first, I could tell that Obsidian modelled the combat system and upgrade system after Mass Effect as it bore a striking resemblance but it wasn't as good i'm afraid. However, towards the middle of the game the combat picked up a little and I genuinely enjoyed the upgrade system and rpg elements that were present.  Overall, I would certainly reccomend Alpha Protocol to fans of the Mass Effect series and just rpg shooters in general and I just loved the clever, political writing like a corporation starting wars just to make massive profit by selling weapons to both sides.

												This game was released 6 years ago to a divided response and it's obvious why; the combat is sometimes unresponsive, the AI is glitchy at times and the shooting mechanics take a while to get used to, but on the opposite side of the spectrum Alpha Protocol is a fun game that plays like the Mass Effect series - its biggest strength is in the story and the dialogue options, which can change the outcomes of the story and the fates of its characters. This game, despite its apparent faults is still fairly (but at times frustratingly) playable and quite fun, with plenty of replayability depending on the choices you make. It's a shame that this didn't become a franchise and that there's barely any other games that allow you to play as a badass spy.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2011
												Finally. An RPG that's NOT high fantasy, sci-fi, or some JRPG hybrid. You have choices but there are no blatant "right" vs "wrong" picks like other games. The plot is reactive and you might not even encounter major NPCs at all between one play and another. The plot isn't idiotic. The characters are all unique, and in true Black Isle/Obsidian form, the dialogue is spot-on. But this isn't Mass Effect 2. The gameplay mechanics are rough around the edges. The stealth systems work but don't feel fully realized. Enemies can spot bodies, but bodies vanish after a few seconds. Later you get the ability to turn invisible and walk right up to people to KO them yet remain undetected. Gunplay isn't quite a "shooter" under the hood. The UI for activating abilities/gadgets/ammo types is kind of clunky. But the rest of the game's good enough that you accept it.Alpha Protocol was a financial DISASTER. Nobody bought it. The reviews were middling. But I so, SO wish more games were like this.

												One of the most underestimated game ever made. Combat mechanics might get little clunky and graphics are not mindblowing, but the real game is in the story and how it revolves around your actions. There are so many endings and playthroughs and most of it will be different every time you play the game. When you have possibility to go to missions and you choose for example mission in Russia, the things you learn and story there will influence next mission, but if you chose that next mission first, the story will revolve differently. ALso characters will behave in the way, you interact with them. This is truly worth an applause for Obsidian, who took the crown from Bioware in my opinion. Apprentice has become master.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Obsidian's underrated espionage RPG, Alpha Protocol has amazing malleability and replayability as far as how you shape the story with your mission choices and the way you treat others. The open nature of choosing your missions can cause you to meet allies who will help you in later missions... or remember what you did to them the next time you meet, so be cautious; you may even miss a couple of characters entirely depending on where your travels take you!The game also has an incredible dialog system, where people will come to know you by your actions and expect you to act a certain way - you can prove them right, or throw them off - something that can come to your advantage played carefully. Enemy or ally, both can work to your favor. Also interesting is the ability to choose a background that further affects conversations and gives your extra points in different categories. (choose Rookie first!)While the gameplay is your standard TPS/RPG hybrid, this game is a must have for anyone that enjoys games with top tier dialog and freedom of character development such as Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines or Fallout: New Vegas.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												 Another one of those underappreciated near classics. An espionage thriller narrated as a series of cut-scenes with action interludes. A terse story, and what your character says and does during the action scenes has a powerful effect on what happens later. Character gets better weapons as the game progresses but cannot carry much and descretion is often the better part of valour--or can go full noise and to hell with the consequences. If anything, going fully stealth with fully tricked out stealth pistol is overpowered. Doesn't worry me-- I like to avoid unnecessary killing. Quality falls away a little toward the end. More time, more polish and this rough diamond would have been a real masterpiece. Just buy it, it's cheap and a single playthrough is quick. A single playthrough is not enough, a full exploration will take four or five playthroughs.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
 Would you like to take part in an action movie where the protagonist got betrayed by his higher ups and gone rogue and then needs to stop the "Evil forces" from "destroying the world"? If yes, Welcome to Alpha Protocol or "<instert_movie_title_here> : The Game ."  Alpha Protocol, is an cover-based RPG shooter(yeah sounds weird but that how it plays for me at least) in which decision matters. Game got decent replay value but thats if you overcome the little performance setbacks(that I only read about) .  Story One thing that grab me was the story or to be more precise, the way the story is being told. You start the game with a tutorial missions and once you complete them, you gonna be send on the field. But before that you gonna be send to forward in time during an interrogation in which you gonna hear something like "overview" of your past actions and this happens for most part of the game . After the interrogation you are send on the field where the game actually starts.Without spoiling much( aka wont say nothing about start and end of the game) can freely say that most of the game happens in 3 cities : Rome,Moscow and Taipei . Each of the cities got its own main "questline" but you can unlock side quests if you buy intel from the black market. But have in mind ... once you leave the city you cant go back so you may try to complete it all.In terms of actual plot ... well its pretty generic : you are betrayed, you go rogue, you have to oppose a big corporation before it start a war. During the journey you will meet different characters that may or may not help you . Dialogue Game offers decision making that often counts on your response during little chit chat and less about the action you take. But you have to be a fast thinker when comes to picking a response because the game doesnt want to break immersion. But no worries since you can response in 3 ways: professional, offensive and suave. You have to take in mind that different characters respond differently to your answers so you must be quite a talker if you want to profit with your tongue. And by profit I mean getting some bonus intel or perks . Hell, you may even skip half a mission if you know the right guy! Missions The game isn’t a straight line of mission after mission. Instead you are given a safehouse(hub) from which you buy and equip gear, obtain intel and start missions. You still have main missions but by doing side missions may unlock different ways to complete missions or simple perks. Now some missions are available only for some “period of time”  so you have to pick well what mission to do and when. Skills While you play you will gather experience points which will give you ability points that will help you upgrade your skills : Stealth , 4 weapons(Pistol, SMG , Shotgun and Assault Rifles) , Sabotage , Technical Aptitude , Toughness and Martial Arts . Now you cant max them all so you have to pick the best that suits your style. To help you out with this, the game offers you to pick 1 class out of 3... or make your own class if you pick the option Freelancer.While upgrading your skills you will "learn" some abilities to help you out in emergencies. Though some abilities like "Shadow Operative" makes the game feel more fantasy than realistic which is a shame. But overall game gives options for different styles though at some times its punishing and makes no sense. Equipment What is gonna be a RPG game without gear,huh? Well the gear options in here is quite limited but still add some sort of depth ... maybe . Before every mission you can check your gear and gear up the way you want it with gadgets and such.You can carry 2 weapons at once and you can customize them a bit. You can change their barrel,scope, magazine and grip. Once you are done with it its time to pick your suit. Suit can be equiped with up to 4 different modifications that can help you out. Last but not least you got your gadgets wheel which you can fill with grenades, mines, EMP, first aid and some others that I never used.  Once geared up its time to head to the battlefield .And always be sure that you have enough ammo to start the mission without problems. Combat and Shooting As said, combat is mainly cover-based shooter style but you can do stealth takedowns and as far as I remember one boss fight ended up with kiting a lot .Now the shooting is a bit different than most games because you need to "focus" aka wait for your crosshair to get smaller and brighter before you make your shot. This is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off players quite fast in early games when you dont have any upgrades in your weapon of choice skill. There arent that many big fire fights to make it a "rage-quit" material. Overall it need some time to get used to it . Hacking Now time for the most annoying part of the game for most players. The mini games for hacking,picklocking and switching off alarms.Now switching off alarms is fairly easy : you need to press the right switches in maze-like scheme.Picklocking is also fairly easy: put in line the switches .Hacking ... oh lord ... the hacking ... I wonder how many people actually quit the game because of it .Check this image : http://abload.de/img/ap7dbuso.jpg or a video to see what I'm talking about. In-game all numbers will be switching non-stop and your goal is to find the line of symbols that isnt moving and mark them.. with one of the 2 line of codes you are given . But be careful.. one wrong step and you gonna set the alarm on and you will need to re-do it . So you are better to put points in Sabotage if you want to manually do the hacking.Or you can just stock up yourself with EMPs and not bother with any of those. Replay Value The game got quite some replay value, 3 endings, several approaches on different missions, unlocking missions by talking much. Its easily can keep your interest for 2-3 playthrougs. First one is always to try the soil and then you may focus on different objectives. Overall Nice story, neat idea and RPG elements but quite lacking gameplay elements and with possible performance issues(for which you better check the hub) .

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Alpha Protocol.Underrated but still quite an awesome game. I was pleasantly surprised as i entered its world of espionage and from the beginning, it shows you that your decisions have weight. They actually matter, unlike in other games that promise that your decisions have outcomes, this one delivers. You can be a really suave spy, a really aggressive 'roided up spy or a professional killer spy or even a combination of the three. You can make people hate you or like you. Both of those have corresponding consequences/rewards. Makes for interesting conversation choices throughout the story.The graphics of this game are okay in my opinion. It hasn't aged that badly actually. The combat mechanics aren't as bad as i was expecting but there are exploits that players would discover. For instance, melee attacks are OP as well as pistols. In my playthrough, i never needed to use my rifle or any other gun for that matter. Why? Chain Shooting. The Chain Shooting skill for the pistol makes for quick and deadly executions. (think today's Splinter Cell: Conviction/Hitman: Absolution's Execution/Instict kills.) I found stealthing the whole map to be an enjoyable experience as the enemies barely have time to react to you punching their lights out.The story is well told and your decisions have an impact on how the game tells it to you. I can't say much about it without spoiling so you'll have to play it. This game is well worth the full retail price, but if you're on the fence or just don't wanna spend a lot, you can wait for a sale so that you can pick it up and enjoy some espionage.I want a sequel to this game so bad.But sadly, Beta Protocol is still in Alpha.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												At maximum stealth level, you can basically walk through most maps entirely unseen, taking the most direct route from checkpoint to checkpoint, entirely invisible to all the enemies.  It's like the game designers realized you'd get bored with the game, so they gave you an option to just skip most of it.  They also gave you a pistol, which at high levels can one-shot kill almost any enemy in the game, if you wanted to skip the bulk of combat as well.  There are at least two easy ways to play the game 'right,' and I found one unfortuante way to play the game 'wrong.'  While the pistol can kill anything, the shotgun can barely kill the starting enemies.  Leveling it up doesn't make it materially better.  If you chose a shotgun build, you've chosen wrong, and the game will punish you for it.  The one interesting aspect of the game is also one of its most frustrating.  Conversations have real consequences and are hard to reset and replay.  It encourages you to research your conversation targets well, like you're supposed to, and to accept convesation mistakes if you make them.  But it's too easy to make mistakes.  The game doesn't tell you what you're character is going to say, it just says something like, "suave."  Now "suave" might be cool and seductive when talking to one character, but creepy and stalker-ish when talking to another.  You don't know until you click the button what ridiculous crap is going to come out of your mouth.  So I never really felt like my conversation choices were "my choices."  It was just a question of whether I pushed the 'right' button, or the 'wrong' one, based on what the online wiki said.  That's not fun.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Alpha Protocol 

			Views: 1,441		

			Alpha Protocol is a modern Spy style stealth RPG 3rd person shooter. Available at Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/34010/ Here is what I found for the fix For The FOV.		

	Alpha Protocol is a modern-esque style third person stealth game withan enriching story element.  The first thing to notice is that the sensitivityin the aim mechanic is just insane, if not annoying to the point of unplayable.The game would benefit from a field of view slider, or the ability to scroll out as well.  	The story centers around a top secret governmental program createdto  do the governments dirty work, so at the same time giving them plausible deniability if anything should go wrong.  It is a modern James Bond game,without the corny puns.  The choices you make effect how the environmentshapes around you.  The result of your choices change the context of the game,making you feel like what you do matters.  	The character build comes with many different options for what you can choose as a specialization, as well as active and passive abilities.  This adds to the games replay-ability.  In addition, the weapons come with a largevariety of customization options.  The guns feel good, and convey the rightweight and power that you want to have in a shooter game.  You can play the game in the style you want, whether it be melee, ranged, or stealth; the game doesn't punish you for playing how you want but rewards you for it.	The game also offers the option for technical minigames; you are forthe most part not forced to lock pick or hack to get to certain areas; you could, for example, use a grenade to force your way past.  The difficulty of the minigames increases as you level up, but they offer variations so that it's not repetitive and boring.  The only issue I had was with the computer hacking  minigame, in which again the extreme mouse sensitivity leads to not completing the hack within the time limit, which then activates alarms, and can then lead to pulling you out of the stealth mode you had successfully completed until that moment.  	The combat is done very effectively.  You can charge in to attack yourenemies, but be aware that the enemy will respond to your tactics, and employ methods to try and counter your approach.  The stealth element was very satisfying, as you can actually ghost through a level if you choose. The enemies level in difficulty, adding to the suspense and requiring that you choose how to level your character carefully, or follow the preselected level design paths for you. As well as making you think more about how you are going to approach any situation.  	The level design is done very well.  Despite the fact that it is linear,each zone looks different, and every mission adds variety in enemies and aesthetic, making the linear aspect a non-issue.	The game interacts with you; your choices make a difference.  You cancreate the character you want to create, and play the way you want to play.  This game has been enjoyable to play; I never felt that my time was wasted.  This is an easy game to recommend.This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you towatch if you are looking for a more in-depth review.Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												This is the most reactive rpg I have played. Everything is so tightly done regarding the dialog system and how it  REACTS to previous choices.  It is just a shame that the gameplay it is attached to is pretty mediocre, and fairly bad in some of the minigames.The game's easy mode is to max up pistol and brilliance.  That is the best. You get 3 "moods" for every response. From memory, left is cold and professional, up is AGGRESSIVE, and right is suave. It is meant to be 3 spy archetypes, Jason Bourne, Jack Bauer, and James Bond, but the "Bond" option instead ends up being the Sterling Archer option.Needless to say, if you are fond of Archer, doing at least ONE playthrough with  THAT set is a treat. This is a title that seems pretty bleh or mediocre on the first playthrough, but just the sheer amount of detail and change that can happen with apparently MINOR decisions makes it shine above pretty much everything else before and after it. Play it. Then try it again. If you can stand its (now for me very minor) issues of gameplay being rather mediocre, it is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing set of experiences. It is a game that no matter if you play it 10 times, you will find new details on each playthrough. You  CANNOT experience all of it in one single playthrough.Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												'Mass Effect' and 'Splinter Cell' had a child named 'Alpha Protocol'. It turned out to be a flawed genius. There are a lot of faults with this game. Broken gameplay mechanics, PS2-era graphics, inconsistent frame-rates and an uninspired beginning. But if one can look past its many shortcomings, this game turns out to be an absolute gem. A global espionage-RPG in the true sense. To start things off, you first pick your character's class: Soldier (firearms), Field Agent (stealth), Tech Specialists (hacking) or Freelancer (a combination of skills of the player's choice). Each class determines how well you perform a specific task in the field. With regards to gameplay, I'm sure the devs were targeting a realistic approach to combat. For instance, you have to aim at a target for few seconds to let the reticule converge. Thus, ensuring that every gunfight turned out to be a challenge. The melee system comprised of martial arts which allowed you to knockout enemies either stealthily or engage them head-on. All character abilities were upgradeable with sufficient experience points (XP). Hacking was one of the highlights of the game. There was a unique system in place each for hacking computers, opening locks or bypassing keypads and alarms. Many people found the hacking system frustrating but I think it was fairly straight-forward. Challenging, yes, but very rewarding in the end. The graphics were rubbish, plain and simple. Character animations were clunky, anti-aliasing horrible, lighting awful, movements jerky and texture loading very slow. These were some of the biggest down-sides of an otherwise fantastic game. Level designs were very good though with plenty of alternative routes to complete objectives.The plot is where this game really shines. The story is gripping and opens up once you're done with the Saudi missions. And it hurtles you head-first into a global conspiracy mess. Allies (and enemies) are made along the way and your treatment of them has future implications in the form of gaining intel, weapons, money (if allies) or facing problems and hurdles (if enemies). Reading their dossier in advance helps you choose favourable options during dialogue sequences. Characters are interesting and unlike many other RPG games, dialogue never feels bland. Alpha Protocol needs a sequel to set its problems right. It requires perseverance and patience to overlook its many problems and bear with its frustrating nature but underneath all that, this game is a true gem. One not to be missed.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												tl;dr: Could have been a good game - a prime example of balancing gone awfully wrong. Normally I would love this game. I *should* love this game. But I can't. It's like getting drunk. At first, it's fun. Then, you regret it and swear to never do it again. Rinse, repeat.The spy-theme is cool, and I love the idea of this RPG. Storywise there are no complaints from me. Graphics are a bit outdated by now, but I can live with that. Sound, music and voice acting is really good.Overall, this could really be enjoyable. As the main character, you get the sense of being in the middle of a spy movie. It is immersing. You can customize the skill tree of your character. Straight-up shooter? Tech wiz? Silent but deadly? All this is possible. And it allows you to approach situations in different ways. Mostly. Sometimes.Except where it doesn't. Then the game flushes sneaking or tech wizardry down the toilet, and you hopefully have maxed out one of the weapon skills when waves of enemies are thrown at you. Oh, you did not? Prepare to die, Mr. Thorton. Seriously, Deus Ex has shown years before this game how it is done properly.And the boss fights. Impossible for me to win. I can accept a challenge. I can accept a tough game. But this is ludicrous. I simply followed the game and wanted to complete my first city, Moscow. There is no indication in the game that the particular mission could be too hard. So you sneak through the compound, face the boss. And then you die. Again. And again. And again. And then you give up, forget the last hour that you sank into the game for nothing, and follow a different path (mostly because I googled how to win this fight - turns out you should do a few missions elsewhere first). Where you also encounter another boss. Same story. I died, again. And again.Save points do not help. Sometimes they are too far apart (e.g.: that one triad attack mission), so you have to repeat almost an entire level. 15 minutes of playtime, wiped away. Over and over again. Hey, Obsidian, I know the game is targeted for consoles. Get your act together on the PC. Let me save anywhere I want. It's not the 90s anymore. Challenge me with smart gameplay, not technical limitations.Speaking of which: navigating the levels can be tricky. Mike does not always go where I want him to go. The camera sometimes turns suddenly by 180deg, and sometime the main character does as well. Very annoying when you started aiming for the bad guys. Moving around, taking cover, getting out of cover... not as fluent as it could be - as demonstrated by other games from the same year.Thing is: would I read this review, I would think that I could live with all that. And sometime I can. Then the game shines, and it's fun, and it's challenging. I enjoy it for a few minutes. And then the hammer falls, and I curse under my breath.There are very few games that literally enrage me. This is one of them. To vent, I can either smash something - or write a review. My things around me appreciate me writing this. I really want to love this game. I want to play it again. Maybe I will in the future, when I forgot how horrible and angry I felt when I played it last.Or maybe I simply made all the wrong choices and leveled all the wrong skills and gave all the wrong answers. I still don't think a game should punish me for that, but, well...Summary:+ I love the spy theme+ interesting characters+ decent story+ this game makes you emotional...- ...unfortunately, this emotion is "hate"- clunky controls- friggin' save points- horrible balance- animation of Mike sneaking is... umm... funny?- Deus Ex did it better, years ago- for me, cheating by changing the config files was the only way to salvage some funRecommendation:get it when the price is really cheap (and I mean *really* cheap), or you really want a challenge...

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												While not a bad game per se, Alpha Protocol attempts to be too many things at once and manages to be mediocre at all of them. It wants to be an action-RPG like Mass Effect with dialogue branchs and a reputation system, but the depth of conversation seems to be superficial. Choosing to be polite or a jackass illicits different reactions for the first sentence, but proceeds to give you the same information after the reaction. It feels hamfisted and doesn't carry as much weight as it could have.AP also tries to mimic stealth games like Splinter Cell, but the detection system feels arbitrary. Sometimes getting spotted feels completely random; you may have been perfectly sneaky, in the shadows and out of sight, only to have an enemy spot you from afar anyways. I've seen worse stealth implementations by far, but not from titles that are supposed to be this caliber.The action also feels a bit dull too. For an agent who is supposed to be highly trained, the protagonist can't aim to save his life. I've spent enough time with guns to know that all the guns in this game will hit point of aim at any of the distances you will find in AP. Shooting basically feels like its a punishment for not sneaking properly, and sneaking is such a gamble that the two combined get aggravating.Also, most of the characters are boring, and a few of them could have been lumped into one person for all I care.Anyways, if you're looking for some stealth gameplay, an immersive RPG, or a good third person shooter I'd suggest looking for a game that does only what you're looking for and not Alpha Protocol. This game isn't bad, but it's hard to recommend because it's so mediocre. I could only recommend this if you want to pretend to be James Bond and none of the Bond games out there appeal to you.

												Alpha Protocol is one of the best games I have played, and it is one of the most underrated games I have ever come across.Alpha Protocol is a espionage RPG where you play as Michael Thornton, an agent who is sworn to protect the interests of the USA.The beauty of this game, which is a little older now, is how amazingly, intensely deep the choice system is. Similar to Deus Ex, the game revolves around how *you decide to play*. I've never known a game to be affected so much by the decisions you make, moreso than Deus Ex. The game is hugely fun. The controls are a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but they are superb when using a controller. So do that. I hugely recommend this game, so good.Nilesy

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I finished the game playing as stealth character and a little bit of shooting.I do not recommend the game that much.Here is a summary of what I think of the game:The positives:+ Does have variety of environments. + Interesting dialoug system and very similar to Mass Effect's. The only difference between this game and mass effect is that your response is timed. Pressing X usually gives a charming/sarcastic response, Y for more agrressive and angry, and B for Profoessional and calm.Meh:* Has various "mini-games" such as picking locks and hacking. They do get repititve and they feel unrewarding to do.* There is ingame cash in which you could pay for weapons, upgrades, armors, and missions intel. However, since combat is bad (I will get to that) then having tons of guns doesn't really help.* Character is customizable but the customization are kind of limited. The negatives:- Combat is very annoying especially when starting off the game. It takes from early Ghost Recon games where you have to stand still and aim at your target until the cursor circle gets smaller. This is not suitable for this game at all especially when you are caught with too many guards and they are close to you. It also make boss fights frustrating.- A.I. with stealth is very very basic. If a guard get the sight of you, alert mode starts right away. This gets very annoying because sometimes they can see you even when you are behind a wall or a cover. Unlike games like Tenchu or MGS, the guard has no "Hmmm?" window. If he sees you expect swarm of guards coming at you.- The game is not clear on the benefit of killing humans or knock them out since bodies simply disappear after 10 seconds. True that killing humans might trigger some conversations with NPCs later on, but this has no noticeable gameplay factor at all.- Camera is a bit annoying and feels a bit stiff. Reminds you of some PS2 titles.- Movement is not as fluid sometimes. For example, when you reload, the character stops moving. - Stealth moves are very limited. For example, you can only jump on certain locations and others you can't. You can never move above any obstacle.How good is the story?The story did not really get me interested. It is very similar to Splinter Cell games. Voice acting is good. Didn't like most of the writing. Romance is very very very awkward and tasteless. OverallThe idea behind the game got potential. At first instance, it seems like it can be a Mass Effect meets Metal Gear. However the game is simply not up to expectations and much of its elements are outdated.

												Funny enough this critically panned game is probably one of Obsidian's best efforts in the last several years.  The C&C is on par with the original Deus Ex (and arguably better although it benefits from a decade of tech advance) in that the ramifications of decisions made at one point won't manifest until much later and the results are more than just cosmetic/cutscene oriented.  Unfortunately the combat is weak, level design is sub-par, and stealth is poorly implemented.  Compounding these issues are some utterly broken talents like Chainshot and Shadow Operative that trivialize any and all combat situations.  Could have been a great game but still worth a playthrough despite the flaws.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												When I heard about Alpha Protocol, I had two thoughts. One was that an espionage action-RPG was one of the best ideas for a video game I'd heard. Alpha Protocol delivers on that. The story is a pretty damned good espionage potboiler. It could almost be a lost installment of the Bourne series. That the story is pretty damned good isn't all that surprising given it's an Obsidian production. These are the people who did KotOR II and Fallout: New Vegas. True to form, expect outstanding writing, difficult choices in terms of what the "right" thing to do is, witty dialogue and bold characterization.Of course, Obsidian has another, less positive reputation, and that's for delivering unfinished, buggy games with as much cut content as what's actually in the game. Unlike KotOR II and New Vegas, there's no real modding community that I could find dedicated to restoring cut content (if, indeed, it was even accessible). Reading about Alpha Protocol I braced for the game to bug out frequently and to have plot holes I could drive a Mack truck through due to cut content. Honestly? I was pleasantly surprised. Maybe I'm just unperceptive, but after one minor bug in the early going and one crash to desktop, the game played smoothly. There was one instance where the game triggered a flag that I had done something that I hadn't, which got brought up in the story as a plot point a few times later on. And...that's it. For Obsidian, that's shockingly solid. And as mentioned above, the story was satisfying. I'm sure there were things that were cut, but for what it's worth the story didn't have the trainwreck feel of the end of the (pre-restoration) KotOR II.The gameplay is fun. One way to think of the game is to think of it as an espionage Mass Effect. Another way, one I think is an even better comparison, is that it is more of a spiritual ancestor of Deus Ex: Human Revolution than the previous Deus Ex games were. There's definitely no "right" way to play the game and build your character though you can make the game much harder if you generalize OR specialize too much. Playing a stealth-oriented character is tough in the early going but once you start to unlock higher powers it's almost game-breaking...except against the mostly-unskippable boss fights. Also similar to Human Revolution, if you've only been focusing on non-offensive powers, the boss battles can be ball-bustingly hard.I've heard Alpha Protocol talked about as a "flawed gem", which is pretyt much how ALL Obsidian games are regarded. On the bell curve of what Obsidian games are usually like, I found Alpha Protocol to have a stable build, a complete story and good if not MGS great levels of stealth-action gameplay. If you like action RPGs and want to play in a fresh and different setting, you'd do well by this in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
Title: Alpha ProtocolGenre:  Action, RPGDeveloper:  Obsidian EntertainmentPublisher: SEGARelease Date: 28th May, 2010TL;DRSpies. Shooting things! Missions. And a whole barrel of fun. ProsGraphics are great, and good for 2010 too when this game first came outGood voice actingYou can make your own adventure/define your character's personalityStoryline hooks youConsWould like to scroll through weapons rather than go into a menuAiming weapons isn't perfect No option to reread the tutorial (I got 15min stuck on hacking at one point :p)  Gameplay Originally an Xbox 360 game, this action RPG takes you straight into the world of spies and espionage (after selecting the type of agent you want to be), and you wake up in a lab, spending the “tutorial” of the game breaking out. It helps to use your common sense factor as well as the game mechanics of rolling around shuffle sneaking with a funny walk and hitting people. And possibly shooting everyone too. I didn't make my character too sneaky. And I think I set off the alarm by failing to pick the lock. I also accidentally shot someone when figuring how to sneak and be aware, so instead of being covert and suitably spy like, I ended up just shooting everything. ♥♥♥♥♥es got nothing. Who needs stealth? Ha! Not that I'm defining my playstyle or anything. Let me just make my character look incognito by giving him big black glasses and a beret. No one will suspect anything.The storyline balances well with the action given, it's enjoyable to follow, from your orientation/induction teaching you the different weapons and methods of succeeding, to the life challenging missions upsetting criminal organisations around the globe. It's pretty much like a James Bond movie in game form. The voice acting is good. I like how I can have the options to be sarcastic, professional, indifferent or defiant, so I can create my own personality within the game.The music is appropiately slueth like, giving the feel you're sneaking around against the clock. It helps to set the mood.The types of puzzles in this game vary, though most of them centre around time limits. For example you need to pick a lock in a certain amount of time, or clip circuits in order, or hack a computer by finding the embedded code on a screen of randomly generating numbers – though that took me quite a few tries to figure out since the instruction wasn't so clear.The graphics are good, the environments are well defined and it's visually easy to follow your progress through a mission, along with promptings when you reach the right spot. It's high end Xbox 360 graphics so you can expect some prettiness.The Ai mechanics focus on brute force, deceit/sneaking and picking and choosing targets, and explosions. I used sound generators to lure people into traps ... then punched them out myself.There will be points where you can't get away with the reckless playing, because the alarm system will pull everything in the vicinity to take you down. It's a shame you can't scroll through to find the weapon of your choice, you need to go into a menu and select them. For me I have to press G in order to start looking in the menu. I would prefer it being more fast paced by being able to quickly scroll through weapons.Overall VerdictRecommended. It could even be worth more, so I'm happy to get it for the price I got it at. You can choose to be stealthy or not. You have the option to play it out how you want. And that for me makes it fun.Want to read more of my reviews? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												While some might be put off by the rough edges this game has, or even the medicore graphics. Underneath it all, is gem of a game that gets overlooked far too often. This game is a mix with Metal Gear Solid, Splinter Cell, and Mass Effect. That said it does not fly above those titles in the things it takes from them, but still does a good job of blending them together and creating an overall enjoyable experince. Alpha Protocol has a decent storyline, while it will not set the bar for years to come I found myself pretty invovled and caught up in the narrative. The characters you interact with are all great, some I felt closer to more than others. I found myself wanting to please certain ones, while others I didn't care to impress, even going as far as being a jerk to them as much as I could. The dialog within conversations is wonderful, everyone who has lines feels natural and nothing feels forced. Conversations depending on you're responses and if you are well liked or hated change fluidly and can really change situations, sometimes going as far as changing major story plots. In today's game industry people often go for graphics over gameplay, which is a shame because with Alpha Protocol, it often gets overlooked for just that reason. The game is by no means a "ugly" game, it even looks nice in most parts. But it will not blow you away, of course since this game is using the Unreal Engine 3 (a crap engine anyways, one that far too many devs depend on) the standard Unreal Engine 3 issues like texture pop in, and missing textures for a few seconds tend to happen. The gameplay is another issues where this game often gets slammed hard. It is not a 3rd person shooter, it is a RPG mixed with 3rd person shooter elements. You will not go in popping headshots and lighting up the AI with machine guns while chugging down a can of mt. dew. You will need to put the skill points you earn into different weapon types, if you do not put skill points into say, assault rifles, you will not hit anything with them ever. If you want to be Solid Snake and sneak throughout missions, you will need to put skill points into stealth, or you will not be sneaking anywhere. You want to be a expert computer hacker, better put skills into the skill tree for that, also different classes and speicalizations effect you differently as well.  The game also has a large assortment of guns, bullets, items and parts for weapons you can customize you're personal arsenal with. In closing, this is a often overlooked gem brought to you by Obsidian, so it does bugs and sometimes feels kinda rushed, but is still worth playing. If you still feel iffy on it, it goes on sale often for 3$ or less dollars during sales. There is no reason not to give this game a try.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Alpha Protocol lets you take the role of Michael Thorton, a new agent of the top secret organisation Alpha Protocol. During the game you will solve a global missile crisis, expose traitors and do all that good spy stuff we know and love. The story behind the game is well done, with no plot holes I could find and believable, if slightly caricatured, characters. It will take you through several different missions in an order of your choice, with each mission influencing the other ones and demanding meaningful choices that not only warrant, but leave you encouraged for several playthroughs.Gameplay is varied and easily customized to your liking; in fact, this is one of the very few games where both stealth and going in guns blazing is a valid choice in all situations, though some might favour one thing over the other. Combat is not your standard Third Person Shooter - Mike actually has to aim his weapons, which constantly affords you the choice of going for precise, slow shots or spraying and hoping for the best. This choice is by no means obvious; while precise shots are generally preferable, one kind of weapon (the SMGs) actually rewards spray and pray behaviour.To me, the really interesting part was the dialogue system. Talking to people becomes a far more engaging experience than in other titles simply due to the fact that you are timed and the game actually progresses while you speak. Have a skill on cooldown? Keep the terrorist talking until you're good and ready to take him down. Filled to the brim with adrenaline and fuming at the mouth? Cut his speech short before you come down and your buff runs out. Not only that, but most of the conversations actually feel realistic and have a strong impact on the world around you. If you tell someone off, this will be represented in your later communications, and he might be more hesitant to help you or just not mention information, preferring not to go the extra mile for the idiot that insulted him. Ths makes the game world seem very alive and helps the characters become more than just cutouts with a "press button, get quest" mechanism.Not only do you have a choice in the way you fight and the way you talk, you also have an rpg-like levelling system to shape Michael the way you want him to be. Not only are placing skill points and unlocking abilities, the world also changes you. Depending on your actions and the things that happen, you gain perks that can influence everything from hitpoints to skill cooldowns to equipment prices.All in all I heartily recommend you pick up the game if you like spy thrillers and/or third person RPGs/shooters. This game has an awesome storyline and interesting customization options that easily rival games like Mass Effect. However, you should know that more than a few people have reported bugs, some of them game breaking, and while I personally have never encountered any be aware that you may have to fiddle a bit to make everything run smoothly.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												***Welcome to Alpha Protocol Recruit!***Disclaimer: This game is an espionage RPG, NOT a SHOOTER. So your hard-earned split second pixel hunting skills do not matter that much.When I have noticed this game, at first I was sceptical due to multitude of bad reviews out there but the game itself proved me wrong over and over. Feeling masochistic I decided to set the difficulty to hard and chose Recruit background which essentially starts with no skill at all. *Your Career As an Agent*At the initial stages of the game you choose a background and decide about your skills which you shall develop and the amount of different skills provide a good deal of options to you. Whether you want to go in stealthily, guns blazing or with Bond-style techs, you can develop such abilities as the game progresses. Of course when you approach the game you should consider that this game is RPG which means for example when you use an Assault Rifle, investing in some mods to stabilize your weapon and supporting that with some Assault Rifle skills...you will have an easier time. Do not expect shooter style easy aiming. If you are inexperienced at a certain skill do not expect your gaming reflexes to save you. And similarly if you do not invest in Stealth abilities, you will have a hard time remaining unnoticed...but it is not impossible. Everything in this game tries to enhance your preferred gameplay style.Now as an agent of Alpha Protocol you will be given an initial training and then they will send you to certain missions where everything you do or say will have a future consequence. Now that is where the game shines. Every person and organization within game contains a dossier where you can learn about them which can be to your advantage. A person might like aggressive and intimidating approach while another will try to remain professional or sneaky. In dialogues and actions if you reflect such things, then you get on their good sides. But you do not necessarily need to get on their good sides and sometimes antagonizing people could provide you different benefits on the long run. And let me tell you...you shall face several important decisions throughout the game, some doors will open for you some will close. The killer side is the amount of memorable characters and lore the game has. Considering this is an Obsidian game, expect really good writing and indepth lore regarding the gameworld/characters whether it is about an arms dealer or a hierarchical corporation which has too many fingers in every pie across the globe along several side factions which you can encounter as allies or enemies depending on your actions. *So You Want to Be a Hero?*Unlike other games where you hoard countless gold/money/coin where you will never use...Alpha Protocol provides you several tempting options to spend your ill-gotten or hard-earned money throughout missions. You want some intel on a certain person? Maybe an armor fit for stealth? Perhaps we can interest you in some incendiary grenades? You pay up on Clearinghouse which is the online blackmarket ingame where you can buy/sell several weapons, armor, gadgets, ammunition, weapon/armor mods, intelligence regarding missions and support. For example, if you buy a sniper dead drop at a certain mission it might make your job easier or you can hire a surveillance service to provide you detailed map of an area or maybe one of your allies can provide assistance at a mission for a fee. As you can see aside from material stuff in Clearinghouse you can spend your money on things which will alter your missions for better.Of course, there are some downsides to the game since we are in 2016 the graphics will seem a bit outdated but that is easier to get past. There are also minigames which are tolerable except hacking which can be extremely confusing at start but requires a bit getting used to abyssmal mouse control during it and good eyes to spot unchanging code segments. But it is recommended to avoid hacking most of the time if you are not patient and invested in technical abilities which makes the process easier and more palatable. Other minigames are fairly straightforward such as lockpicking and disabling alarms, you shall have no major issues with them. And one last issue could be the hard boss battles which requires tactical approach since they have no mercy. But as a recruit I never gave up, no matter Mike is blasted up with grenades, sub-machine gun'd to death or beaten by several sucker-punches from behind! But yeah boss fights can be hard if you are not properly equipped with some lethal means let it be martial, gunpower or gadgets.Now on my experience there are moments when the game truly shines. On one of the missions I was quite cornered and decided to give up on stealthy-nice guy approach and threw some incendiary grenades to kill 5-6 enemies which then granted me the perk "Plan B: Kill It With Fire" which literally cracked me up. On another note, if you go in stealth suit to meet certain people they make fun of you whether you will sneak out after the conversation or not. Which reminds me that the game provides perks based on your actions, choices and playstyle. Even watching news can be helpful at times you know. Also as a final note, Recruit background will have different cutscenes/dialogues/emails then Veteran which is unlocked by finishing the game on Recruit. So there is you NG+ if you are looking to try different things with a more experienced character. But as I initially said Recruit can be hard at start.*Conclusion*Alpha Protocol may have its shortcomings here and there, but if you can look past that you shall have great time with one-of-a-kind espionage RPGs. In my opinion this game is better then games such as Deus Ex: HR which while had excellent differing approaches to missions, they did not have emphasis on relation with other characters too much. In Alpha Protocol nothing is ever black and white. So if you are up for some espionage RPG, give Alpha Protocol a try.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Garbage mechanics... how this game got released with shooting so horrid and movement so clunky is beyond me.The timed dialog choices are the highlight of this game, but the actual decisions you make don't amount to anything. Choosing dialog options has never been more exciting but once you choose nothing comes out of it long term, a character might pop in later and say "I'll help you because you helped me" but you'll never find out what they actually do, or see anything of any significance come out of it. I saved one character at the beginning, so he popped up before the final mission to "help". But your character asks "I need you to broadcast something..." and the scene fades to black. You never find out what he actually does, what he broadcasts or why... The game's ending is not affected by your choices up to that point as far as I could tell, and the actual resolution of the game's conflict is left to 3 paragraphs of endgame text.I played through because I heard positive things about the dialog and story choices. Those may have been the best parts of the game, but they do not make up for the most horrible gameplay i've experienced in a game in years. Shooting in an RPG is hard to do correctly, but even the original Mass Effect did a better job with it. Borderlands, Fallout and the most recent 2 mass effect games have all found ways to pair RPG concepts with at least passable shooting. How Obsidian couldn't make something even remotely fun to play is beyond me. At least I got the game for like 5 bucks.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Before you read the review I would like to ask you to ignore my time spent in game - I played this half a dosen times when it was not on Steam and bought it just as a "thank you" to developers.I'll start with cons, if you are looking for a good Third Person Shooter, look elsewhere, action part of this game is relatively bad: it's impossible to fatally hit an enemy without aiming for 5 seconds first, a quarter of availiable weapons is not capable of killing at all, AI acts strange and shooting in most levels doesn't really fit with the atmosphere of the game.And that's all, nothing else about this game is bad. It's a fairly decent representative of stealth genre, not Splinter Cell and like level, but still, much better than action part. Overall, traditional TPS\Stealth part is present so that you weren't collapsing in awe before the second part of part of the game. Just invest in stealth to deal with mooks and in pistols to deal with bosses. Now, that second part. When the protagonist is not busy beating up some mooks, on scene comes the talking and reading part of the game. Alpha Protocol features about 20 organisations (titular Alpha Protocol, Al-Samad terrorist group, CIA, NSA, Chinese mafiosos, you got the idea) to interact with and nearly 30 characters. Everyone has his secrets, agendas, loyalities (well, your tech instructor doesn't since his "secret" is revealed in the first hour in the game without any effort from your side). And unlike many other games where you refer to some as "that guy, who is characterised by X", Alpha Protocol will make you remember everyone. You're guaranteed to pity Sis, respect Albatross and genuinly hate Marburg. Bonus points for not using cliches for the most time (Shaheed, Hong Shi and President Sung are notable exceptions) I've never seen such an image of a Russian mob leader (Konstantin Brayko, for those who decided to play) before.Another amazing thing about this game is complexity of it's plot. After I finished the game for the third time, trying to play differently each time, I decided to check some forums to read opinions\help with problems. I had a major WTF reaction when I saw people discussing event and possibilities and lore details I didn't even suspect to exist. For example, one of the bossfights ends with the boss running away to give you a second chance to beat him\convince him to join your side in the finale. However, If you collect all the pieces of his file, earn his hatred towards you and generally act like a smartass while talking to him, you can mock him, hitting all his weak points, reminding him of his past, which leads to him being so enraged with you that he forgets about his safety just to get a chance to kill you, thus allowing you to kill him. Another example, near the end of the game you have a talk with a pretty asian woman who you were building relationship with for the whole game (that's mostly optional). After talking with her for a couple of minutes you are presented with the following options: continue talking (comes in different flavours) or have sex with her. Guess, which one is more popular... However, if you continue to talk to her, she gives a lot of very interesting information which may affect the endgame if you will choose to use said information.In the end, I recommend this game to everyone, who is capable of finding joy in interesting story. Just don't let the boring beginning in Saudi Arabia to make you lose interest in this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Don't let the time played fool you-- I've played this game through a ridiculous number of times, and only recently bought the Steam version.Especially at the asking price this is an underrated little gem.  It has its rough edges and (sometimes endearing) glitches here and there, but it's adaptive in terms of both narrative and gameplay style in sometimes astonishing ways that many games claim but few actually deliver with satisfying variety.Do you want to be Batman, and stealthily tear through foes as the master martial artist with the gadgets and the tranq gun?  No problem.Do you want to be Bourne?  Lethally mow foes down in quick shock and awe close combat and pistol chaining?  You betcha.Do you want to just go full on console FPS style heavily armored marine killing machine?  No one will stop you. >:|The three conversation stances, similar to Bioware's conversation system, are meant to evoke the snark of Bond, the ire of Bauer, or the cool head of Bourne; or mix and match them as you please.  Fourth conversation options will also open up depending on what you already know about the person, what origin story you pick... or how well they (dis)like you. Not only that, the game's narrative shifts in often notable and surprising ways depending on what you do, in what order, with whom, and how-- two different plays as Agent Thorton can even yield the -player- a different view of the convoluted conspiracy behind the game's story.This deep, rich story is also one of its downsides-- due to the aforementioned lack of a final polish, some story threads are either vague or missing entirely, and while the otherwise diligent foreshadowing and character dossiers tend to let the player read between the lines rather clearly... the story can be hard to follow -without- going 'waaaaat' and looking deeper.Overall I love this game; I'll replay it again sometime soon, and then again, and then again probably after that.  This last play through, at -least- my eleventh or so, I discovered an entirely different way to kill one of the game's main antagonists.  There's good reason this one's a cult classic.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Altough a quite unfinished product as what it is, Alpha Protocol has much to offer in the form of the choices you will have to make during your career which in turn will have an effect on your future as an agent. Rather than just being the same old Mikey all the time, you can change your angle of approaching different people, by sometimes pis**** them off with the aggressive style often associated to Jack Bauer or you can just keep them doing favors for you because of the suave style of James Bond you chose to use. Maybe aggressive and suave styles will not always work and you want to keep yourself in the line of duty by being a professional like Jason Bourne. The thing is, you need to learn to adapt yourself to the ever changing environment.When it comes to the action, you can choose to upgrade your skills to match those of Rambo's or put all your efforts on sneaking, depending on which one is more to your liking as a gaming style. Knowing your enemy by simply collecting all the available intel on him/her, gives you a huge advantage if you two decide to pick up a fight. Of course, it's not once or twice you can avoid being beaten up by a giant boxer if you choose the correct phrases. Just be sure to create good relations with the people you meet, and you will find yourself being helped by different organisations if the price is right.Now, I beat Alpha Protocol twice on PS3 system soon after the game was released, and decided to buy it also for my laptop because of the glorious moments I had with it while playing it on PS3 years ago. To this date I have played this game through six times on my laptop, once with every background, and not until now can I say I know just about every twist this game has to offer.Do I need to say anything more? Alpha Protocol has offered me good gaming experiences and memories in the form of a modern espionage RPG. If you are a gamer who dares to look beneath the surface of this highly underrated piece of art, I have no doubt you find yourself being comfortable with it. Just don't forget to turn up the radio guys!

content:
Posted: February 20
												Overall, Alpha Protocol is a hidden gem and another game from Obsidian that hit the mark for me.  Basically, the plot is okay, the characters are alright, the combat is meh.  However, the reactivity and C&C (choice and consequence) is very noticeable, and may permeate more areas of the game than any other I have played.  This means that you have real impact on how the game plays out.  Occasionally, my Michael Thornton would end up saying something unexpected based on the limited dialog wheel and it would alter the game in a way I did not want, but I am willing to overlook that for what the game does well.  If you and a buddy of yours were to each play this game separately, it's likely that your experiences would be vastly different.  For that reason, it is a game that everyone should try at least once.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												A glorious flop, Alpha Protocol is a highly ambitious project with great ideas but weak gameplay. Sitting in the Deus Ex genre of rpg-stealth-action-espionage, it offers a customizable protagonist and a game world that reacts to your chosen style of play and personality to present a long, branching storyline where your choices really do matter. Friends might betray you, enemies might become allies, and the plot has plenty of ways it can wrap up. Stealth mechanics are passable and easily broken by overpowered skills, combat is fairly generic, but between plot and player choice and overall style, it creates a distinct sense of immersion and does a fine job really making you feel like a spy. Frustrating at times, but satisfying, it's worth a look if you enjoy a game you can play any way you want to.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												Alpha Protocol is best, and perhaps most favorably described as different. It is the standard cover based third person shooter stealth game mixed in with a dialog system and storytelling mechanics that would put any RPG to shame.The variety of choices and options in this game, and how they effect everything from the storyline to stat bonuses is truly inspired. It is one of the few games that can honestly claim that every game will play different and deliver on that promise.The gameplay is fairly generic however and it is marred by seemingly unending wave of bugs that can turn an otherwise entertaining game into a frustrating exercise in teeth-grinding within minutes.Despite it's obvious problems Alpha Protocol should be applauded for integrating choice and consequence into the gameplay in a way Bioware can only dream of. The mediocre gameplay and exorbitant amount of bugs however means this will never be the classic it was meant to be. Such a shame.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												This was an OK experience. I like to think of AP as a cross between Mass Effect & Batman Arkham...Maybe even Deus Ex!But...you can really pass this up.If you're REALLY considering reading this whole review, let me tell you whyAS A STEALTH GAMEFirst of all, gameplay is mostly stealthy. That is: Hiding, waiting for enemies to have their backs turned, then kill them without being detected. That is pretty cool. But the feel of the rest of the gameplay just didn't do it for me. Combat kind of blows. It's just not FLUID at all and the amount of control feels like I'm prodding a pregnant cow. For everything it can offer, I would rather be playing a Batman Arkham game when said and done. If you're looking for a Stealth game, do not buy this game, go buy Arkham Asylum. "But...COMBAT?!" Yes, you can customize your character to be more run-and-gun...but it just wasn't polished enough to really make it feasable alternative. Shooting with that silenced pistol was really cool though. Expect to take a long♥♥♥♥♥time trying to get unreasonably lucky on some hard bosses.AS AN ESPIONAGE GAMEThere is hacks, gadgets, electronic sautering, lockpicking... yes. They are nice little minigames to make you feel espionagey. But by the end of the game, you want to stick a lockpick up your♥♥♥♥♥if ONE more of these just gives you money (money is used to buy better gear...but you really don't NEED better gear). Nothing that is actually mission-changing at ALL. The integration of these into the actual missions were below expectation, but it was a good effort especially as sometimes it would give you some story.AS AN RPGThis is where Alpha Protocal helps to outshine it's not-as-good-as-Batman stealth gameplay. This I went IN not expecting to like the story, but it was actually pretty cool. The protagonist is way more likable than expected. Not the most AMAZING story, but still pretty OK!Like MASS EFFECT, you get to CHOOSE how you want conversations to go. You can indicate the mood throughout the conversation. Very cool. A LOT like Mass Effect, but with it's own little twist! Kind of felt like a cheaper version of it. You can Romance women you've kept close near the end, but don't expect anything dramatic...could be a horribly animated kiss, then a "Mission Completed". Not close to even Bioware romances. But, the transitions are kind of cheesy, almost immersion breaking to an already semi-bland story. The things/coroprations that are "mysterious" in the story, are uninteresting, and I really couldn't care less about learning about them.The story is run on semi-tracks. Kind of like Mass Effect...linear...but you get to choose your linearism to some degree. Emphasis on SOME degree. Little freedom, but what it is is very appreciated. Go to Saudi Arabia base. Then to Taiwan, Rome, Moscow (those 3 in any order). Then final mission. The safehouse feature was very cool, but honestly I couldn't help feeling like implementation of overall RPG elements was an EXTREMELY poor effort."What about the SKILLS?!" To put bluntly, choosing your class isn't really important. It's not really a necessary feature even (you choose whatever skills you want anyway)... the skills aren't very diverse and your choice in them don't really change your gameplay in an already linear game. If you choose anything but spy...you're going to have a ♥♥♥♥♥ier time because combat is not feasably enough implemented to go run-and-gunning. Don't expect Mass Effect skill options/progression...and DEFINITELY don't expect Skyrim status on this. Very basic, not worth getting worked up over.REPLAYABILITY??It's OK...but not really unless you have a strong desire to watch this a second time. Like Mass Effect, the story is pretty much the same, but with different outcomes in the middle if you choose a different dialogue option. But it's importance is severely lessened in Alpha Protocal. I have no interest to replay the story again for another 10 years. Like I said above, class/skill variety is way too lacking to expect replaying just for that as well. CONLCUSIONLook at other games like this closely before buying. There are a lot of similarities Alpha Protocal shares with other games, but is absolutely sub-par compared to them.♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'm always optimistic & thumbs up in reviews, but I just CAN'T be with this game. It's just OK. The story was pretty cool, but it is just another game touched by Obsidian. Alpha Protocal = don't worry about it

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you've ever wanted to be a secret agent like 007 or Jason Borne then Alpha Protocol might just be what you're looking for!The good:+The story feels like a fun mix between James Bond and the Borne Identity movies.+The dialogue and writing is snappy, funny and delivered fairly well by voice actors throughout.+The gameplay feels akin to Deus Ex in that you customize your own character and play as you please.+The levels encourage exploration as you can find hidden stashes of cash, dossiers or even upgrades.+The game is fairly short, but encourages multiple playthroughs with different approaches in both gameplay and story decisions.The bad:-Animations tend to be stiff and robotic.-The camera zooms in too close and can be clunky to work with.-The combat is poorly executed and you should at least max one weapon skill to keep up.-Plays awful with a mouse and keybord, get a controller and enable it in the options menu in-game.-Bugs, bugs, bugs! It just wouldn't be an Obsidian game without them.-The final mission feels rushed and is more bugged than the rest of the game.Bottom Line:Alpha Protocol is a rough gem that will leave you frustrated at times, but satisfied by the end. If you're unsure I would suggest you pick the game up during a sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2012
												So underrated. Yes, the combat kind of sucks (it's servicable, but is entirely consolized and a bit wonky at times), but the real reason to play this game is the dialogue system. It's rare enough for video games to get something as mundane as people talking right so when it does happen it's a bit of a revelation. Dialogue options not only give you bonuses and pay off in real ways that affect the plot, but they are also timed--so rather than allowing you to sit and mull over what your character should say you need to make snap judgements and live with the consequences of your decisions. The result is that talking to people becomes a form of combat all its own--something which is, admittedly, much more exciting than the more literal forms of combat the game throws at you, but which is revolutionary enough on its own to make the game worth playing. Plus the plot/dialogue are well written enough to mostly rise above their hodge-podge of spy tropes and cliches. An overlooked (if rough) gem.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I originally purchased Alpha Protocol for PS3 when it came out a few years back.  After playing about midway through it I found it to be pretty boring and dropped it.  During the recent Steam sale I picked it up for PC and finished it today.  The story is very engaging and you meet a number of very interesting characters throughout the story.  The graphics are dated and the cover, shooting, and stealth are a little iffy at times.  However I have to say the game was very fun to play and had an original story with RPG elements unlike anything else I've played.  The dialogue choices alone make you want to replay certain sections to determine which responses may have alternate paths to take.  Again this one is primed for a replay and recommended to anyone that is willing to look past some of the unpolished parts and enjoy the game for what it is.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												Alpha Protocol is a 3rd person RPG game made by Obsidian Entertainment. You play as Michael Thorton, an agent with a top secret branch of the CIA.I can not speak highly enough about this game. Yes it does have some issues which I will get to in a bit but overal this game is amazing and very much worth your time if you are interested in the RPG genre. Lets start off with the pro's for this game.Gameplay: You have 3 options for how to play the game right out of the gate. You can play as either a complete stealth style never being noticed by anyone. A middle of the road style where you use stealth to take out your enemys. Also an FPS style in which you go in guns blazing with no regard for stealth at all. This alone opens up many hours of replayability and is something I personally have not seen very often.Customization: Just about everything about your character, except general looks, can be customized. Your weapons, what gear you take with you, and your armor or lack there of are all fully customizable giving you a plethora of options for each misson you go on.Dialogue: The dialogue system is top notch giving you multiple options for how you want to respond, some of which are very entertaining. This also leads into a reputation and romance system that is very well developed for characters that actually make you care about them on some level.Impact: This is probably the most important part, at least for me. The decisions you make in game, who you talk to, how you handle each situation, all matter a great deal in this game. Your choices have consequences and you have to carefully consider what you want to say, how to say it, and what to do at any given moment.Now  lets touch on the negatives for this game, and yes, sadly there are a few.AI: The enemies in Alpha Protocol are not the best out there. The can be rather predictable at times and glitch out. That being said it is not game breaking in any way and personally it didn't bother me all that much.Combat: Alpha Protocol is first and foremost a console game. It was ported over to the PC and as such has a combat system that at times can feel clunky and drive you nuts. Once you get used to it though you can get through the game just fine.Hacking: There really is no other way to say it, the hacking minigame in Alpha Protocol is absolutly terrible. It really could have used an overhaul but it sadly never came.Bugs: There are a few other bugs in the game some of which can be quite annoying but I personally never experienced anything to dramatic or game  breaking.Graphics: This was a console game that is pretty old at this point and was ported over to the PC. The graphics are not top tier yet at the same time I have seen a LOT worse out there.TLDR: Alpha Protocol  is a great game very much worth the asking price and even more so if you can get it on sale. 7/10
