content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												i'd love to say that i absolutely without any doubt recommend this game, but i'm honestly a bit more lukewarm on it than i wanted to be. i'll say it right here, if you want a stealth action game with rpg elements, this game is not going to cut it at all. the stealth is super janky, the hacking and lockpicking minigames are fidgety and progress to being almost unplayable by the end, and the shooting is awful with pistols just becoming an instant win button as you specialize in them and martial arts being fun, but super janky and kind of useless in later portions.it kind of lacks the polish in its core gameplay to make you feel like an incredibly stylish and smooth secret agent, you just end up feeling like a crazy maniac dashing around punching people and chainshotting entire rooms and then the camera bugs out and you're running in the opposite direction. which is fun in its own way, but the game gets frustrating like that.the important thing, though, is the character interaction. i like the writing in a lot of obsidian's games, and while i can't say the plot in this particular game really astounded me, it was a great vehicle for character interaction, which is the real highlight. the way you talk to people, the way people think of you, they're all recorded in-game and while a lot of games just have it as window dressing, it's actually really in-depth here. every mission presents you with choices to make, and every choice has a big effect on other missions and the way people view you. and ultimately, it all really does add up in a lot of key interactions.so when it comes to all that, i consider that part of the game strong enough to at least be worth taking a look at. i wouldn't say this is a game you should pick up for full price, but it goes on sale often, and if you're interested in that aspect of the game, it's definitely worth a look for sale price. all that, and stephen heck, who i can assure you if you are a good and just person will become your best friend.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2013
												Pros: - The game has a great story, interesting characters that will react to you and your actions (helli liked every character)- The perk system is awesome, giving you a ton of different options to choose from ( from stealth to firearms to hacking)- The game is highly replayable- I loved collecting dossiers on different people and factions in the game, provides an extrainsight into the story- Game ain't to hard unless you want it to be (tip: don't start on the hardest difficulty)- It takes around 20-25 hours to finish the game depending on how you play it- The dialogue system works in a way that you have 3 stances: Suave (James Bond), proffesional (Jason Bourne) and agressive (Jason Statham) giving you the choice to make Mike the character you want him to beCons:- First level is boring but it gets much better after it- The gunplay makes me cringe everytime, it's unpredictable and the only way to hit someone is to wait for your croshair to "charge up" while out of cover, it gets better if you upgrade your perks- Even with my good pc the game stutters here and there, luckily you can fix it by messing with the ini ( backup your files first)- Graphically it can put some people off- There are some areas where you have to play the way you don't want to ( Fist fighting with your stealth only character) but thankfully that's just 2-3 areasNeutral:- The hacking minigames are nothing special, same for lockpicking- The cover system works as intended but it ain't anything specialBuy the game, play it one way then replay it with different choices.I found this to be one of Obsidians best games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Alpha Protocol  is a prime example of early games made by Obsidian. Great concept attached to unfinished, buggy game. You play as Michael Thorton, special agent on his quest to stop global terrorism... or whatever. Story isn't that important in this case. What's really interesting is choices and consequences mechanic. During the game you will have to make a lot of decisions and most of them actually matters. Depending on what you say through a conversations, how you approach missions etc. you will get different outcome. The consequences vary from something as simple as skill boost to more complicated things like loosing or gaining allies. Furthermore you can choose in which order you play the missions and it has impact on the story too. I'm not saying that it will change it diametrically but certain things will differ. Generally Alpha Protocol can be divided into two parts. The first is built around choices, the dialogue system, character customisation and leveling up. Also in this part you will be preparing before missions which includes more dialogues and briefings. It's all great. But there is the second part. Missions itself. And they are bad. Theoretically you can be sneaky or go full Rambo but more often than not you will end up killing every enemy on a level anyway. Just because simple “miscontrol” (and controling Thorton is real pain sometimes) or because you've “misclicked” during mini game and activated an alarm. You can of course restart and try again, but everyone has their limits and sooner or later you'll have to answer the question: how many restarts is too many, and then go full Rambo. It wouldn't be that bad if combat was properly executed, but it's not. Shooting is boring, blank experience. There are martial arts too, but to fully enjoy them you would have to be stealthy and as I said it's not that simple.Despite it's flaws Alpha Protocol is solid, good looking game with great concept behind it. Definitely worth to give it a shot. But it's your choice to make.Disclaimer: I'm living in third world country so my english is poor. Sorry :(

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is one of those games that sneaks under the radar for most people but is actually a pretty decent game. It plays and feels like Mass Effect but with a spy setting. You play agent Mike Thorton who is recruited to a secret spy agency called Alpha Protocol and you find youself embroiled in a plot to kick off a new cold war which you need to stop. The strenghs of this game are in it's RPG elements. You can conversate with other characters via a dialogue sytem similar to Mass Effect and Dragons Age 2. Depending on what you say to a character can influence their opinion of you, which in turn can affect what they're willing to tell you. Get friendly enough with a character and they might help you later on in the game via intel or providing support on missions. The choices you make also have an impact later on in the game, for example going all gung-ho ona mission lead to more enemies in the next mission as security is increased.The combat sections of the game is what lets it down. You can use various weapons which can be upgraded in your mission,as well as abilites you unlock as the game progresses. The combat does get repetetive after a while though an interesting mechanic is the ability to acquire intel before a mission which gives you advantages like reducing enemy numbers or a sniper rifle drop.Another interesting feature is the intel you can collect on factions and individual characters. Instead of being useless filler information, this intel can be useful in giving you hints in how to get a character to like you in a conversation or the tactics they use in a fight should you need to fight them.The Good:- interaction with other characters is this games main strength as well as the many ways and options you have in dealing with other characters and in missions.-levelling system is pretty good with each point gained in a skill conferring you a bonus of some sort.-Weapons and body armor customization is pretty good and varied-the intel feature is pretty good and is actually of use instead of being just fillerThe Bad:- combat isn't great and gets repetitive-game is pretty buggy at times.(i found my character was getting stuck in the ground every now and again)Overall this game is pretty good if a bit flawed. Worth picking up if you enjoy action-rpgs like Mass Effect and Dragons Age. 7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
A Flawed MasterpieceFrom the get-go: the gameplay is TERRIBLE. It's simply awful; animations are terrible, enemy AI is either ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or omniscient, the mini-games scale poorly to the point of being nearly completely broken; fortunately once you learn how to exploit it it is incredibly easy.The gameplay however is the flawed part.The plot, however, is simply amazing. I'm not referring simply to the story. It's how it plays out that is simply amazing. When most games claim that actions have consequences they usually mean that you merely get to choose some buttons at the end and a pat on the back because you killed few or no people.With Alpha Protocol this is not the case. Everything you do changes everything around you. Every single gameplay can be different merely because of how you chose to react to certain people. And the NPCs react to who you are to the point of some being able to figure you out because of your past actions and reputation.This even reflects itself in the gameplay where there are perks related to your play style but also how you roleplay. Basically it's possible to be (somewhat) uniquely rewarded for all possible play styles. Are you a pacifist? Kill everyone? Mix and match? Are you nice to people? Irreverent? Random? You'll be rewarded.That's why it's a masterpiece. Play it twice and you'll start to see it. From then on you'll start seeing how every little detail is a part of something bigger and a single playthrough is not enough to experience the entire plot or even the full extent of possibilities within the game itself.This of couse only applies to people who actually like games with a plot. If you're the run & gun type to whom games are merely "violence porn" and you zone out if someone doesn't get shabbed every 45 seconds then don't even buy this since it'll just be fodder for you to "write" a terrible review.I blame SEGA for rushing this.

content:
Posted: April 25
												I downloaded this on sale years ago, and tried many, many times to start a campaign. This time around I finally got beyond the training and played through the game. It's not the worst game I've ever played, but it's not good either. In this very short campaign, you'll encounter glitched enemies who appear randomly in sight, visuals cutting out, loading textures, and very poor weapon accuracy (which is based on how patient you are).The story itself is quite good, and my desire to see how everything worked out was my main motivation in finishing the game. I really enjoyed the conversation system, which legitimately has a serious impact on how the story of the game unfolds. The replayability is solely in these conversations, as one can try out different paths to see the story unfold in a different way. Unfortunetely, the game itself is not very good so replaying it solely for the story doesn't interest me at all.This game is only for hardcore RPG fans who have the patience to overlook the game's obvious flaws. If you are a completionlist who would like to play through all of Obsidian's games, then by all means get this. There is a good game somewhere in here, but just not good enough to recommend to anyone other than the previously mentioned.

												I was impressed by the depth of story and dialogue choices in this game, and how the approach you take with people will have an impact on their impressions of you, and also that there are different effects based on what you choose. It's also one of the few games I've seen where having a low reputation with some people can actually work in your favor, if you prefer not to cater to everyone. The combat is fun and as for the character you have a lot of different skills to develop how you like; you can focus more on stealth or go hand to hand, or choose from pistols, SMGs, shotguns, or assault rifles. There are diffferent types of each weapon class with different stats and the same goes for armor; plus, all of the above can be customized with a variety of parts you can buy to improve the weapon or armor abilities further. If you played and liked Mass Effect and/or Deus Ex, you would probably enjoy this too.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Alpha Protocol, more accurately the critical response thereto, is a monument to games journalisms’ need for art-house institutions willing to judge games on non-commercial, non-standard merits. Considering Alpha Protocol as one considers most AAA-titles reveals a failed experiment: a reactive plot with inconsistent characters, gunplay that doesn’t quite land, unbalanced skill-trees that result in a clear hierarchy of character builds, and a floundering finale. These properties are, in some ways, Obsidian’s hallmark: since KOTOR2 and NWN2 the studio (my personal favourite working studio) has been plagued with releasing inconsistent products. In some ways, Alpha Protocol is the worst offender: there are some marring bugs that were never fixed which can lead to very flawed plays. Despite the above mentioned issues—even the slightly bland story and inconsistent characters—I’ve played through Alpha Protocol three times and enjoyed each pass. Obsidian remind me of a quote from Tony Kushner (American dramatist most famous for Angels in America): Kushner distinguishes between two types of artists, “the ones who ask small questions but give great answers and the ones who ask huge questions and often, as a consequence of the ambitiousness of their questioning, fail to give good answers”. Kushner holds that both are necessary, and I agree with him; Obsidian and their works should be treated as the second category. They ask huge questions about RPG design, and though they fail, the questions themselves are both a merit and a necessity. Alpha Protocol questions the very foundations of RPGs: it is not science fiction or fantasy, it has a branching plot in which the player is almost fifth business instead of universal saviour, and there is no party. Spies, turncoats, flashbacks take you on a global adventure that feels, ultimately, small: this isn’t fate of the galaxy (KOTOR) or fate of the Great Wheel (NWN2) stuff. We have a relatively localized plot that, while slightly bland and riddled with some forgettable characters, unfolds organically and persuasively. Everything feels like it happens for a reason, and you never question your character’s role in it; the game is quite good at being reactive (or at least appearing so, and illusion is everything) and that’s the whole goal. And on the merit of its questions, I think Alpha Protocol is an important game. It asks: does an RPG need a party? (no); can it deal with slightly smaller stakes? (yes); can it play like an action game instead of an excel simulator? (yes), etc. I would never absolve Alpha Protocol of its bugs or failures—one particular bug causes all enemies on a map to disappear, which can make some areas of the game unforgivably bland, until you figure out that it’s a bug you can correct by shutting down and reloading, which is still unacceptable—but regardless I recommend the game as a glimpse of what RPGs could be like. And, honestly, the bugs aren’t that bad; if you’ve made your way through STALKER, you’ve played far worse on that front.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Personal rating: 8/10Replayability: MediumBudget: It's not an expensive game, it's an older title by now. It's worth the money. Lenght: A couple of full days worth of playing should get you through. This game has a lot of excellence. While occasionally, it seems a bit like a parody on spy-series and spy movies alike, it does a really great job of portraying the setting of being some sort of secret agent. Gameplay wise, it doesn't quite live up to modern standards. Don't ge me wrong, it's more than playable. Heck, it's even enjoyable, but certain things in the game could defiantely have been done better. Prettier. Aiming for instance, and the clunky animation from the sneaking motion. Some of the equipment in the game looks outright stupid, but apart from that, most of it is pretty cool and resembles real-life tactical equipment. The game features a lot of roleplaying elements in- and outside of missions. Over-all, I'd say Alpha Protocol is the best "agent" game out there, the reason I'm punishing it's rating is because it's not that old, and yet in a few ways it looks much older than it is. Dialogue is great, missions are good and it even incorporates quite a bit of humor.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												After playing other games since finishing Alpha Protocol, I keep wishing those that boast a great conversation and choice system would look towards this game as a way to do it well. Possibly the best thing about the game that at best is a flawed gem, there's no doubt that it is a gem, so long as you're willing to look past just how flawed it is.Make no mistake, the whole game feels clunky, almost as if it was designed after all its characters, plot and the flow-chart-requiring choice system was implemented. It features that bizarre aspect of playing better the further in you get as you put points into your RPG'd character. That said, it does feel like catering to every aspect of a spy-in-fiction available, from sauvé Bond-esque conversationalist, cool-gadget user and pistol-preferring gentleman, to the Bourne "beat the crap outta them!" specialist in martial arts. It's just a shame that while you're developing these, or even your own character idea, that you must suffer the wonky gameplay in the mean time; shooting, some stealth sections and particularly the boss fights are all rough around the edges, but work just enough to be passable.Again, the emphasis is on everything else. There are some fantastic characters that are incredibly well developed and will no doubt linger with you for some time after playing. Dialogue and the story are clever and whilst the over-arching plot might be a bit been-there-done-that, it never takes center-stage and thus never feels like it's letting the side down. The reason you should want to play the game is for every conversation you have which is directed by the need to read into non-playable-characters, both from the dialogue you're having with them that second and in collected information along the way, so that by the end you can try and manipulate the situation to your want.It's a slog to suffer through, but come the conclusion I felt incredibly satisfied that it was all worth it for an experience I've not enjoyed in any other game. My advice would to be turn up the radio and push on through.*Played with a 360 controller as keyboard and mouse controls felt sub-par.

												Another half-baked game from Obsidian.The dialogue system is good. The story is more or less intriguing. But the rest is complete crap.Movement is clunky. Camera is bad. Shooting is horrible. And melee is even worse. Character development system is too primitive. Locations are too linear and provide almost no variety in walkthrough. Enemies are super dumb, but have a great aim and spot you immediately (played on hard). And if you thought you could bear all that because it's a stealth game - no, you can't. There are moments when the game throws enemies at you and the only way to deal with them is a direct confrontation.If you want a spy game, play Splinter Cell or No One Lives Forever. If you want an RPG/shooter, play Mass Effect. If you want cyberpank stealth/shooter, play Deus Ex. Alpha Protocol tries to be everything at once and fails miserably.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Alpha Protocl is a truly stellar Western Role-playing game. Developed by Obsidian, the guys behind Fallout New Vegas, this role-playing game puts you in the role of Mike, a spy for Alpha Protocol. Mass Effect and Dragon Age are lauded for their ability to have branching storylines, and many feel that those games don't deliver too well. Alpha Protocol is the answer to those people's complaints, as the perfect synegy between storyline and gameplay. Storyline truly branches around what the player says, and whole missions change and even become available based on your decisions. The character is given three different conversational tracks to choose from, which are based on personalities similar to Jason Bourne, Jack Bauer, and James Bond. Combat is RPG-based, and the skills you take really modify what your character can and can't do. No other recent game truly puts agency of the player, and allows him to so fully shape the game.With all of that said, Alpha Protocol IS pretty buggy. Not game-breakingly so, but still to the degree that it could put some people off the purchase of this game.Get this game if you loved Fallout New Vegas, or you felt that Mass Effect or Dragon Age left you wanting. Or if you want to be a kickass spy. Because, who doesnt?

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I love this game. Don't let any of those trolls get you down on the negative aspects because if you are a fan of any spy in the history of literature then you will love this. This made me watch Bond, Mission Impossible, 24 and Taken again just for reference. The first playthrough I wanted to get a feel for it so I went with the Mission Impossible route, some jokes, some professionalism, making friends with poeple you come accross for info. Then I played full bond, just a pistol, no armor, stealth, suave and of course if you are a Roger Moore fan, the corny and suggestive jokes. Then I played as Jack Bauer, agressive, confrontational, but knows when to kill and not to kill. Then I played full on Taken and opened up a can of Liam Neeson on my enemies which turned it into less of a spy movie and more into a Rambo like movie where anyone who got in my way or was a potential threat....they were dealt with. So if you are a big fan of either one here is the playstyle to follow.Ethan Hunt: Mixuture of everything including armor and weapons, little to no suave but plenty of jokes and yet maintain seriousness and mostly stealth 007: You can be as aggressive as Brosnan and Craig or as snarky and funny as Moore, to the cockyness of Connery and if you feel the need to throw in some Dalton gun play go for it. However everyone besides Dalton does not wear any kind of armor so be warned. Jack Bauer: Again little to no armor but damn aggressive and up front, you basically carves through anyone he wishes yet spares those he has has to. This would be the hard gameplay.Liam Neeson: This would be the INSANE game style, no armor, just a pistol, wits and of course you eliminate EVERYONE and I mean EVERYONE. Which makes everyone mad but hey its Neeson we are talking about here.Then you have others:The strong quiet types like Steven Seagal to Rambo and the Commando Arnold (which is a specialization option) So which ever spy you want to emulate go for it. I prefer Bond and word to the wise, download a track or two from the movies, really sets the RPG mood.

Mike: I'm a spy.Scarlet: (laugh) Did this line ever worked?Mike: I don't know, are you impressed?Scarlet: No.Mike: Then never.― Mission: Picking Up. Status: Failed ;)Obsidian Entertainment. Interplay Entertainment. Black Isle Studios. Different varieties and the same common, great story - the best RPG's ever. And probably the last title, which I have not played - Alpha Protocol.After 23h (two full runs):PROS+ three JB styles - Bond, Bourne, Bauer + Agent History styles & Advance for 2nd run...+ ...resulting different game's style during a mission+ full customization - weapons, gears, armors, beards and mustaches ;)+ dialogue system+ locations and their structure+ very nice NPC's+ reputation and romances (in 007 style [or Buck from KillBill ;P] My name's Mike, and I'm here to give you my pike.)+ nice character development+ last, but MOST important - REAL choices and consequences in a REAL non-linear storylineCONS- enemies AI- flawed combat system- and terrifying MASS of smaller and larger bugs sometimes completely ruining all the pros...- EDIT: somehow I forgot about the terrible, massacred-my-eyes, inhumanely against human rights... hacking.Subjective rate: A+ for non-linear choices and consequences, and for that you really feel like a secret agent/spy/mercenary in international intrigueB- or C+ for story AND technical sideD or F only for technical sideF+atality for hacking styleReally, I have no clue why released to market as terribly technically underdeveloped game like this. And what the strangest thing - despite all the bugs... story is complete and consistent. Whatever you do, whatever you choose - there are no gaps as in the case of (for example another Obsidian) Fallout: New Vegas.Strange. This game is no longer count on any patches, but surely it deserves a sequel, with the same dose of juicy RPG AND with normal engine, without the dramatic novice programmer's mistakes.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I feel like writting reviews today so i need to post one about this game wich is one of my favorites. Don't look my Steam play time i already completed the game twice elsewhere.So the game is just GREAT if what you are looking for is IMMERSION despite some flaws. If you can enjoy Gothic 1/2 despite the graphics and clumsy combat/movement and get yourself immersed into it after just a few hours then i'm pretty sure you will enjoy this game. If not, you might want to find your happiness elsewhere.The game is all about choices and consequences. There is no good or bad, it's all about how you see ethic, you are the spy and you investigate the whole game depending on your own morality. But everything have repercussion, how you interrogate someone, how you work, what you undertake, who you trust... and this is what makes the game feels so good, so right, so IMMERSIVE. This is why you forget rpg intended mechanics where you need to level your skill to be able to land a shot properly or be totally invisible making the game a cakewalk. In fact i kinda liked this aspect of the game too and never understood people ranting about it. What annoyed me the most the first time i played Alpha Protocol were the boss battles. It felt so "out of place", so "unrealistic", even gamebreaking when playing only with stealth and no good weapons, but then i found a way to finish and i couldn't wait to see what else the game has to offer. That's why i like it so much and would recommend you to buy it.

												What do I say about this game? It's not particularly well done, but the writing is excellent. It's a second-rate console port, but it's suprisingly talky and interesting at times. There's a fair share of unpatched bugs, and might run like♥♥♥♥♥on your system, but if it works, it's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ immersive and fun to play. The weapons handle like♥♥♥♥♥and you're going to hate the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them at first, but that merely is a thing that's done to demonstrate just how awesomely broken the stealth system is in your favor. To summarize, this is basically an unrefined project that got booted out the door, yet another hallmark of Obsidian's approach to making games, but most of it is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome and you might not even notice the bugs. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I thoroughly recommend this game.Despite all its flaws, glitches and errors (of which there are a few) this game is tremendous fun. The RPG side is not well fleshed out but it still has a nice sense of fulfilment to it. The discussion tree is vast with so many choices to go through, I suspect this game can be different every time through up to 4 maybe 5 playthrough’s (if you can stick it out that long).The characters and story are great and very well fleshed out. I loved finding out things about everyone I met and the world in general around the action seemed deep and rich as well. As for the combat it was alright, for an RPG it was fantastic, for an action game it was average at best. The Ai is either amazing or so stupid it ignores being shot. I found little use for the gadgets but I loved using some of the skills. As for progression when you gain enough XP you level up and in doing so can add to a number of espionage/weapon skills. You will probably want to specialise in one weapon, doing more than that means you can fill out the full skill tree. Side note: pistol is OP.If this game is on sale you should pick it up, not recommended at full price unless you love the concept, too many glitches to really justify though.Have fun ^_^

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I played this game on the 360 shortly after it was release and I LOVED it.  Branching storylines based on real time conversations and quick choices with consequenses made/make this game unique and enjoyable.  There are some fairly glaring issues.  The enemy AI is pretty awful...like yeah pretty darn awful.  Some of the animations are weird and screwy...Mike sneaking for example.  There were numerous bugs (in the 360 version at least...I haven't played the PC port much yet) but the storyline, relationships, dialogue and interactive nature of the game make up for its, admittedly, numerous shortcomings.  It makes you feel like you're a real part of the story, not just watching cutscenes.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												This game is worth it, but it will disappoint you, and possibly frustrate you.As many have said, the dialogue system and character interaction are very well done. The perk system is cool, and the skills system is decent. And the story (just done first few missions) is spy-ish.I liked the buy the intel, the dossiers, and the reading it entails (makes it feel more grounded in espionage than just first person shooting). The graphics are good (including the character details when talking, etc). I liked the mini-games (which simulate hacking, lockpicking and eletronic lock bypassing) which are based on observation puzzles against a clock.You will be disappointed by the animations which are a bit stiff but not bad. The controls (because of a possible poor console port) seem a tiny bit sluggish. You will become a little bit annoyed at the hacking mini-game because of the wildly poor mouse response to it.And finally, you might become ANGERED by the too frequent (for me at least) crash glitch which occurs against walls and corners, especially when stealthing which you will want to do a lot because, y'know you are a spy. So when your character jams permanently into an invisible wall-terrain join, just seconds before the checkpoint for the nth time, you will WANT to SMASH your pc screen. DON'T. Just turn off the game. and come back to it later. You will enjoy it again after a break....and hopefully the bug won't hit you so maliciously the next time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Seriously underrated game.  This is an RPG game, not a purely action game, so you need to level up and work on advancing your skills and customizing your character.  If you expect traditional action gameplay, you'll be disappointed.  But as an RPG, it's a lot of fun, and the espionage settting is a fun change of pace from the usual sword-and-board Tolkien cut-and-pasted drivel that most game makers seem to think we want in our role playing games.  The game is very ambitious, though you do have to be tolerant of some of relatively rough production values.  OK, very rough production values.  I guess that's why most people hate the game.  But if you are the kind of player who wants a game where your decisions really do impact the gameplay, the story, and the future missions, this is a great game because it delivers in that department.  Mass Effect has more polish, and better gameplay, but really, at the end of the day, all your decisions do is change a few seconds worth of cut scene at the end.   The Telltale Walking Dead games love to tease you with the choice between saving one character or another.  But then, no matter who you save, they end up dying a few minutes later.  Your decisions simply don't matter in most games.  But in Alpha Protocol, the story can change dramatically from one playthrough to the next in a way that most games still can't compete with.And, sadly, it's still one of the only non-sci-fi, non-fantasy RPGs out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Alpha Protocol is one of the few games I wish I'd never played, because I'd still be able to experience it for the first time.Everything you do in this game has consequences, from conversations with the other characters to how you carry out your missions. There are whole missions you can miss out on depending on how much intel you gather, and characters that you may never meet face to face. The story is non-linear, with different outcomes and events depending on which order you complete the main hubs in.If, like me, you're a sucker for story in games and are willing to put up with slightly clunky gameplay, give this one a try. The story, settings and characters are all fantastic, and the audio design is among the best of any game I've played. Overall, it definitely places in my top five favorite games of all time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2011
												Alpha Protocol is hands down one of the best spy and espionage games on the PC. It kind of makes you feel like Jason Bourne. The interactive story provides satisfaction in knowing you are actually a part of the outcome and all of your actions have consequences. In addition, the timed responses mean that all conversations remain fluid and believable. The perk system provides persona customization primarily between stealth or run and gun. There is a money collection system for buying weapons, armor, and accessories through the black market to enhance your chosen perks. The aiming system was biggest weakness, the enemy AI could have been improved, and the bosses seemed overpowered, but overall there was really very few issues with the gameplay, and the execution is top notch. The game also offers a lot of replayability due to its diverse story paths. This is a must buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2013
												An interesting take on an espionage game, Alpha Protocol manages to keep you on your toes for most of its story, with a plot straight out of a Bourne movie. The game has some pacing problems but it gives you an impressive amount of freedom and still wraps things up satisfyingly. The characters are refreshing and the innovative conversation mechanics (limited time to choose your answer) force you to actually think about your replies. Sadly, the gameplay is very aracade-styled, with the shooting elements completely broken in your favor when using a mouse and a keyboard. Still, it deserves to be played as one of the few true espionage RPGs.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2011
												Fantastic action/rpg that was plagued with poor press on release. It's basically like a modern day james bond, with all the womanising and over-the-top action one would expect. The shooting mechanics feel a little 'light', similar to mass effect's gunplay, but not as bad.The game can be played any way you like, lethal or non-lethal, run and gun or stealthy, but have little bearing on the overall outcome. If you're looking for a hardcore stealth/espionage game like metal gear solid or splinter cell, it doesn't really deliver.Intriguing storry, great voice acting (featuring Jim Cummings aka Minsc) and just a satisfying singleplayer experience overall.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2011
												A truly underrated title. It has a really great conversation system, interesting characters, and excellent leveling up and customization, allowing you to go through the game with different builds.It is not, however, without its flaws. The gameplay controls are not very responsive. For a game looks and feels like it should be a third person shooter, the actual shooting mechanic is very poor. The stealth mechanics are better than the shooting, but Splinter Cell this is not. And it a few mandatory boss fights, which are of course terrible in this style of game. In fact, the game is very similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. They certainly both occupy the same genre of Steath/Action/RPG. The biggest difference is that DXHR has better gameplay, but far worse plot and character. Alpha Protocol has much better characters, plot, and dialogue/choices, but the gameplay is less polished. That said, if you enjoy games with well written characters, interesting choices, and one of the best conversation systems ever in any RPG, then you'll enjoy Alpha Protocol.

The first few hours of the game suck becuase your character is a scrub, the recoil on every weapon is beyond unrealistic, the levels are linear as hell, and you  don't know any good skills. pro tip: level up your stealth and pistol as soon as you can.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												i3-4150, EVGA 750ti Superclocked.Resolution: 1920x1080Graphics settings: Ultra SettingsAverage framerate: 60 fps with vsync. Never a potate framedrop.Input device used for game: Played with gamepad, though switched to Mouse and Keyboard. Both systems are equally as great in this game.I was gifted this game and was definitely not expecting anything of this epic magnitude. It was pleasantly surprising considering I'd never even heard of the game before. As far as the controls go, this game is solid: there's a large inventory, weapons customization, and skill-tree system that is easy to learn and navigate. I'll admit that when I was greeted with a huge Sega logo and wopwopwop do do do woooop electronica I was thinking "Oh man, dat hilarious dubstep♥♥♥♥♥♥.Oh noes.", but as soon as I entered into the game I was astounded by the quality of the voice acting, and pretty decent graphics considering that this is a previous-gen console port. I'm going to keep this review very short: If you're into secret societies, black-ops, PMCs, and shady underworld conspiracy theories, this game is for you. This game has single-handedly opened doors for me into the spy/espionage genre and since then I've played Spec Ops The Line and Deus Ex:HR. I'm going to be trying MGS games as well. This game is chock-full of ethical decisions and is begging for another playthrough as from what I've read, there are hours upon hours of different paths and cinematics. Do you want to be a guns blazing, bomb planting execute-every-character in-the-game-type to see where that leads you? Do you want to be a Melee-only character and a silent assassin? Do you want to be the suave, filthy,flirty, and cocky Archer-like spy who pisses off all of his mission handlers? Do you want to have a gun fight with a Russian in an arcade/discotheque to a blaring 80's hair metal soundtrack? You can do all of this.This is an underrated game you've never heard of with a rich story-line that you should definitely pick up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												It was a very nice surprise. It is not a perfect game though. Boring and hard-to-figure-out in the beggining, but nicely developed thoughout the story. The game is divided into chapter, which one comprises of a series of missions to investigate an international security issue. Well done. The safehouse concept was very well implemented in which you can buy/sell weapons, gadgets, and key intel to unlock additional side missions (investigations) related to chapter's story mission. After completing the first chapter, you can choose from 5 professional styles which of them with unique abilities and gadgets. I can relate spy, soldier, engineer, etc.  I chose spy...it is a stealth game, guys. But fell free to choose a different one to go assaulting everywhere. Also, there are a wide variety of weapons to fit with your choosen professional style. That would allow game replayability. As you progress you gather experience points that will lead to characther's level up and upgrade points to allow you improving certain abilities at your choice.Level design are very nice. Again, this game have its isues, but it gathers the best elements of stealth action games: Hitman, Splinter Cell, Batman, Deus EX, you can recall other games in every element of this game as you play it. It is not purely linear, because by using the safehouses, you can return to certain areas to collect items, hacking computers, find money caches, collect ammo, etc. THAT IS GREAT.As a RPG, dialog system is a bit different from other similar games. Here, you may choose your reply tone rather than the response phrase itself. Options varies from sarcastic, professional, ironic, flirtatious...Oh yes, there are romance options you can decide about. You also can reply to emails to disclose sensitive information, flirt, threat and compliment someone else in your mailing list. Here your decisions matter and will affect the game ending. Weapon wheel are difficult to browse at the beggning but I got used to. There are lethal and non lethal takedowns that are cool.  It resembles the Krav Maga martial art. Mini games are not that cool, some of them are tough, but you can buy certain upgrades to help you out. There are abilities you can upgrade with its cooldown time that can be reduced with level up points.The weakiest part were the Boss battles that should be much better. Without spoilling, there are certain upgrades and gadgets that will make your life way too easy fighting bosses. But overall, it is enjoayble and worth playing.  It is worth playing with moderate expectations. RECOMMENDED.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2011
												A truly underrated title. It has a really great conversation system, interesting characters, and excellent leveling up and customization, allowing you to go through the game with different builds.It is not, however, without its flaws. The gameplay controls are not very responsive. For a game looks and feels like it should be a third person shooter, the actual shooting mechanic is very poor. The stealth mechanics are better than the shooting, but Splinter Cell this is not. And it a few mandatory boss fights, which are of course terrible in this style of game. In fact, the game is very similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. They certainly both occupy the same genre of Steath/Action/RPG. The biggest difference is that DXHR has better gameplay, but far worse plot and character. Alpha Protocol has much better characters, plot, and dialogue/choices, but the gameplay is less polished. That said, if you enjoy games with well written characters, interesting choices, and one of the best conversation systems ever in any RPG, then you'll enjoy Alpha Protocol.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												A few words: Jolly good fun!!!Where to start??? A lot of choices, a lot of characters, a cool (if kinda campy) espionage story, what's not to like??? The way they handle choices is very brilliant. It's up to you whether you want to be a suave spy a la James bond or cold combat pragmatist a la Jason Bourne who punch the hell out of anyone dare to deter you from your objective. Choices matter. Some characters may like you, some may hate you. But what I like it isn't about good or bad choices. All choices have its own advantages and disadvantages. By threatening some informant you may get discount on weapons but he will alert the local government, blackmailing a local triad boss may get you a large sums of money but you lost his support, etc. There're also a lot of small details, such as dialog change based on where you start your mission first. Love this small care to details.There are also a lot of characters, some of them become your handler (your mission intel guy) and give you passive bonus, such as lowering the chance for your enemy to detect you or increasing your endurance. Sadly most of the time you'll be guided by Mina (your default handler) with few option to change handler in several missions. The problem with a lot of character is most of the character aren't really fleshed out. Some of them are really interesting but their story end up abruptly without closure about who's this guy really is or who the hell they work for, etc. Such a shame, really.And the story!!! Hell yeah it's your typical espionage story, about deception, betrayal, and controversial topic. What's make this game special is the way the story handled. A lot of your choices will affect the story. The story is immensely branching, many of your choices will create a completely different way the even unfolds and how the game will end. It's up to you whether you want to play a game about revenge, about patriotic spirit, or maybe you can gain something from all the conflicts? Who knows, eh? So what are you waiting for??? Play this game!!!

												Gameplay and controls are akward and plain bad. Its a "stealth" game, yet cover system is broken, you can pass by unnoticed by walking next to the enemy who take about five seconds to notice you and another five seconds to finally start shooting. Yet, other times you are sneaking and they magically know where you are. The shooting is... worse. I like realistic games, by realistic I mean, basic laws of physics apply, this being said, a game where somehow you shoot and bullet turn 180 degrees and headshot an enemy is not what I would call "realistic". The people in charge of the graphics did a good job with the textures, yet it takes about a second for textures to fully load in my computer playing in medium, (specially noticeable in inventory menu). I don't think this normal for that to happen on a computer with i7, 12 GB Ram, 4GB Graphics Card, which can load textures faster in newer games on High graphics. Also they really, really, like Depth of Field, which is nice to focus on the important during cutscenes, but fails miserably when you are sneaking and try to shoot, just before you shoot, some stupid object near you gets focused and your target gets out of focus so all the enemies, which are stupid, end up shooting you. The very begining was, nice, I thought I would like it, sadly, I don't. Luckily I got this game from the Sega Humble Bundle, but $15 for this? If you like spending $15 on a broken game, this is for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												Alpha Protocol does the best job creating a non-linear, branching narrative with meaningful decision points of any game I've encountered. Your relationship with various characters effects how they respond to you down the line and changes the color of the story being told. For once, there are no wrong options in a mechanical sense, either; every path leads to unique, sensible mechanical benefit through an elaborate "perk" system. You are genuinely rewarded for making your own way through the game, as well as for playing it more than once.There's a catch. This is one of the buggiest games I've played. The minigames are frustrating, the action wavers from slick to stuttering, and an untold number of glitches really put a damper on all the great level design and RPG systems at work. I still recommend it for the dialog and the chance to see a branching narrative done right. It also innovates on the guns-and-conversations genre with it's conversation system: as in Mass Effect you select the tone of your response rather than the exact wording, but here you only have a short amount of time to pick your response. This keeps the tension up, makes it feel more dynamic, and reduces analysis paralysis.Highly recommended if you can stomach the lack of polish. I really hope you can, becasue it's a wonderful game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Being able to make choices in a game is a big deal these days. It's just a shame few do it well. And out of those few that manage it, Alpha Protocol stands tall as the prime example. The gameplay may be archaic at best and broken at worst but it crafts an excellent techno-thriller with a well thought out world and invites you to spin it how you want. Whereas an average game would give you a bonus if you made someone your friend, Alpha Protocol may reward you by angering someone so much that their hatred of you clouds their judgement. Whereas a normal game makes you choose a side, Alpha Protocol invites you to play multiple sides, playing them off against each other leaving the remaining allies ripe for a final, easy betrayal. If you like games that let you truly get involved in their storylines and don't ever make you think how 'this choice would actually work in a video game', play this. Seriously, there's not really another game that has done choices as well.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3
												The game is structured around a series of missions in certain cities, including Rome, Moscow and Taipei. In each city Thorton has a home base where he can catch up on email, watch news reports (periodically updated to comment on the chaos caused by his latest operation) and buy new weapons and equipment. From each base he can rally out to do missions, which are sometimes nothing more than short cut scenes as Thorton tries to wheedle information out of someone else but are sometimes long and elaborate infiltration and combat operations. For each mission Thorton can attempt to achieve his objective through sneaking into locations without being seen, going in all guns blazing or attempt diplomacy (or some combination of the three). He also has the ability to hack security systems, remotely unlock doors or set traps. A levelling-and-skill system also gives Thorton a wide array of abilities he can upgrade to improve his chances of success.You can generally engage in conversations aggressively, suavely or professionally, with occasional extra options available if you have researched the right info about the character. Intelligence dossiers (bought through the black market or found on missions) hold clues as to how people will respond in certain situations, allowing you to manipulate them into helping you out. It's a clever system, enhanced by some satisfying dialogue and some terrific, unexpected outcomes which radically change the way the story develops.The game's reactivity is probably its best feature, with characters living or dying (sometimes taking entire storylines and occasional missions with them) based on your actions, or how you go about doing things. Alpha Protocol rewards replaying more than most games for this reason, with real consequences to your decisions.Alpha Protocol does have a reputation for being heavily bugged, although I did not find this to be the case. Minor bugs abound, but on only two occasions was I forced to reload. Out of a 15-hour game, that's not too bad at all. It's a game clearly in need of a few more months of polishing, but it's still perfectly playable to completion.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2013
												This is a tough one to review. I'm going to try and assert what this game is trying to be, followed by what it actually is. Alpha Protocol is advertised as espionage game with RPG elements, this may give potential buyers the idea that the level of sneaking involved is reminiscent to that of the elder Splinter Cell series, but unfortunately this is far from true. The mechanics in Alpha Protocol limit you to basic climbing, basic hand-to-hand combat and you should expect that most sneaking will consist of simply taking cover behind objects to break the line of sight, which is rather disappointing. However, the RPG elements in Alpha Protocol are nifty and interesting, they can greatly influence the game and the modifications you make will definitely be an asset to your personal skills and gameplay. Lastly, spy thrillers usually involve conspiracies or dirty gritty stories, and Alpha Protocol does this in a somewhat decent way. Don't get me wrong there, the story is pretty interesting and involves the player traveling to diverse locations and meeting different people, but the presentation of the story is lacking. With that in mind, my last important note and a lot of the justified criticism for this game can be mentioned shortly and firmly: this game should not have been released yet. Alpha Protocol is very buggy, feels unpolished and in overall these things killed what would have been a great experience. My verdict: only buy this if it's on sale, a price tag of  €5,- would be as far as I'd go. Of course, one might pay more if he or she is not annoyed by bad character animations, odd NPC behavior, graphics glitches and event triggers that do not work as intended. For reference, you can look up Voidhead's 'Alpha Protocol - bugs, glitches and annoyances' video on YouTube.

												This game is a lot better than people give it credit for. There has not been any other game this generation I've played that has had such an impact based around the player's choices and the consequences of them. This is a real RPG. Your stats matter, if your character isn't skilled with shooting guns you will miss every other shot. It won't hold your hand. You will make mistakes. You can't save everyone. People will die by your call. Everyone you meet can die by your decisions. The world is in your hands. Don't mess it up. I say pick it up on a Steam sale if you're not sure. Multiple playthroughs are necessary to see how differently the game can branch from your decisions.8/10, not perfect but I have a lot of fun playing it.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This game is sort of like the son you never wanted. It loves you unconditionally and will sit in your library patiently, waiting for you to love and accept it. And you'll rebuke its affection, saying it's "not polished" or "poorly balanced" or "buggy". When really, it's just a diamond in the rough, and you won't pay for medical to get his vertigo checked out, and you haven't cared enough to deal with the lice in his hair. But every once in awhile, you see it in the corner of your eye, and you know, you just know, that you need to do better by him. So you play with him for a few hours, and those hours become days, and you think, "Maybe I was wrong". Just because Kathy makes you pay for child support after the divorce, and still dumps him on you more than four days a week, doesn't mean you shouldn't love him. And it's in that moment that Morgan Freeman's voice can be heard, saying, "You've done good".

												This is a tough one to review. I'm going to try and assert what this game is trying to be, followed by what it actually is. Alpha Protocol is advertised as espionage game with RPG elements, this may give potential buyers the idea that the level of sneaking involved is reminiscent to that of the elder Splinter Cell series, but unfortunately this is far from true. The mechanics in Alpha Protocol limit you to basic climbing, basic hand-to-hand combat and you should expect that most sneaking will consist of simply taking cover behind objects to break the line of sight, which is rather disappointing. However, the RPG elements in Alpha Protocol are nifty and interesting, they can greatly influence the game and the modifications you make will definitely be an asset to your personal skills and gameplay. Lastly, spy thrillers usually involve conspiracies or dirty gritty stories, and Alpha Protocol does this in a somewhat decent way. Don't get me wrong there, the story is pretty interesting and involves the player traveling to diverse locations and meeting different people, but the presentation of the story is lacking. With that in mind, my last important note and a lot of the justified criticism for this game can be mentioned shortly and firmly: this game should not have been released yet. Alpha Protocol is very buggy, feels unpolished and in overall these things killed what would have been a great experience. My verdict: only buy this if it's on sale, a price tag of  €5,- would be as far as I'd go. Of course, one might pay more if he or she is not annoyed by bad character animations, odd NPC behavior, graphics glitches and event triggers that do not work as intended. For reference, you can look up Voidhead's 'Alpha Protocol - bugs, glitches and annoyances' video on YouTube.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3
												The game is structured around a series of missions in certain cities, including Rome, Moscow and Taipei. In each city Thorton has a home base where he can catch up on email, watch news reports (periodically updated to comment on the chaos caused by his latest operation) and buy new weapons and equipment. From each base he can rally out to do missions, which are sometimes nothing more than short cut scenes as Thorton tries to wheedle information out of someone else but are sometimes long and elaborate infiltration and combat operations. For each mission Thorton can attempt to achieve his objective through sneaking into locations without being seen, going in all guns blazing or attempt diplomacy (or some combination of the three). He also has the ability to hack security systems, remotely unlock doors or set traps. A levelling-and-skill system also gives Thorton a wide array of abilities he can upgrade to improve his chances of success.You can generally engage in conversations aggressively, suavely or professionally, with occasional extra options available if you have researched the right info about the character. Intelligence dossiers (bought through the black market or found on missions) hold clues as to how people will respond in certain situations, allowing you to manipulate them into helping you out. It's a clever system, enhanced by some satisfying dialogue and some terrific, unexpected outcomes which radically change the way the story develops.The game's reactivity is probably its best feature, with characters living or dying (sometimes taking entire storylines and occasional missions with them) based on your actions, or how you go about doing things. Alpha Protocol rewards replaying more than most games for this reason, with real consequences to your decisions.Alpha Protocol does have a reputation for being heavily bugged, although I did not find this to be the case. Minor bugs abound, but on only two occasions was I forced to reload. Out of a 15-hour game, that's not too bad at all. It's a game clearly in need of a few more months of polishing, but it's still perfectly playable to completion.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is the most reactive game ever created. Every other RPG you've played where "choices matter!" and "you shape the story!"? Complete bunk compared to this. There are SO MANY things you can manipulate that it is entirely possible to end the game with the entire main cast dead or every single one of them alive. If you enjoy good writing (the game was developed by Obsidian who have created some of the greatest RPGs in the business), semi-cheesy spy fiction and interesting characters you will fall in love with this game.Now for the bad parts:The start of the game is pretty slow and fairly linear. After completing the tutorial and the first "hub" the game opens up hugely in both options of where to go and the impact of your choices. Many reviewers never got past this first area and therefore never got to experience the 'real game', leading to a lot of fairly negative reviews.A lot of people dislike the gunplay and combat. Personally I found it solid and enjoyable, if not particularly special. However, the build balance is slightly out of whack - the pistol's Chain Shot (similar to Mark and Execute systems found in other games) is way better than any other weapon's special ability. However if you just embrace the cheese you can run a Martial Arts/Stealth build that leads to you, about halfway through the game, being able to turn invisible and punch every single person in the room in the throat, which is wonderful fun. Be aware that some bosses are really really hard to melee though, so pure martial arts builds might suffer.Despite these and some other minor niggles, however, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. There's nothing on the market that compares to Alpha Protocol for reactivity.

content:
Posted: April 21
												Alpha Protocol is an awesome action RPG game from Obsidian Entertainment and published by SEGA which is about a guy named Mike Thorton. Then you can customize your Mike Thorton and then you set up the skills you want for him. Then you can set up the classification for Mike Thorton like be a field agent, a freelancer, etc. In the world of Alpha Protocol you will have to make some tough decisions. Those decisions will affect the game and the future storyline of the game. And also there is a romance option on this game as well. Mike Thorton can choose a female character to romance and be with. This game is amazing and really underrated. This game is not that known but most know this game enough to create a fanbase for it. Which is why I considered this game as a criminally underrated cult classic game. I highly recommend this game because this game is really fun and it's awesome! I would definitely be on board for a Alpha Protocol 2 game! :D

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13
												A success in storytelling and choice/consequence. A missed opportunity in gameplay. Alpha Protocol does a superb job in making your choices matter. Tackling the story missions in a different order leads to different reactions from the main character and other NPC's, alliances being made with different factions with enemies made from others, and significant impact on the endgame. Likewise conversation options, and how fast or slow you make dialogue choices, can impact the strength of your opponent or even skip a fight entirely. This game does a great job in enforcing the weight of your decisions and making you feel like a spy. Alpha Protocol fails in the combat department. Shooting feels inprecise and melee combat (especially in 1 on 1 scenarios) is a simple test of mashing the attack button. AI is poor, even for the time this title was released.I still recommend this game to fans of choice and consequence in games or fans of the action/spy genre. If the combat systems of a game like Mass Effect could synergize with the rest of this game, Alpha Protocol would have become much more than the overlooked title it has become.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This is a very underrated stealth/action game that recieved a lot of crap when it first came out. If not for those early reviews I have no doubt this game would be rated at least 80-85 on metacritic. The main problem is that the developers tried to put everything into the game, so it doesnt nessesarily excell at any of them. With that said, the game is very unique because of this as well. You're able to build social connections in the game, customize your armor and weapons, and go about missions however you like. You'll see the results and effects of how many people you kill or how many people see you once the mission is over. You even get a little terminal in the game that you can use for emailing other characters.Overall it's a really good game, but it may take a bit to get used to the very strange shooting mechanics. Once you've jumped that hurdle you'll be gold.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												The excellent title from Obsidian Entertainment (the sadly underrated Alpha Protocol), delivers to gamers a uniquely satisfying experience. Alpha Protocol suffers from perhaps two things only - the admittedly horrible combat system, and the "average" quality of the AI. Most video games boast "average" intelligence; this title is no different, and although that wouldn't make much of a difference in the long run, a game which focuses on stealth mechanics should most definitely have decent AI. Now, what Alpha Protocol DOES deliver is in fact an incredibly mature, well-thought, and gritty story interspersed with above average scripts (some good, some bad); memorable characters, locations, interactions, story pathing, and a decent upgrade system. What makes this game essentially worthwhile though, is the character networking, the scripting. Relationships matter, and the dialogue flows like a good spy thriller. The relationships one makes in the game directly influences the end game conclusion, and it's a most satisfying experience indeed.I would recommend Alpha Protocol for both newcomers and the avid afficionado of the genre alike.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Ignore the negative press. This is easily one of my favourite RPGs of the last generation. The sheer reactivity of the game is staggering, and the dialogue trees are second to none. In an age where voice acting has stunted the opportunity for player choice, this is one game that manages to pull it off.The combat ain't Mass Effect. This is foremost a stat-driven RPG. Your gun will miss if you haven't put points into it. For some, that's unacceptable, but I never saw that as a problem.Obsidian might be a flawed developer, but they're the best RPG maker in the biz.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2012
												9/10 Ignore the metascore and check out this game.It's Obsidian, which sadly means that it's a flawed work of genius, but it's still a work of GENIUS! This game is the sequel that DEUS EX deserved, never mind that Invisible War nonsense...Most importantly remember that this is an RPG and not a shooter. This means that blazing gun battles are not well presented, but it also means that ALL of your decisions, and a LOT of your casual throwaway comments have an impact. Not just in a "character X was killed, we'll replace them with generic NPC in this mission" way, but in an actual "You didn't back me up when I was arguing with a contact, so now you'll never get to know about a side mission and potential comrade in a future chapter" way. This leads to me giving it the best possible praise for any RPG:PLAY THIS GAME! THEN REPLAY IT IN A COMPLETELY DIFFERENT WAY! THEN AGAIN! And yes, some of the mini-games can be frustrating, but there are tools for defeating those. Just like Deus Ex, there are multiple solutions to any problem. Trying to raid your former boss for files that can  solve your final case? Why not show some professional courtesy and slip in and out completely unseen, without setting off any alarms. Or just give them a little nap? Or show them what happens to people who fire you and spread them suckas over the walls with your shotgun?Personally I stormed through an "Elite" force's base taking down every armed guard with my hand-to-hand, just to send a message.Finally, I'm not saying that Alpha Protocol is the game version of Burn Notice, but if you made a game of Burn Notice, it'd look a lot like Alpha Protocol.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Rating 8.5/10Overview: Underrated RPG The Good:+ What really sets Alpha Protocol apart from almost every other RPG out there is that EVERY choice you make influences the story or your character in some way. The order in which you play missions, the choices you make in the game, how you speak to people...all of it has a major or minor effect in how the story and missions play out. There is no right or wrong answer, there is no good or evil, there is only your choices and the consequences that follow. + Character creation is identical to the first Mass Effect. As you level up you gain points to spend in a variety of categories. As you spend points in any particular category you gain passive and active abilities. You could play stealthy, guns blazing, maybe some close quarter combat, the game gives you plenty of options in how to develop your character+ The game provides a lot of different perks depending on how you play. Pick enough locks and you will get a bonus to your lock picking skills. Get enough headshots and you gain a perk in accuracy etc. Almost everything you do in the game has some sort of perk associated with it.+ Lots of items/weapons/armor/upgrades to further customize your character + Multiple endings depending on the choices you make. + Level design is solid, giving you multiple ways of completing certain objectives. My biggest gripe however is that the levels are a little too linear for my tastes. For a game that is all about choices I would have liked some more levels that are open ended.  + The story and dialogue is well written and doesn't take itself too seriously given the subject matter. Obsidian wasn't afraid to have a lot of interesting characters either. + Surprisingly, on a technical level the graphics are very well done. Textures and characters are well detailed. The AverageThe AI can be very impressive at times. The enemies hide behind cover, duck and weave, try to flank you at times and in general act the way they are suppose to. This only highlights when enemies act completely stupid, running in the same spot, getting stuck behind cover, and in general seem to prefer being dead than alive. Very noticeable texture load in when customizing your look or selecting weapons and armor. Some texture pop in when a level loads.Certain bosses are very difficult to complete depending on what skills you invested in. The game can be easily 'broken' if you invest in certain skills The Bad- The crouching animation is one of the worst animations I've seen in gaming - There is an overall lack of polish in the game especially regarding the cover based shooting.- The game can be especially frustrating in the beginning when you have very low skills and killing enemies is difficult.  Conclusion  I have completed this game many times on the xbox360 and looking at this game strictly from a RPG perspective  I think Alpha Protocol is one of the best RPG's around. One of the reasons why the game did so poorly is that most people were expecting a third person shooter with RPG elements like Mass Effect, instead Alpha Protocol is a full blown RPG that happens to be a third person shooter. As long as you realize this you will have a great time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I absolutely love this game! Despite all of it's bugs, animation problems, questionable level design, gameplay flaws (stealth system and shooting are truly horrible), it is one of those games, which give you a chance to LIVE the experience, not just shoot-kill-see-the-cat-scene. The plot and the approach to storytelling are amazing, the characters are really interesting; the dialog system is something similar to the one we've seen in Mass Effect, but it is more complex: there are no simply paragon/renegade/something_useless options, you have to find the dialog tactic for each of NPC you meet in this game. Strongly recommend this game to the fans of Obsidian titles and RPGs in general.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												I have fond memories of this game from my Xbox days, but this PC port - at least with Win10 - is unplayable. The big problem is that commands are usually completely unresponsive. Whether I'm trying to take cover, select an inventory item, or throw a grenade, the game refuses to cooperate more often than not, which, as I'm sure you can imagine, is a bit of an issue when the fecal matter hits the spinner. And no matter what the graphical settings (and my Fallout 4-friendly laptop is not the problem), the framerate has frequent (as in, every couple of seconds) tears and stutters at all times. It's just an awful - or at least poorly updated - PC port of a perfectly decent console game. That said, the style hits some good notes, and the roleplay elements are still pretty neat, being better and more complex than almost any of the competition even now. Which just makes the unforgivable control problems that much more tragic.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Introduction:Alpha Protocol combines an enthralling storyline with a functioning role playing core and the highest grade of replayability in years! This game is my favorite Spy game to date of writing this review (3/29/2016). It has it's flaws but at it's core is an amazing game. Look beyond its obvious faults and Alpha Protocol isn’t frustratingly bad, but frustratingly good; that is, if you care to look that hard.Positive:+ An astounding variety of ethical decisions that affect how the story unfolds+ A wide range of believable, fun characters; characters that you just have to love (and hate)+ Great FPS with a plethora of guns to choose from with attachments+ Government thriller story that allows you to pick which route you want to go+ Romantic options+ Multiple endings+ Excellent execution of FPS/RPG with fun minigames (hacking/lock-picking)+ Character creation allows for different types of playstylesNegatives:- Game designed for console that causes a lot of bugs for PC port (listed below)- AI is bad, sometimes it reminds me of old school Goldeneye- Crosshair/Accuracy, bullets just seem to randomly miss no matter where the crosshair is placed- No Sniper Rifle as a choice of guns to upgrade, although placed in game in missions- Bugs, overall a terrible PC port- No Achievements- No Steam trading cardsFails of computer port:- Hacking is extremely tedious sometimes moving the mouse to get to the correct location- Mouse sensitivity is terrible, hard to adjust for multiple weapons (IE: moving then using sniper rifle)- Camera movement was bad, I ended up getting used to it though- Graphics could be better, designed for consoles- No hotkeys/gadgets for skills because it was designed with limited buttons of a controller- Bugs againGood Game: 7/10, could be a 10/10 GOTY if they fixed their computer port issues (or made a game specifically for the PC)Good game that's a MUST BUY during a sale. I think it's even worth full price ($14.99 at the time of writing this). It is a rare game that I might actually replay. I am the type of person who can only watch a movie once, same with games. Alpha Protocol might break the trend when I replay it. This was one of those games I just couldn't stop playing.It needs a sequel to get everything right and designed for PC.Some screenshots of the game (some may contain spoilers, didn't go through them):https://steamcommunity.com/id/ImpalaPUA/screenshots/?appid=34010

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												In Alpha Protocol, players control Michael Thorton, a young man with a chip on his shoulder who acts like a real bummer around his friends after his girlfriend left him for his uncontrollable flatulence problem. The game takes place over the course of a single night where Michael’s bros take him out for a night around town. This however isn’t just any night, for Michael’s friends decided to activate what they call the “Alpha Protocol”. The game reveals itself to be a visual novel dating sim where Michael Thorton’s friends pressure him to talk to young ladies, but only after talking to them about how alpha Michael is, and how much of a catch he would be. This goes on for a while as every eligible lady is turned off by Michael’s stench of sewage and rotten eggs. In the end, Michael comes to the epiphany that perhaps he should look for some ladies who also have trouble controlling their sphincters.The moral of the game’s narrative is that perhaps being beta isn’t so bad.

												An odd combination, espionage/agent RPG.Overall, I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10, That number feels *right*.The graphics were certainly not amazing, the gameplay could've been more varied, the sounds we're nothing amazing either, so why 7.5/10?It had me just like Mass Effect had me, intruiging, your choices impacted the game story greatly, if you were friendly or not had it's positive or negative effects at some point into the game, I enjoyed the sneaky-route and the suave-♥♥♥♥youintheface-route, and at some point, I'll probably replay it again, going for another route. There's many many many ways to play this game and next time, a certain ♥♥♥♥♥ is going to die early on.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is the gaming equivalent of a homely girl with a heart of gold. She may not look that great in comparison to some of her sisters, nor will she entice many people with her odd quirks; however, once you get to know her she will blow you away with her razor sharp wit and give you some truly memorable conversations. Her incredible depth will make you learn more and more things about her even after "playing through" her three times - leaving you yearning for more. She's in good company with Deus Ex and Vampire: The Masquerade in the sense that these gals have some serious quirks but are ultimately the dream girl at the end of film.She may not be for everyone at face value but if you give her the chance she deserves you surely won't be disappointed.

Yes.After all this time Obsidian got rid of most of the bugs so now the game experience is good.If you want a mixture of rpg elements (a lot of them and with actual repercussions on the story) and decent cover-based shooter then this game is for you; also, completing the game nearly only with stealth and takedowns is possible or, if you want to be a gunblazing tankier bearded badass you can achieve it.I completed the game in about 17 hours on normal using mostly the stealth+silenced pistol+takedowns approach so it can be less long if you like to shoot everything on sight with shotguns/assault rifles/gadgets.And yes, you can get the girls in here.sidenote: the pistol tree is pretty much op but, along with the stealth one, it's a must if you want to play the stealth approach.
