content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												I adore this game to bits. I've almost put 24 hours into this and will put more into it. The dialogue is fantastic with characters responding to things like your previous choices and how you've talked to them in the past. There are also a crap load of choices. In my first run I played as a charasmatic ninja god who shot everyone in the end. In my current I'm a no nonsense tech god who takes people out using traps and shotguns. The levels are sadly mostly linear and the combat isn't very good. The enemies also just feel like differently skinned goons with nothing interesting about them. Oh and the Chain Shot Reload Cooldowns combo cheeses any and all bosses instantly. Overall great for people who can ignore combat gripes and enjoy a great story.

												Based on the three J.B.s: Jason Bourne, Jack Bauer and James Bond this is a spy game where you choose the action, stealth or suave demeanor to get though. Despite the less and glowing reviews this game is worth the time you spend with it. Fun missions, decent storyline, and a chance to live off the radar. content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I finished this game like 4 times before buying it from Steam (Or, perhaps, I got it with a Humble Bundle. I don't remember correctly) and I enjoyed every single bit of it.You play as Michael Thorton, a brilliant and promising trainee to join the ranks of Alpha Protocol, a secret agency. Prove everyone and yourself that you're the best agents around. As the world around you seems to collapse, you always find a way out.Introducing a similar, but much more interactive, dialogue system like Mass Effect, you decide the attitude you want Michael to have towards people, depending the personalities of the others and what you have read in their dossiers.Be a spy lurking in the shadows or a tough soldier ramping your way inside compounds and bases. This amazing third person shooter game also have RPG elements allowing you to make the agent you want to be.The story is not so long, I think. Depending on the difficulty, 20 hours should be enough for you to finish it.Perhaps you've heard about some bugs and glitches this game have. I will not deny it, it's not a perfect game. As everything, it has some flaws. But, trust me, it's an experience hard to forget.Would I recommend it? Hell, yes!So, feel free to buy it, my friend. I'm sure that, if you like RPG's, you will totally love it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Great game but it could have been so much more.  Good:It's a spy shooter that let's you play the way you want, stealth, guns blazing, etc.  An RPG skill system can be used to bolster your play style, for example developing lock pickking, silent running, rifles, explosives, etc. Your choices in and out of combat give you influence with various characters and ultimately decide how the story unfolds and how the game ends. Bad:It was obviously dumbed down for consoles.  Some of the hacking mini games are annoyingAlthough the story is good, some of the choices are forced a la Mass Effect, choose who dies.Worse, it does so, by commiting the ultimate gameplay sin where you win a battle, but lose in a cutscene.Overall.  I love the game, but it could have been so much better.  As with many Obsidian games, the final execution just isn't quite there.  When will game makers understand that the real art isn't forcing us to choose who dies.  It's in allowing us to discover how to save both, or maybe not to be the hero and let them all die.  Still, highly worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Controls are clunky and painful, protagonist has an absurdly annoying voice that you will immediately be sick of, when the player walks around while crouching it's one of the most comical animations I've ever seen, and the shooting mechanics suuuuuck.But it's still one of my favorite games, becaaauuse...1. It balances player choice with a smooth narrative. No matter what direction you choose, the story always compensates and fills in the gaps with finesse.2. The skills actually reward you by giving you crappy skills to begin with. You start out as a top operative but can't shoot worth a damn, and then after several missions and a few upgrades, you're finally getting the hang of things and notice a dramatic improvement in the mechanics.3. The supporting characters dynamically react to how you treat them. This is the closest we will get to scripted AI dialogue where our responses affect the NPC's attitudes and behaviors in conversations and remain consistent throughout the game unless you resolve the conflicts.4. Gun modifications make sense and follow a semblance of realism, which isn't unpopular nowadays but adds a nice addition to the game.This is a super toned down version of Just Cause with fantastically crafted dialogue. And right now it's 3 bucks. You have no reason to not buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												The first thing you will notice is that the combat itself is very.... unique. When I first played AP, it was hard to get into but I persisted, hearing good things about this game from other people. After the first few mission were over and the international plot began to emerge, along with the characters who would be along for the ride with you, I was hooked. It is an RPG, not a shooter by any stretch. And what an RPG. Obsidian continue to impress with the story lines. No binary good/bad system is in the game, something which shows this game to be beyond anything before. Many will think of Mass Effect while playing, and to an extent they are right. The first ME was a poor combat game but a good RPG. This is a brilliant RPG: each choice makes a diffrence, every single dialogue choice could change the end of the game in subtle ways.This game could be much better. The combat and stealth could work in a more logical way, the pistol could stop been the answer to EVERY combat question. But the dialogue, plot and characters make this all worth playing.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Alpha Protocol... What an odd game to be reviewing. This game has average AI, Bad combat, clunky animation, stealth that is ruined by invisibility and guns that feel like pea-shooters. Yet, the dialog, choices, and story, somehow manage to make this game compelling and a blast to play. The guns suck, but the shotguns are somewhat fun to use once you charge them up. The melee combat is a bit odd just run up and punch someone two or three times and they are out, or sneak kill/knock-out. Honestly, this is one of the best games there is, but SEGA constantly changing what type of game they wanted made it a bit of a mess. But even though it is a mess, its like a Jackson Pollock painting.Sure it isn't the most amazing game of all time, but it is worth a play through. Just keep in mind, this is an RPG, not a TPS.

A guy recently signed onto a super secret ultraviolet level covert ops group that do jobs that other organizations can't handle. 												This game is fantastic! For 2 dollars your can't argue to NOT buy this game, a lot bad rep kept this game from shining. content:

												One of the last games by Bioware and Obsidian that I've finished.  I'm a big fan of both companies.  Alpha Protocol isn't a bad game, though the plot is relatively uninspired and the dialogue is a little...wooden.  However, you can see glimpses of greatness here and there. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												This is seriously one of the best games I ever played. Yes. Seriously.Not only is the gameplay is really good (you can approach your missions in any style you like - sneaky or brute force, lethal or non-lethal, solo or with help, etc.) the story is very engaging. It's a true spy story. It takes you all over the world (which leads to very different areas in both style and atmosphere) and brings you in contact with all manner of organisations with their specific style of members and a number of very interesting NPCs. The roleplaying aspect - where you choose from different styles of answers in dialogs (like professional, sarcastic, casual, suave, etc.) has a true impact on the gameplay, as do you choices during your missions. It gives you different allies or enemies.Except for the good old violence, there are also locks to pick, electronic locks or alarms to disable, and computers to hack, all tree done through minigames that decrease in difficulty if you have the right skills.Progression is level based. Your PC goes up in levels by earning experience, which gives you points you can spend on several skill tracks, things like stealth, pistol, assault rifle, sabotage, etc.There is also a sort of underground black market where you can buy all sorts of weapons and armor and accessories for those, as well as gadgets like grenades and spy trickery, but also intel, like maps, dossiers on NPCs or organisations, support, extra mission objects, etc.So, yes, I love this game. It really has it all.

Posted: March 21, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is the gaming equivalent of a homely girl with a heart of gold. She may not look that great in comparison to some of her sisters, nor will she entice many people with her odd quirks; however, once you get to know her she will blow you away with her razor sharp wit and give you some truly memorable conversations. Her incredible depth will make you learn more and more things about her even after "playing through" her three times - leaving you yearning for more. She's in good company with Deus Ex and Vampire: The Masquerade in the sense that these gals have some serious quirks but are ultimately the dream girl at the end of film.She may not be for everyone at face value but if you give her the chance she deserves you surely won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Let me just start by saying the Alpha Protocol is one of the few RPGs I know that have delivered on it's 'choice changes the game' mechanic. I've played this game for 80 hours now, and I can say that there's cutscenes I have seen in LPs that I haven't even played before.GameplayHonestly, this isn't the best combat I've ever seen. You can play with stealth, or just shoot everything in the face. You start off with 4 classes to choose from which have perk points already in some predetermined places, but you can mix them up. A 5th option, Recruit, has you starting with no perk points at all, making the game a lot harder. Completing the Recruit option will unlock Veteran for future playthroughs, who has perks from previous experience.You can carry two weapons with you at a time, ranging from an assault rifle, a shotgun, an smg and a pistol. They can be upgraded and you can even buy more of them in the safehouse.The safehouse serves as a hub for you inbetween missions, allowing you to read your emails (which sometimes contain funding or other useful information), watch TV about 'recent affairs', or check the black market. On the black market you can buy things ranging from a map of the complex to intelligence on a person.You can build up intel on people or groups, and knowing it can sometimes give you an extra option in conversations. They also give you a certain damage bonus against some of the bosses.StorySPOILERS:The story begins with you, Mike Thorton, waking up in a secret government facility. You break out, only to find that it was a test of your abilities. You are sent off to Saudi Arabia, to recover stolen Halbech missiles. A terrorist group has stolen them, and they used them to blow up a civillian plane earlier. There will be sequences where you are sat in a room talking to a man about what you have just done. The idea is that the missions happened months ago, and you're being interrogated now. You will learn in Saudi that the missiles were never stolen, they were given freely by Halbech. With the help of an agent, Mina, who is still operating in the AP facility, you escape, and quickly realise that Halbech are attempting to spark a war, so that they can ramp up production and earn more money. Off the data you take with you you find that there are three major Halbech locations. They are Rome, Taipei and Moscow. You can visit them in any order, but the game will change considerably based on which one you go to. After collecting information on Halbech, you have to return to the AP base to finish it all. Based on if you romanced anyone or you were good friends with them and they survived, they will join you on a final boatride into the sunset.VerdictThe story is extremely well written and has a very high replayability, only being dragged down by the combat. For that, I'll give it an 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
Alpha Protocol™ is an overlooked gem of an RPG. Alpha Protocol™ is the whole package. A branching story, filled with multiple game-changing decisions. Each mission has more than one approach to it. Weapons and gear customization. Story: You play as agent Michael Thorton, tasked with his first Alpha Protocol mission. Things, however, are much different from what they seem to be, as Thorton becomes involved in a conspiracy. The story features many turns and twists and yes, you can be evil as much, as you want to.  Gameplay: Alpha Protocol™, however, is plagued in its gameplay. While you can opt for a stealthy campaign, you're still forced into close combat and horrible boss encounters.  Movement is detailed, you can climb walls, crouch, vault over. However, it is also restricted. You can do those things only where the game says you can.  Shooting, on the other hand, is terrible, but this plays a part in the character progression. Depending on what skills you decide to improve on, shooting can be enjoyable. As mentioned above, there is character progression. These are upgradable skills, which can influence your experience with the game and, combined with the dialogue choice, encourage multiple playthroughs. Sum up: So is Alpha Protocol™ worth checking out? Yes, definitely. While the gameplay is a mixed bag, the story is worth it. Give this one a try,

content:
Posted: July 6, 2011
												Yes, this game has some fundamental flaws and could have used some more testing before it was released.  BUT, if you enjoy the decision elements of western RPG's such as Mass Effect, and open-ended gameplay like Deus Ex, you will love the twists and turns available to you in Alpha Protocol.  I have played through this game twice, taking two very different approaches, and it was almost literally like playing two entirely different games.  My suggestion for making the most of this game: build your character to be stealthy (the stealth system was well-refined) and throw any obsession you have about choosing the "correct" conversation option out the window: you will ALWAYS be rewarded for whatever option you take, even if what you chose seems ridiculous!

												This game has two sides. The first one consists of shaky gameplay and technical unrefinement; the shooting, covering system, sneaking, animations, everything screams "unpolished".The second side is what makes the game shine despite its flaws: plot, storytelling, dialogues, characters, consequences. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2011
												After finishing this game, I really don't understand why it got such a panning - it's great!I'll start with the not-so-good stuff first:•	The AI isn't great, and•	The boss battles are insanely unfairThat's it.Alpha Protocol is an espionage RPG/shooter, but really - first and foremost - it's a great story well told. It offers choices that have real consequence, and it allows you to play it out however you see fit.All out action? Sneaky stealth? A combination of both? You can tailor your character to suit your play style. I'm a sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at heart, so I chose a Specialist, with Stealth and Martial Arts as my lead attributes ;)You want to kill everyone you come across? You can. Prefer to be non-lethal and just use a painful take-down instead? You can do that too. That assassin that tried to kill you, you want to kill or spare it? Again, up to you, and each choice will affect the story.Conversations I found a blast, with usually 3-4 options as a reply - 'Joking', 'Suave', 'Professional', 'Tender', 'Taunt', 'Antagonise', 'Execute'... Each response can have its pro's and con's, whether positive or negative, and affects how the other person will react to you in the future. It looks pretty good, while not spectacular. The look is very 'clean', and there is a few clipping instances, but I really didn't find anything that marred my experience. I'm not sure how many hours it took to complete, as the Steam hours counter didn't work on quite a few of my plays. I would say around 20-25, though. I played the game using an Xbox 360 pad, so I can't really comment on the mouse/keyboard controls, but from what I've read, the pad is the way to play, really.I paid £5 for this in the Steam Sale, but I really wouldn't have felt cheated if I paid full whack for it. It really is a shame it was received the way it was, and that the sales reflected this. I would have loved another slice. It's a good job multiple playthroughs are catered for... :D

												This game didn't deserve all the hate it got. It's a pretty decent RPG where choices in friends play an important role. The progression system is good and all, but there are some fights where you'll sit there and think "Huh. I put all of my points into stealth, and now I'm stuck in an open gunfight with an insane boss. This sucks."  There are a small number of bosses like this, but enough to make it a real hassle. I whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in RPGs and spies, but you NEED to put at least some points in at least one gun. I suggest the pistol if you're trying to avoid killing people. It's the only gun with tranquilizer ammo.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												This game got a seriously bad rap. It's not the best third-person shooter I've played, and oftentimes one might run into an annoying bug, but overall it's a game that offers a lot.Espionage isn't the most investigated genre in the gaming industry, at least not to this level - and Obsidian did a good job of it. Globe-trotting, stealth missions, lethal or non-lethal methodologies - it's a good example of a good game being lambasted unfairly by the general public.The dialogue and choice system are top-notch and can vastly change the playthrough from one game to the next. Most comparable to the dialogue system in Mass Effect, how you treat others can have serious ramifications long down the road; choices made when conversing with one character may completely alter the conversation you have with another several chapters later. A very impressive achievement, and one that seems to have flown under the radar of most.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2011
												Don't judge the game by the first hour.This game is fantastically well-written. If you're a fan of RPGs and rate dialogue, story, characters and consequence over guns and explosions, you will absolutely love this game. I'm currently on my 3rd playthrough, and have had a very different experience each time. If the reason you loved Deus Ex: Human Revolution was because of the conspiracy, the dialogue challenges and the repurcussions of your actions then I would DEFINITELY recommend you play this.Annoyingly, there is a definite learning curve and the movement and combat controls are lacking. I very nearly gave up on this game within the first hour, because I found the computer hacking minigame (coupled with the checkpoints save system) so frustrating I wasn't enjoying it at all. But I am VERY glad I stuck with it: once I got the hang of the hacking game and levelled my character to be more stealthy, the limitations became much less evident.Buggy controls, but *superb* writing.

												8.5 / 10 I think this game is totally under rated. the game must have been patched, i only saw one major glitch. the stealth in this game is pretty good, thats how i played it anyway, but it really only allows you to fully specialise in one weapon which is annoying.Evasion allows you to go invistible for 3-6 seconds when an enemy sees you, to allow you to attack or hide. if stealth, you want the proper stealth gear ($130k) that is not avaible after you finish saudi arabia, get it there.also there are other cool perks, hard to kill reserects you at death and allows you to recover. You have a secondary health that recharges, so it you hide somewhere, it gives you a good chance of survival.SIUMMARISING, Its a subtle cross between hitman tactics and dues ex story line, but is not as good as either of those games. The amount of influence your decisions have on what happens next though, is very impressive. Would recommend. 22h to clock roughly

Posted: September 28, 2011
												I don't know why this game got panned. When I heard they were making an espionage action RPG with Mass-Effect conversation threads that you need to react to in real-time, I actually got tingly. But, then the reviews came out, and, shamefully, I listened.However, I gave the game a chance recently (as it was on special), and sat and played through it until I got a yeast infection. This game is that kind of fun. It's not perfect, but what game is? It's the right mix of over-the-top spy action and RPG level-ups that everyone loves. Get yourself a stick and a rag, and sit down to play this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2012
												This game didn't deserve all the hate it got. It's a pretty decent RPG where choices in friends play an important role. The progression system is good and all, but there are some fights where you'll sit there and think "Huh. I put all of my points into stealth, and now I'm stuck in an open gunfight with an insane boss. This sucks."  There are a small number of bosses like this, but enough to make it a real hassle. I whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in RPGs and spies, but you NEED to put at least some points in at least one gun. I suggest the pistol if you're trying to avoid killing people. It's the only gun with tranquilizer ammo.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2010
												It's like Bioware and Obsidian had a baby. The gameplay and npc dialogue will leave you reminiscent of Mass Effect, while the story will probably remind you of Obsidian's inability to put together a decent story. At least this game has an ending. Several, in fact, which all depend on actions you take through the game, as opposed to one important decision made at the end. Even though it's marketed as a stealth rpg, you are free to go in guns blazing, although that will punish you through means of severely reduced mission rewards and your allies either hating you or loving you for it. Think Dragon Age's approval system, where some of your allies might look down upon killing police officers, while others might encourage you to take down anyone in your way. In a way, this is an interesting game mechanic, as there are some npcs you might want to hate you for story related reasons.Overall, a solid game that didn't get the appreciation it deserved when it first came out.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2012
												This game has two sides. The first one consists of shaky gameplay and technical unrefinement; the shooting, covering system, sneaking, animations, everything screams "unpolished".The second side is what makes the game shine despite its flaws: plot, storytelling, dialogues, characters, consequences. All these aspects are at least on par with Bioware games, so there's some quality to it. All in all, giving it a try wouldn't be a bad idea if you're a fan of the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2011
												After finishing this game, I really don't understand why it got such a panning - it's great!I'll start with the not-so-good stuff first:•	The AI isn't great, and•	The boss battles are insanely unfairThat's it.Alpha Protocol is an espionage RPG/shooter, but really - first and foremost - it's a great story well told. It offers choices that have real consequence, and it allows you to play it out however you see fit.All out action? Sneaky stealth? A combination of both? You can tailor your character to suit your play style. I'm a sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at heart, so I chose a Specialist, with Stealth and Martial Arts as my lead attributes ;)You want to kill everyone you come across? You can. Prefer to be non-lethal and just use a painful take-down instead? You can do that too. That assassin that tried to kill you, you want to kill or spare it? Again, up to you, and each choice will affect the story.Conversations I found a blast, with usually 3-4 options as a reply - 'Joking', 'Suave', 'Professional', 'Tender', 'Taunt', 'Antagonise', 'Execute'... Each response can have its pro's and con's, whether positive or negative, and affects how the other person will react to you in the future. It looks pretty good, while not spectacular. The look is very 'clean', and there is a few clipping instances, but I really didn't find anything that marred my experience. I'm not sure how many hours it took to complete, as the Steam hours counter didn't work on quite a few of my plays. I would say around 20-25, though. I played the game using an Xbox 360 pad, so I can't really comment on the mouse/keyboard controls, but from what I've read, the pad is the way to play, really.I paid £5 for this in the Steam Sale, but I really wouldn't have felt cheated if I paid full whack for it. It really is a shame it was received the way it was, and that the sales reflected this. I would have loved another slice. It's a good job multiple playthroughs are catered for... :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												By far one of the jankiest and most enjoyable Action RPGs you can play.Obsidian is nothing if not a writing savant and with Alpha Protocol it shines through. Gameplay is your basic spy game; stealth around, jump kick a guy, put several bullets in his head at once. Nothing groundbreaking but it doesn't need to be. As I said, it's packed to the brim with quality dialogue choices and trees that would make Mass Effect 3 weep. Shepard? Nah son, give me Steven Heck any day.A+ quality Obsidian title. Don't expect some perfect simulation or deep immersion, you are looking at the wrong company for that.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2012
												Pros: Absolutely brilliant conversaion system concept. Excellent story arc arguably better than 24 and Homeland combined. Between the conspiracy theory puns (from the silly to well-founded) and the parodies of the media, I enjoyed every minute of it.Cons: Make sure to use an Exbawckz360 controller because of the annoying mouse bugs. There are also some confusing choices to make at two integral parts of the game, but they're actually not bugs. You also don't get absolute freedom in how to go about accomplishing the mission; you can't make Mike into a bad guy without some serious contradictions of character.Other thoughts: It is not an open-world RPG so don't expect to be able to play past the ending. Other than that this is quite possibly one of the most underrated spy-RPGs ever. I blame the bugs.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2011
												Obsidian's Alpha Protocol offers an original setting and the power of choice. It's a game where you decide the fate of a majority of the cast, giving you the sense that the story is guided as much by you as it is by the designers. With a number of ways to customize the experience – you can play as a stealth agent with a silenced pistol or bullet-spraying berserker – it is an entertaining role-playing experience with some little flaws. One of the best story telling experiences I had in a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												A game I both love and hate in equal measure. The combat is janky and unbalanced as all get out and animations/texture quality can be laughable at times. The hacking minigame is unspeakably awful.It's also one of the finest modern RPGs from this generation. It far eclipses what Mass Effect tried to do in terms of it's dialogue system and how characters react to your actions. The dossier system actually ties back into the game and the options you're given rather than being extra lore reading. And the sheer amount of reactivity to your choices and the consequences that can result put Mass Effect to shame, causing genuinely different endings based on how you play - sometimes drastically different. There isn't a blue, red, or green light to be found. The beginning takes patience to trudge through, but once you're past the Saudi Arabia hub the game begins to shine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2011
												Seeing as how i purchased this game for 2 dollars, this is actually a pretty decent game (storywise at least).  If you're a fan of games where your actions and choices have consequences, this game is for you.  Some of the decisions you make really do feel like some of the decisions people in inteliigence would actually make.  The decision points are never A = good B = bad and you don't really know how your decisions will completely effect the storyline.  The conversations in the game are also well done and feel very natural.  There is, unforunately one glaring problem, and that is that the combat is pretty awful.  Shooting is not skill based at all, and is reliant on how you level up your skills.  Also the inventory suffers horribly from consolization, and you are unable to map equipment to hotkeys, rather relying on a radial wheel (like you would use on a console).  So if you enjoy a decent story and dialogue get this game (was 2$), but don't expect anything great combatwise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2012
												Disclaimer: I am a self confessed RPG nut.I have to make a guilty confession,  this game slipped under my RPG radar, a fact I'm not proud of, even more so, because it's actually quite good.Taking strong elements from Deus Ex and Splinter Cell, you get to play as either a Spy, Commando or Tech, which equtes to the modern day roles of Rogue, Warrior and Mage, with skill trees to develop your class.Similiar to Deus Ex, there are key conversational turnpoints where you can aggravate or side with the other party, and sometimes it's worth your while to♥♥♥♥♥♥them off.There are boss battles, and these seem to run counter to the approach of the remainder of the game, particulary if you favour stealth.That said, the end boss battle was the easiest of them all, and again, there is parallel to Deus Ex with multiple endings based on earlier conversations.I'm a bit bemused why this got savaged by critics, as it's actually a pretty good game, with high replayability. More of this please..

Posted: September 22, 2011
												It's basically like every spy movie rolled into one game.  It used just about every spy trope there is to be a great send up to the spy genre.  Solid writing, great characters, plenty of memorable moments on playthroughs (some being boss fights, others just being conversations), but gameplay is just a bit unbalanced.  Some skills just aren't that good, while others are really overpowered and really break the game by making bosses go down in seconds.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2011
												Seeing as how i purchased this game for 2 dollars, this is actually a pretty decent game (storywise at least).  If you're a fan of games where your actions and choices have consequences, this game is for you.  Some of the decisions you make really do feel like some of the decisions people in inteliigence would actually make.  The decision points are never A = good B = bad and you don't really know how your decisions will completely effect the storyline.  The conversations in the game are also well done and feel very natural.  There is, unforunately one glaring problem, and that is that the combat is pretty awful.  Shooting is not skill based at all, and is reliant on how you level up your skills.  Also the inventory suffers horribly from consolization, and you are unable to map equipment to hotkeys, rather relying on a radial wheel (like you would use on a console).  So if you enjoy a decent story and dialogue get this game (was 2$), but don't expect anything great combatwise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												This game got a seriously bad rap. It's not the best third-person shooter I've played, and oftentimes one might run into an annoying bug, but overall it's a game that offers a lot.Espionage isn't the most investigated genre in the gaming industry, at least not to this level - and Obsidian did a good job of it. Globe-trotting, stealth missions, lethal or non-lethal methodologies - it's a good example of a good game being lambasted unfairly by the general public.The dialogue and choice system are top-notch and can vastly change the playthrough from one game to the next. Most comparable to the dialogue system in Mass Effect, how you treat others can have serious ramifications long down the road; choices made when conversing with one character may completely alter the conversation you have with another several chapters later. A very impressive achievement, and one that seems to have flown under the radar of most.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												This game, had a low critical rating when i first bought it. And after buying it, i could easily understand why. However, i also found myself loving the game. Stealth becomes extremely overpowered when points are poured into it, and the main character comes off as a cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at almost all times, but there is plenty of fun to be had in the character progression and choices, the sheer amounts of weapons and armor are boggling, and you've got plenty of ways to finish every level depending on the stats you've chosen. I played as a stealthy martial artist. I developed an innate hatred of guns in this game quickly, they seem to be as effective as meatballs against king kong. Martial arts however, works fine, and can be fun to watch in action.The choice to be lethal or non-lethal can change how events occur, though the game can penalise either depending on how it's implemented. The choice system is amusing, though some events are set in stone, you can make allies and enemies easily. My character, by the end of the game had slept with every possible female in the game. This astounded me, as i hadnt even been trying to.This game is fun, it isnt a paragon of great design in any field, but it does succeed in being fun, and giving a super-spy feel to the player. Finally, i know that i don't have many hours logged on this game. A stuffup with the steam overlay stopped me from logging hours, or getting achievements as steam didnt register i was playing.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2011
												Playing Alpha Protocol is like trying to shave your♥♥♥♥♥♥with an electric razor because a woman once told you that your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ resembled an Ewok. But then if you compound that with the fact the razor is eight years old, has only one functioning speed (chainsaw), and feels about as smooth as a face rinse using a garbage disposal while munching on chewing gum made of glass and recycled kittens, you'd get the picture.Playing Alpha Protocol is also like flying to Hobart for Easter only to find out when you get there that all of Tasmania is, in fact, now a black hole. But instead of vaporizing instantly into nothingness, you're forced to sit in an auditorium where the seats morph into goblins who munch off your balls and thrust javelins so far up your bum you choke on them. You’re forced to die slowly while watching reruns of Sex and the City on the JumboTron and wee elves drain your bank accounts by one-click-buying the world’s stock of Harry Potter merchandise on Amazon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												As much as I love stealth and games where choices matter, I can't recommend this game. It has a lot of stealth sections in the beginning, but near the middle (which is as far as I got) it starts to fall apart. The second I walked through doors, even though there was no alert, the enemies were already heading for cover and getting ready for a firefight. There is one ability that lets you see enemy locations and alert levels, and when the enemies were running for cover, I could see they had no alert level at all. Level design spoilers ahead, but no story spoilers. In the last mission I got to, you're in a mansion and I could only use stealth for the first beginning parts of a room at best. The levels were open designed and everything to make stealth close to impossible for that level at least. Maybe I should have played more and not jumped to conclusions on this, but a few levels before this one everyone was instantly attacking me too. So in the end, this game just turned into another boring, brown, generic, third-person military cover shooter.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Despite it's flaws, this game is amazing.  Things get blown up, sexy men, shoot people, sexy ladies, you hack things, sneak around, oh and get some lovin from some sexy ladies. There are a variety of ways you can play. Want to just jump right into the action, and mass rage at everyone? Okays, cool, you can do that.  Want to pull some martial arts out your pocket, and knock them senseless? Yeah. That'll work too. Want to sneak and be some wicked ninja? Right on!  (though stealth has some major 'game breaking' flaws for some). The most interesting aspect of this game is the dialogue choices. You can choose from different styles (sauve, professional, joking, etc), which all affect how the fractions and individuals view you.  Getting them to hate you, or like you will have its benefits for you (such as an increase in endurance).  However, if one fraction favors you, you may have issues with those who oppose it- choose wisely! The point? Must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2010
												It's like Bioware and Obsidian had a baby. The gameplay and npc dialogue will leave you reminiscent of Mass Effect, while the story will probably remind you of Obsidian's inability to put together a decent story. At least this game has an ending. Several, in fact, which all depend on actions you take through the game, as opposed to one important decision made at the end. Even though it's marketed as a stealth rpg, you are free to go in guns blazing, although that will punish you through means of severely reduced mission rewards and your allies either hating you or loving you for it. Think Dragon Age's approval system, where some of your allies might look down upon killing police officers, while others might encourage you to take down anyone in your way. In a way, this is an interesting game mechanic, as there are some npcs you might want to hate you for story related reasons.Overall, a solid game that didn't get the appreciation it deserved when it first came out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Better than its reputation led me to believe. Don't get me wrong, it has flaws, but once you get the hang of it it's very enjoyable. If you've been debating about picking it up I highly recommend grabbing it. Some of the controls are funky (hacking is rather annoying and feels like it was clearly designed for 2 joysticks) and the story is fairly cliche but in usual Obsidian fashion the characters are very well put together and I easily found myself sucked in despite ARPG/Shooters not being my thing. Some of the design reminds me of Deus Ex, you almost always have the option of stealth or combat and both are viable. The design allowing you to pick and choose allies which directly impacts the way the story unfolds is great.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This game isn't perfect: it has its share of glitches, and just getting it to run can be quite the hassle.  It's worth the effort, though.  Besides the solid gameplay that allows you to pick virtually any approach with equal effectiveness, it shines head and shoulders above every other game in making your decisions meaningful.  Everything you say can have both large and small impacts on the future of the game, to the point that you can play it a dozen times and not see everything.  And that's no exaggeration - I've done it.  The game is that satisying.The technical issues mean I can't give this game a strictly positive review, but if you can get past them, you'll find an incredibly solid and immersive game that will continue to surprise you even after several playthroughs.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												This game is great in some ways and completely broken in others.  The story is fun.  James Bond the RPG in a nutshell.  Nothing wrong with the premise.  Interesting characters and locations.  Stealth mechanics are ok and the dialog options is some of the best in any game and thats including dialog wheels in Bioware games.  Its Obsidian so good dialog is what you can expect. It falls apart when you actually have to do combat.  Gunplay is iffy at best and while melee is fine you rarely get a chance to do it without running across a room to do it and thats rediculous.  The part that truly brings this game down is the bosses.  OMG the worst bosses in any game ever.  Hell I would argue this game didn't need bosses.  Its a game about being a spy gaining intel and learning who the bad guy is.  Forced boss fights with normal people who take a gazillion shots is bad enough but they are insanely hard for no reason.  90% of the boss fights I died like 10 times before I was able to beat them and i feel it was mostly luck that did it for me.  I regret putting this game on normal because it was damn near impossible.  In fact the first time I tried the game it was impossible.  One boss fight was simply unbeatable from how I leveled Michael and that is just stupid!  Level up right or you will never finish the game.  Put points into stealth to make every mission easy and max out pistol because the pistol becomes your best friend.  Put in a lot of points to a second gun as well.  Assault Rifle served me well.   This is not advice this is required to actually get through the game.  Without stealth most missions will drive you nuts with the combat.  Without pistols at high level bosses will destroy you.  Even then put the game on easy.I had fun with this game but I also got angry with it too often to count.  I just wish I put it on easy because there's nothing to prove in giving yourself an anuerysm for those damn boss fights.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												As much as I love stealth and games where choices matter, I can't recommend this game. It has a lot of stealth sections in the beginning, but near the middle (which is as far as I got) it starts to fall apart. The second I walked through doors, even though there was no alert, the enemies were already heading for cover and getting ready for a firefight. There is one ability that lets you see enemy locations and alert levels, and when the enemies were running for cover, I could see they had no alert level at all. Level design spoilers ahead, but no story spoilers. In the last mission I got to, you're in a mansion and I could only use stealth for the first beginning parts of a room at best. The levels were open designed and everything to make stealth close to impossible for that level at least. Maybe I should have played more and not jumped to conclusions on this, but a few levels before this one everyone was instantly attacking me too. So in the end, this game just turned into another boring, brown, generic, third-person military cover shooter.

												This is almost the definition of a 'flawed gem' game, with some fantastic ideas showcased throughout its' 15-20 hour runtime, some of which are implemented better than others. While the gameplay can feel rough around the edges at times, the story and characters are this game's highlight in my opinion, with good dialogue and great character development (particularly via their interactions with the player character). Also, the amount of choice given to the player adds a couple of playthroughs' worth of replayability. Its' fairly linear level structure may not appeal to some though, so be mindful of this before purchase if this is a game-breaker for you.Overall, although the game has a lot of bugs and some shortcomings, this is a game I readily recommend to RPG fans, especially those looking for a modern setting and an engaging story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
												I've only been playing for a few hours but the issues are piling up quick. If I had to resume the game in a sentence, I'd say it's what Mass Effect could have been if it was handled by inexperienced developers.What to begin with? It's made by Sega and Obsidian but I'd have never guessed.The controls become immediately a problem as you start moving around your character for the first time.Clearly this game was made for consoles and barely adapted to PCs. It becomes even more apparent once you start messing with hacking and mini-games, as the mouse is emulating the right joystick. You have to keep moving your mouse towards a direction in order to simulate the pressure you'd apply on a joystick, which means you'll be out of bounds of your mousepad in no time. As soon as your mouse stops moving, it registers as if you released the joystick.The aiming, is the old Mass Effect style. Big lousy crosshair that seems confused between recoil and spray.While the game keeps calling it recoil, there is no recoil in this game. Instead the crosshair enlarges as you keep firing or move (Moving your aim also enlarges it, even if you're not moving your feet) which makes your gun spray area larger, forcing you to miss shots. This game really wants you to move, stop, aim, shoot then move again. No fluidity whatsoever in combat except for those melee takedowns.The interface has weird reactions to key presses. When you press the default toggle key "C" to open your gadgets panel, the window pops up and you can interact with the window but the "C" key is still locked, making you wait a few more seconds before you can close that window again. (Yes, it's a gadget panel and not crouching, the crouching is done with the old style CTRL)You cannot close that window by pressing ESC either.Actually, some windows you bring up with a key press will not close by pressing the same key again, instead you have to navigate through the menus.The speech, which if you've never played this game, is pretty much like a poor version of what Mass Effect did.I enjoyed it nonetheless but here again, you can see the inexperience/lack of polishing of the developers..Sometimes, not always, when speaking to someone, the answer will pop up before the NPC is done talking, triggering the countdown that forces you into the default answer. If you decide to wait to hear what the NPC asked of you, you will be left with less than a second to click on the answer you wish for, potentially making you say something you didn't want to. I understand those types of timers are meant to keep the conversations going and be more realistic, and even though I disagree with the principle which makes me heavily biased, my opinion is that they (the timers) should be at least twice as long, giving the player more time to think about the situation. (It's an RPG element and should be treated as such, time and thoughts are involved)Now, for the gameplay/level design.. Which is what made me write this review in the first place. There are some terrible decisions that only makes me guess what is the next thing they'll mess up.The "Training" sessions is what I'm refering to, there are 3 trainings you can go for (afaik) (Weapons, Gadgets and Stealth). If you complete the Weapons training with enough points, Mina, the person in charge of it, will suggest you to try her "bonus" round, which gives you more goodies (Cash/hardware). Good, sweet deal.You then go to the Gadgets training and more or less the same happens. As you finish the training with a high score, Darcy the guy in charge of that session will offer you a similar "bonus" round  (although I'll explain why the bonus of that training is absolute garbage later).So far so good, the game has a pattern and I'm following it. I head to the third training (Stealth) and get started, I run a few rounds and get what I think is a near perfect score. I get back to the person in charge, the old man tells me I'm doing above-average and asks me the same question other people in charge asks me when I'm not getting enough points to get the bonus, which is "Do you want to try the course again?". So of course, I whine; think about what I could do better and try the course again.. I retry for an hour, getting a 58 seconds time with a perfect score. At this point, i'm so close to perfection and still getting 135 points and still being asked to try the course again..I get frustrated, start googling and I find out that this old man, doesn't propose you the bonus until you say you don't want to try the course again...You created a pattern that ends up in an infinite loop, that is one of the worst design you can think of.I'd expect that kind of mess up towards the end-game, where many games tends to lack polishing.It's astounding that this happens in the first hour of gameplay.This would have been an incredibly easy/fast thing to fix compared to the trouble it causes especially in the beginning where most people makes up their mind about your game.As for the Gadget training's bonus round, they spawn you in a closed room with a rack of gadgets. They tell you that your objective is to disable all the alarms and that everytime an alarm goes off, more guards are spawned. As the guy talks to you for what feels an eternity, the gadget locker is locked and you have nothing in your pockets. You can't prepare for what's coming and instead forced to sit around and listen to that mofo.As the guy finally finishes serenading you, gadgets are spawned in your pockets, the locker gets unlocked and the enemy's door opens and all the alarms triggers. All they taught you in the previous Gadget training is out the window. You can't trap them as the only door opened automatically, you can't sneak in because they're watching the only door like hawks and you can't move around in your room because they can easily spot you from outside.Welp, I decide to start chugging static grenades like there's no tomorrow, I kill all the guards then use a gadget that stops alarms. The alarm stops for less than a second, then rings again, spawns more guards etc..So after getting pummeled and shot at, I start again, chug grenades, kill all guards then I walk into their room.I see the alarms on the walls so I started trapping all of them, trapped the newlyfound doors and basically do exactly what the previous training taught me to do. Once i'm ready, I disarm an alarm manually, it magically triggers again less than a second later and more guards spawns right behind me, in the middle of the room, effectivelly bypassing all the traps I've setup.Frustrated again, I start googling.. To find out you have to crawl in a corner of the room you spawn in, disregard everything that you've been told and just spam the gadget that stops the alarms. Bam, less than a minute and it's done.. A+I'm not sure what that bonus round was supposed to teach me but I'll take the 20k$. kthxbye.All in all, these types of mistakes are timeless. It doesn't matter that the game was released 7 years ago like it was or 15 years ago. These are fundamental problems that only demonstrates a lack of experience and/or lack of polishing.I've played a TON of games, both old and new, I have a massive steam library and I've rarely seen a game getting the complicated parts right and the fundamentals wrong. I mean, don't get me wrong, there is much worst out there. It just hurts to see that from Sega and Obsidian, I have to assume this had a decent budget.To end on a good note, I do enjoy the RPG elements. It's hard not to compare it to Mass Effect as most systems are very similar, even the level up interface/mechanics. It doesn't seem to limit the player by blocking everything away like newer games tends to do and instead letting you choose your own path. I like the speech system, where NPCs may like you more or less depending on the answer, even though your options are always one word (Suave, Professional, Suspicious etc..)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I had this game for a good while, but I had major gameplay issues from the start and I kept getting annoyed and leaving it alone for months on end. I had a friend point out a couple of fixes to me, and suddenly, hello - I lost an entire night because I was enjoying the game just that much.Those fixes, btw - your default interact key [I believe it's Spacebar], should be left as default. In the hacking minigame at least one of the threads insists on Spacebar just to be able to work. You can always assign a different key as the backup key and it'll work fine for everything else, but for hacking to work, Spacebar needs to be left as default. Also, don't try overriding the graphical settings from within the AMD or nVidia software - it can break the dialogue boxes, leaving them blank and you unable to actually choose your dialogue. Considering how Alpha Protocol works, this isn't a good thing.Those two bugs were gamebreaking for me originally. Once I knew how to get around them, the game played like a dream. Clunky in a few places [combat/movement wise] and I despise the checkpoint system, but I would still happily play it over and over again. There is major replay value depending on where you'd like to travel to first, your dialogue options, everything else. Definitely worth it on sale, though not necessarily otherwise.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												Obsidian is one of the few developers who have earned my trust enough for me to be willing to buy their games without hesitating. I can't think of a game by them that ever disappointed me, but I can think of plenty that became some of my favorites, and Alpha Protocol is one of them.In terms of the core gameplay, the game is only slightly above average. It's framed as a stealth game, but there are plenty of character options to let you play as loud or quiet as you want, or even dump all your points into Martial Arts and become a kung fu spy if you want. The AI can be a bit finnicky sometimes, and the camera mouse controls sometimes have issues, but for the most part it's functional, and fun to play. The real distinguishing factor of the game is in the dialogue, and other choices. An average playthrough may only last 10 to 15 hours or so, but it has enough replayability to easily make it worth playing several times. Everything from the order you take on missions in to the people you ally with likely has an effect on future events, and there are enough ways that events can play out differently to continue to surprise you even after 3 or 4 playthroughs. The game features a full Bond-like cast of memorable characters, each of whom have their own likes and dislikes that can influence your results throughout the game. It really puts up the illusion that this is a real world of espionage, and it's easy to find yourself invested in the character and story because of it.The one place where the game does falter is the dialogue interface itself. The game uses a Mass Effect-style one-word-choice system, where most dialogue choices fall into three categories - Suave, Aggressive, and Professional. It's not as simplistic as it may seem, and it is somewhat necessary to shorten the lines since unlike other similar games Alpha Protocol is fairly aggressive with its timed dialogues and often may not even give you more time than it takes for a character to finish their sentence to make a decision, but it does occasionally end with you misreading the prompt's intention and leading to the main character saying something you didn't want. This ties in with the fact that the main character's voice actor isn't all that great at times, and he doesn't do a very good job of actually sounding particularly suave when you pick those options. Alpha Protocol is the one game where I don't completely hate the use of the dialogue wheel, but I still wouldn't mind it being gone.If you're into Bond movies or just spy fiction in general, Alpha Protocol is a pretty easy pick. Almost every Obsidian game has their faults due to both publishers rushing them and Obsidian themselves not being that great at managing their time, but like most of their games the faults aren't enough to bring down what ends up being another really great RPG to add to their list.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Perhaps unpolished, but still a gem.Fan of Deus Ex, or Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines, and their brethren of immersive sims?  Don't pass up Alpha Protocol.Be warned, of course.  The game is riddled with severe technical problems; across two PCs and two operating systems, this game has proven more challenging to merely run than any other game I've played in the last five years.However, it is also among the very best.  The setting is lacking any particularly fantastical elements, and the characters are arguably not especially memorable, but the intrigue is well presented, and subtly woven.The game's dialogue system is superb, reminiscent of Mass Effect, but with the addition of a timer, forcing you to make decisions on the spot and stick by them.  Characters react to your playstyle, and the choice to play stealthily, non-lethally, or  loudly and violently will ultimately impact certain sequences.  Don't expect to notice massive consequences for your choices, but repeated playthroughs show an excptional number of subtle, appreciated differences.Gameplay is ambitiously diverse.  Certainly, as a whole, it controls somewhat awkwardly, as the game does not master any of its elements entirely, but it offers many options competently enough.  The standard paths are available; stealth, hacking, gunplay, and melee (unarmed, in this case) are all present.  Various abilities, unlocked through RPG-like progression, offer a feeling of meaningful specialization, and nicely allow you to focus on a certain skillset.If you can tolerate its technical failings, Alpha Protocol offers an experience that's difficult to compare to any other recent releases.  It was clearly a labor of love, and fans of other Obsidian games probably know what to expect, in terms of its stability.Highly recommended, if you want to take a risk on something different from the norm.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												This is a very fun game about espionage, secret service agencies and world conspiracies. The plot itself is kind of naive, somewhat cliched but the storytelling itself is very fun. The character development is great, there's a lot of attention to detail, lots of choices to be made during the game that will have their consequences in future. The dialogue system is great - you get a mood of reply which you need to choose really fast. Depending on the reply you can gain reputation with the person you're talking to and that can open up different resolutions of conflicts in the game.The gameplay itself is not terribly exciting. The AI is somewhat dumb which spoils the shooting part, the minigames (hacking, lock- and codepicking) are simplistic and get dull after a while. Stealth is really powerful tool. I've heard a lot about bugs in the game but I haven't encountered many during my walkthrough. I got stuck in a texture once and saw AI do some really stupid stuff.Despite all it's flaws Alpha Protocol is a great and fun game. It's like reading a good super-spy book and watching a good James Bond movie. I've played this game practically non-stop for 3 days, it is that much fun to get through the plot and see what comes next, how this all will end and how it all will be resolved. This conspiracy/espionage setting is really a breath of fresh air in RPG world and I really can't have enough of it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Product received for free
												-First impressions, will have full review on the way.-Alpha Protocol is a third-person action RPG shooter with Stealth elements developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and published by Sega. Starting off this review, Alpha Protocol was a game i played when i was much younger, but i barely remember anything from it. So, my experience was bad, and i thought the game was bad, and it was a physical copy. It was around the time of release, so it had some issues, such as the issue i had myself, of completing a tutorial, but, it claiming that i haven't. Now for the review. Alpha Protocol contains an intresting narrative, and the game has a good tone, but just doesn't feel all so serious yet. The storytelling is also very good so far, and the game is reminding me of Mass Effect, the first game, which i thought was okay, but it did have really amazing storytelling, character development, and stuff. This game also has a dialogue system insanely similar to it, and it really, really feels just like that, although, the storyline isn't as good as Mass Effect. The characters are all very well written, and character development is also very good. For the gameplay, it does work well, and it makes me feel as if this is the Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain of 2010, or an early Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. And talking about that, the gameplay has some unique stuff, but not much. It's the precision thing, and i like it. The gameplay isn't very tactical, but it is fun and induces you into creating strategies and stuff, using your mind, just like MGSV:TPP does, except, a lot of the gameplay depth and detail is removed here. Combat is also pretty damn good, although A.I is quite dumb at times. The graphics look top-notch, even at the time, but it doesn't stand out today, but it still looks good. At the moment, the game is very good, but we still didn't talk about the only problem i have with it, which is sadly slightly big. The game contains occasionally unresponsive controls. Anyway, i still think the game should get better, as the intensity of the storyline isn't quite gripping me yet, although it is intresting, it is really not bad, but so far, it feels as if it's gonna get much better. The gameplay, will too. The weapons? There aren't that many. I like the concept of Agent History at the start of the game, too, which you select actually before you get to play it. My experience so far with Alpha Protocol is good, and could nearly achieve a 9/10 with its gameplay, specially since the Stealth works very well.8.8/10 ~Only so far.This review will be updated constantly as i go through the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												It’s third person shooter/RPG that is most similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Mass Effect. The plot is very reminiscent of James Bond and other rouge spy movies.The story is actually pretty intriguing and decently written, involving different factions of spies, mercenaries, terrorists and secret police; taking you to places such as Moscow, Rome and Taipei.  Its interaction mechanics with NPCs during cut-scenes is the highlight of this game.  It allows you to chose different dialog choices that influences the story and character relationships. The cast of characters is colorful and they are all very interesting. Each NPC has a unique and different personality and a huge part/theme of the game is manipulating people to get what you want, that means acting aggressive, professional or suave depending on the person. Your relationships and interactions can also influence the way a mission plays out, whether or not you’ll receive back up, determining who are going to be fighting, and what items on the black market you can purchase. The game also emphasizes dossiers and gathering intel, which gives passive combat bonuses to specific factions and helps you learn about a character’s background so that you can learn how you’re supposed to talk to them if you want them to like you. Missions offer multiple paths, approaches and options. You can also bang MOST of the chicks in one play through, if you play your cards right (this is, hands down, the best part).Combat and controls can feel clunky, it seems like they wanted to make weapon specialization and stats like accuracy, stability and recoil matter in a third person shooter, so it forces you to ‘focus’ your cross hair on your target before you can shoot or else your shots will be all over the place.  This can make early game very annoying because your shots won’t focus fast enough, and any kind of long ranged combat becomes a pain.  The game forces boss fights, there is no stealth solution, you have to straight up fight them so it's highly reccomended that you pump up the stats in at least one weapon (fun fact pistol is over power). Regardless of the boss fights, playing stealth is generally over power, it rewards you with more stuff than a straight up commando/aggressive play, and it trivializes a lot of missions. There are 2 hacking mini-games, a word search and clicking tangled wires in a specific order. They get repetitive fast and are not really fun. The game can also be glitchy at times; there have been times when I’ve been spotted and never should have been (through a wall), times where I’ve gotten stuck in walls and had to die or reload my save, and the game had crashed on me 4 times throughout my play through.I’d recommend it if you like the talking parts of the Dues Ex and Mass Effect or just enjoy a good story driven game. You’d have to deal with the par combat, missions and maybe a rough early game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												READ THIS!To truly enjoy this game make sure to save often. Autosaves tend to screw you over IE they will autosave right as the door behind you gets locked and you cant double back for loot or something else. This is my main gripe with this game as I love exploring every edge of a game like this and sometimes the game literally blocks you from doing so when you've reached a certain point. Always make saves in case you need to backtrack so you don't have to restart from an earlier point.Also, make sure to check out the FOV bind with a quick google search, this will allow you to zoom out from Thornton(you) and allow better viewing specifically for widescreen users. This game is simply put; Awesome. It's like if Mass Effect went spy on budget. It's a really good game if you like RPG/TPS mechanics with (meaningful) leveling. If you play Recruit on Hard difficulty at first you will feel truly like a recruit and by the end you will feel like a freaking super spy of awesomeness. This game has an amazing element of evolving and also its dialogue tree which actually affects the outcome unlike other games of this genre (looking at you Mass Effect...) Allthough there are some INCREDIBLY annoying things about this game like how the AI will literally do a 180 once you shoot them and spot/simultaneously fire on you. Being a stealth character is more difficult then it should be as this game is mainly built around running and gunning but it's a fun challenge and by the end stealth+pistol became very OP and ultimately rewarding. If you enjoy Mass Effect type games and are willing to look past the occasional issues this game runs into(crappy autosaves, barely serviceable PC port, occasionally weak or unfair AI) it will result in a pretty fun experience that I'll be sure to replay once I unlock Veteran.

content:
Posted: March 9
												thinking of revisiting this game right now.i played more of it than just these 7 hours before i had this steam account.a good deal of it really.its basically an action/stealth RPG with choice and consequence and a coolnon linear espionage/ conspiracy story.id say the stealth and combat mechanics are very decent.i guess there are some flaws here and there but i cant think of anything right nowthat really took the fun out of it for me.the writing of the game is very good.. its obsidian after all..graphics are okay even though the game is fairly "old" now.honestly in my opinion at 15 bucks you can get a lot worse games and this game is actuallypretty damn good! i mean its not just okay and whatever but a game that you should at least try once.i have not expierenced any bugs or performance problems either.pros+ rpg elements, skills and stats and gear. (fairly decent selection in my opinion)+ interesting non linear story with nicely written dialogue, interesting characters and various settings from china to russia to the middle east etc+ good quality of animations, nice cutscenes, talented voice acting+ decent combat and stealth mechanics (nothing too special but nothing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ or boring either)+ choice and consequence+ aged but still decent enough graphicscons-loading screens during levels- while the AI is not "broken" it isnt the smartest either. sometimes you think wait? he didnt see me there?- like i already said there are loading screens some areas are bigger some are smaller.hardly a difficult sell. i dont understand the mixed reviews it recently got. its a  good game with high production value (at least for its time) done by obsidian who.. dare i say it? always delivers at least a somewhat interesting expierence. and they are charging less than most early access games on steam. (think about that!) and if you can get it on sale... well then its probably cheaper then a menu at mcdonalds.go ahead dont believe and try it.. it may be rough around the edges here and there... but its quite unique.

content:
Posted: April 12
												So this game was much better than I expected.  I felt there were some areas they could have done better on though...The sniper rifle is not effected by mouse sensitivity. It was so aggrivating to move it just a hair and it would fly all over the place. Several games have this problem, I don't know why.The tranq bullets need work. I got a double head shot with a single tranq bullet Deadpool style. I'm no doctor, but I think the first guy probably isn't asleep...They said I killed marines in the embassy in Russia, I am almost entirely convinced I didn't. This may be a bug.There should have been a first person option. Some games have to be third person but many don't and I feel like this one didn't. Some tight spaces I couldn't see the enemy cause my character was blocking my view. I wish I shot more accurate. The chance to miss is fairly high, even with max rifleman.I personally didn't like hacking computer terminals. It was like a word search in middle school. I never liked word searches.------Random notes:Not a problem but I'd recommend you have one of your weapons the pistol. You really need tranq bullets to beat the game and the pistol has them.Also I'm sad I didn't kill all my enemies but that may be my own fault. I'm also curious about Sis and G22, sure I killed a lot of them but what ever happened to them?------Now, there were some amazing areas. Despite it's flaws, the combat system was a blast. I enjoyed the boss battles (even if they didn't make a lot of sense in an otherwise mostly realistic game)I enjoyed the four romance options, I especially enjoyed you can pursue all four. I disliked that they didn't really stick around. Maybe if you guys do a sequel you can pick up with the romance from the first game? Seems a waste to have the options but never do anything with them.The dialogue system was fun. -----I admit I haven't played many games like this, really only Mars War Logs and Of Orcs and Men but I would say this is the best of those three. I can't say how this compares to Mass Effect but I still recommend it.

												I forgot I didn't have a recommendation for this game because I pirated it years ago.Anyway, the premise of the game is pretty awesome, and not really something done before, you're Micheal Thorton, a  bipolar and slightly psychopathic spy that gets betrayed by his own agenecy and has to go rogue to save the world. Well, more like save face for America, but close enough.   I'd go into praise about the gameplay here, but unfortunately Deus Ex: HR did almost everything this game did but better.  The stealth is wonky as ♥♥♥♥ (the developers probably realised this and literally made one of the skills make you go invisible the first time you are spotted) the combat trees are unbalanced, and worst of all there's level scaling, at the start of the game, people die when they are killed, and near the end russian gangsters are tanking headshots like they've been crocodil addicts their entire lives.I briefing mentioned the protagonist's mental deffecientcies earlier, the dialogue system is sort of similar to mass effect, instead of picking what you are going to say, you instead pick an 'approach' such as being suave, joking, aggressive, etc. However, you don't know HOW WELL or how MUCH Micheal is going to go.  Cutting to the chase, Michael is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible at jokes, and is extremely violent and sadistic when given the chance.  To make things worse, being successful against certain NPCS tends to just mean picking one approach and staying with it instead of responding appropriately in a fluid converstational matter.  Of course, since it's an obsidian game, it's filled with a few glitches and probably missing 20% content.All these terrible things being said about the game, it's definitely worth your time, there's some great scenes, and a couple of interesting characters, and some decent customization for your very own secret agent.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2011
												Alpha protocol's story is possibly one of the best I've seen when it comes to spy games/movies.It's complex,but not confusing, rewarding multiple playthroughs.The dialogue also comes through,as it's well written and it's mass effect-esque dialogue branch keeps multiple playthroughs fresh.Unfortunatelly,it also has the same problem as Mass Effect,as some of the dialogue choices you make might actually mislead you and have unintended results(like negatively affecting your stance with a character).As usual in an Obsidian game,it also suffers from technical problems,raging from slowdowns on certain machines to enemies not loading on a quick-load.The gameplay also suffers from slight imbalances,with some bossfights being resistant to weapons/skills you might have selected.If it's going for cheap,do get the game.The story alone is worth it!Note:DRM was removed on patch 1.1 so you don't need to worry about install limits anymore.

												One of the most under rated games!  Pros:* It's a fantastic RPG experience: good mix between action, stealth and RPG. * The storyline and characters are awesome. * All your decisions (kill civilians, leave a boss alive, etc.) have real consequence.* Like any RPG, you have to choose your skill, buy/sell weapons, objects, ammo, etc.* You can play each mission like Rambo, or Sam Fischer or a mix of them (kill only enemies).* Good replayability (Kill Them All, save the civilians, flirt with all the girls, etc.)Cons:* Some lag if you move your mouse too quickly* Sega have abandoned the seriesBuy it, buy it now :p

												First I thought, oh hey, a bargain for 2 Euros.Then I started the game... and suddenly lost 6 hours of my life before I realized that it is well past midnight.This game is pure awesome. It delivers on presentation, story, sound only sometimes I wish I could fiddle with the mouse sensitivity for sniping. The effects of your in-game decisions are very visible in the storyline and so far, it looks as if there is no right or wrong choice... you just play like you want to play. If I had to, I would describe this game like a playable version of a James Bond movie who had a love child with the Burn Notice TV series.As long as it is 90% off, BUY IT! No excuses! This game is well worth the money and I would pay 40 bucks and consider it money well spent. The last time I had so much fun was with Mass Effect 1 and 2.

												Dont trust the reviews. This game is very overlooked because people were expecting a third person shooter aka Mass Effect and got dissapointed. This game is a RPG first and a TPS second. If your looking for a game that will suck you into its world and give you freedom of choice, this would be your game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												This is a great game. Just finished it.Disclaimer,  there are some annoying glitches and bugs here and there but once you get used to the weapon aiming and the hand to hand combat it's more than tolerable. If you can see past some of the minor flaws, you'll find one of the best video game stories I have ever played. Not quite the character development of Mass Effect but a great secret agent story. The dialogue, story, and voice acting are excellent. The moral and ethical choices are really satisfying. If you can crank up the resolution the graphics still look pretty good. None of the writing or voice acting were filler. All the emails, dossiers, and newscasts are crucial to the plot and game play, and quite funny at times. You really do have to build a rapport with characters and be tactful with the ladies to get anywhere. Make sure you go for the "Ladies Man" acheivement. ;) One of the things I found dissappointing was even on a mission with patience and perfect stealth you still have to fight your way out as part of the story. Overall, if you like a Jack Ryan, Jack Bauer, ripped from the headlines kind of story, you'll really enjoy this. The newscasts and politcal scenarios could have easily been written in the last couple months and don't feel dated at all. Truly a hidden gem, well worth it even if not on sale, just make sure you finish it, it's worth the time. I just hope they make a sequel. Given that there's no Metal Gear or Splinter Cell games in the pipeline that I know of, I think this is an underserved market right now. Too much fantasy needs a little bit of reality. Even if it's the Mission Impossible, Jason Bourne, Homeland imaginary kind of reality.
