number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												This is the first game I've heard deemed a "classic" that I hadn't played around the time it came out where I still ended up enjoying it. The style reminds me of if Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory was an ARPG. It definitely went for the cool Hollywood feeling over realism but it doesn't go over the top.The characters all felt unique and learning about them and trying to persuade them to do things your way really grabbed me in a way I find hard to explain. It felt like what I said and how I approached things actually mattered. You have your usual bunch of options on how to handle /most/ of the game. There are spots with bosses that require you to take the conventional beating-the-snot-out-of route, but for the most part you're free to sneak past people rather than knock them out or kill them. Gun selection isn't great; you've got pistols, shotguns, submachine guns, assault rifles, and aside from better/worse stats here and there they all feel mostly the same. It never bothered me that much.Around the end the upgrades felt kind of overpowered, especially stealth. I might as well have been a ghost. I guess that's kind of the point of a high stealth stat, though, so whatever.This being a PC port shows at times (those sniper rifles!) but I didn't notice it for the most part. A boss near the end of the game proved really difficult because the sniper rifles handle like garbage and that was practically the only way to deal with him.There are a few bugs. One of the bosses ran into a wall and I could beat him with melee attacks while he didn't fight back. In another part Mike exploded into some otherworldly mass of polygons that would've given Lovecraft a wet dream. Again, nothing too terrible. I found these two bugs more funny than annoying.The story isn't spectacular. It's pretty stock. You'll likely see where most of it's going if you're familiar with the genre. It held up well enough though.I'm decently impressed, which, admittedly, is a rarity for me. 7/10, well worth the money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Alpha Protocol is an incredibly peculiar blend of unbelievably awesome and utter crap. Think of it as James Bond by way of Mass Effect. Unlike Mass Effect, however, choice actually matters. This is one of the only games I can think of that provides a genuine reactive storyline: Literally every choice in the game alters the story in a profound sense. "No two playthroughs will be alike" gets bandied about, but Alpha Protocol is one of the only times where that's actually true. As per the usual, Obsidian puts every other RPG developer to shame as far as the "RP" part goes.Unfortunately, that's really all there is to recommend it. The production values are passable, but far from outstanding. The protagonist's voice in particular grates, and while there are options to customize your appearance, they are so limited as to not even be worth the time.Where the game really falls flat, however, is the gameplay. The level design is dull, the shooting is weak (particularly in the early levels), and the stealth system is a joke. Easily the worst parts of the game are the boss levels, which, unless you spec a very specific way, range from near-impossible to just tedious. Unfortunately, this means that for the most part, non-combat builds will have a very, very hard time progressing past the Taipei sections.Ultimately, whether or not Alpha Protocol is worth your money depends entirely on your patience and how much mileage you can get out of the story. I'd say it's worth at least one playthrough, as the story, while not great, is entertaining, and the reactive storytelling is a beauty to behold. However, this one is to be avoided if mediocre gameplay is a turn off. I'll recommend it, but with reservations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												This game pretends to be shooter, but it isn't. Tries to be rpg, but something isn't right. Scenario is torn, so it's hard to follow it. The good thing about storyline is it's variability. Several times you will have to choose: spare or execute characters, or you have limited time and two goals, and you have to choose which one should be completed. Saved person could help you in future.Sometimes everything looks so interesting and dramatic, but all of it falls prey of very, very, very poor movement animation. It's hard to be serious, when guard walks, than turn around, takes T-pose (or something like that), stumbles and continues walking. Dialogue system reminds of one from Mass Effect, but answer shows you only attitude or emotion your character would apply to his answer. From time to time option to act will show up. Game is full of different characters. For every person you had met, your "journal" will show you basic dossier. Further, you could find some additional information about them. In game there is relationship meter. People approve or disapprove of your actions, and could provide you assistance in certain missions.With leveling up you purchase some perks, and I used them only on late levels or against bosses. On mission, you could carry with you grenades, medicine and etc. They are of great help, so don't forget to purchase them after every mission.Gameplay is not bad or good. At first, enemies will die quickly only after headshots, or just immense amount of bullets shot into torso. Accuracy depends on how long you are aiming and on your movement. It sounds ridiculous, but I eliminated more opponents hand-to-hand, even those who were armed to teeth with long-ranged weapons.There are several points in game, where you should use stealth. Stealth here is completely useless and stupid. When enemies or cameras spots you, alarm raises. You could crack it and turn off. Also, you could open locks and crack computer systems. I really hate computer cracking. You get two lines of numbers, and you have to find matching patterns on screen, full of changing numbers. When you find combinations you need (they don't move), you have to move your lines till they match similar lines on screen. My eyes scream in terror! and of course, time is severely limited. But, there is an upgrade, making cracking easier. I bought it immediately as I saw it.Graphics. For game from 2010, they are pretty good.Conclusion. If you like espionage theme, this game is for you. Interesting dialogues, not bad graphics, short intense missions, ability to make important choices that influence story. I beated game in 21 hour, so you could not get tired or bored of it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
Pros:-Various gameplay styles-Multiple storyline experiences-Surprising and intriguing plot twists-Choices have far-reaching consequences-Fantastic character cast-Dossiers give the story a great deal of depth beyond the surface plotline-Phenomenal replay valueCons:-Controls sometimes clunky-Main character's voice-Need more Sis; a small number of characters really need further developmentOverall: I have never played a game where my choices impacting the game on this scale.  Who your allies are, what solutions are available, who lives and dies, even shop inventory... all of these are tied to choices made during the plot.  Conversation choices, yes, but also choices on how to complete missions - sometimes completing a mission undetected yields very valuable rewards and opens up choices for later plot points.  One different choice, or performing missions in a different order, will almost always guarantee a different outcome later on.  This is an espionage RPG done right.  The gameplay is mostly smooth with some clunky moments, particularly when it comes to gunfighting, but it's almost unnoticeable.  And while the core cast is very well developed, and most everyone has a dossier that gives their backstory, two or three characters could use some more development.  Still, the gameplay is fun, and the storyline RPG elements are flawlessly executed.Bottom Line: The best $14.99 you'll spend.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2011
												Forget what the reviews say. Sure, it's an Obsidian game, so there are bound to be a few bugs. But: it's an Obsidian game, and that means it's excellently written, and tons of fun to play. It really deserves a sequel, even though it's an excellent game in its own right (and no, there's no cliffhanger ending; it's wrapped up at the end). Think of it this way: it combines the brilliant writing/dialogue of Planescape, with the gameplay of Deus Ex, in third person. For the most part, it pulls this off brilliantly. Keep in mind that one playthrough of this game is going to be different from the next: how you interact with people determines how the story plays out, and will open up various different missions and plots, so multiple playthroughs are definitely worth it. After reading the reviews, I went into this game a bit skeptical, but I've become a convert. Buy this game!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												Alpha Protocol.  Alright, this game was pretty much raked over the coals when it came out.  Let's get the bad stuff out of the way first: the game is buggy.  There are some bugs that make gameplay a bit more difficult than it should be, however, nothing is gamebreaking and I never had to re-load the game because something bugged out to where I couldn't do something.  For me, I had a bit of a camera-jerkiness problem that was easily fixed in the Engine.ini file. Quite honestly, I'm not too sure what the big deal was about this game being so bad when it was released.  I experienced no game-breaking issues at all.  Now, for the good: this story is as interesting as you want to make it. The timed dialogue choices are awesome, and this game has ridiculous replay value.  I played as the "nice and professional" guy, which landed expected results, but there are three or even four other choices at times that will drastically change your experience.  You can go through the game at your own pace and to whichever place you want first - which also impacts your game.  (Unless you write down everything you do, I doubt you'll have a run that is EXACTLY the same.)  The story is neat, and what I liked most is that I never truly knew who to trust.  At times I thought a certain person had my back, just to find out they sold me out and then tried to kill me.  The twists were interesting and the game is quite good.  I played on Normal and it took me about 17 hours, exploring everywhere, experimenting with the Black Market, etc.  I would recommend you guys to get this guy as it's the only game like this that I know of.  Deus Ex is the general comparison, but this game is nothing like DE:HR, so it's not fair to compare it.  Next time it's on sale, be sure to grab it.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Although I have not played this for the PC, Ive played through it three our four times on the 360. This game has everything it needs for a perfect rpg. Made before dragon age, this game has romances, hatreds, and customizations. Depending on your relationship with different people you get different perks that help up your game. Through out the game you get funds inwhich you can upgrade weapons armor and components on each. Mass effect has a very similar custization technique. The game is a modern warfare/ secret operations rpg. Its not called the sabatoge rpg for nothing. You have several different strategies to go about missions including stealth, bombs, and assault. Pretty much eveything you do in the game changes the gameplay in some way. If you make someone hate you it could change a way one mission goes completely. It is a very direction oriented game, in which i mean there is not really open world. You do missions and build relationships. Yet somehow, its fun, invigorating, and playable over and over.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is a much maligned gem of a game. I'll not deny that it's rough around the edges; the controls are sub-par, and the level design is occasionally just bad.But the dialogue, the choices, and above all the consequences of those choices, these are all gold. The leveling system is comprehensive and covers a whole lot of options. The choices you make genuinely have repercussions; treat your handler well and they'll be good to you, but if they get too attached you might miss out on imprtant mission details. How you deal with enemies early on will impact what they do for (or to) you later. The story is extremely well put together and I think it makes up for the flaws.It's well worth a look.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												This is one of those games that got lost in the shuffle. Possibly overshadowed by another release or maybe poor advertising campaign.  Pay no attention to the fact that I've played it for a mere 5hrs - I OWN this on DVD from a while ago and have beaten the game several times. In fact it's the first game I've played since Never Winter Nights that inspired me to replay immediately after the end. Literally I started over when it ended.  --  The replayability comes from the fact that you can never know the true intentions of ANY of the people you deal with unless you have gathered all the Intel on them... and you can NEVER get all the intel on everyone in one playthrough.   (To clearify: You can get ALL the intel on one person but you'll sacrifice the option to get intel on another person in doing so) It was interesting finding out that I supported the wrong people for what I *thought* were the right reasons on my second time through (by making different choices from the first playthrough and gathering different Intel)The Game mechanics are NOT all that great and it lends itself to possible exploitation when chosing skill sets -- If you max out Pistols and a couple other skills you can actually shoot "blind" (without aiming) from cover and get headshots about 80% of the time.  --  You can compensate for this flaw by playing on a harder level or diversifying your skillset to include other weapons thereby reducing the possibility of maxing a skill.Overall I recommend this to anyone who likes a cool spy story.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												While it doesnt live up to its potential, it is at the very least a decent game.  Character customization is very limited visually, but as far as playstyle goes it is pretty diverse. Players can customize their skill points and equipment to suit Full Stealth, Full frontal assault and everything inbetween.  AI is rather buggy but not in the way most stealth games are, they dont randomly see you through walls or across the map, they do however occasionally completely stop their assigned patrol route and just stand still until aggro'd or killed. Enemies will attempt to flank you if you stay in cover too long and throw grenades to force you out of cover.  Bosses for the most part are rather straightforward, but some are overpowered if you do not buy certain intel on them(a certain boss ignores knockback effects and brushes off punches while sprinting at you...)   Visually this game is not impressive, but it's not so out of date that it's glaring. Characters mouth movement feels natural enough that you dont feel the need to focus on it or attempt to ignore it *cough*life is strange*cough*   Combat is fairly balanced around range, headshots and time, though spread on guns is rather frustrating at times, it can be compensated for with various skill points/perks and upgraded weaponry. Melee is rather fun and reasonably strong, but often pointless vs bosses.If I were to rate this game out of 10?   Graphics 6/10Fun 7/10Story 4/10Gameplay 7/10   Overall: 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I first heard about this game from a list that was titled, "Best games you've (probably) never played". So naturally, I came into this game with mixed expectations. That said Alpha protocol has pleasantly surprised me. This is a stealth infiltration game. It's not a shooter, it's not even a traditional rpg per se. If you come expecting a shooter with great shooting mechanics or a deep RPG you will be dissapointed. On the other hand if you want a game that lets you play out your fantasies of being a modern day ninja, with a branching "choose your own adventure" style story. This game is right up your alley. It's core gameplay revolves around stealth, with minigames that involve keypad splicing, cracking safes, hacking pc terminals for various secret agenty reasons (gain intel, shut off surveillance cameras etc). It honestly reminds me of an American version of Metal Gear Solid with RPG lite elements that was never born. I liked it so much that I played it twice, back to back (I wanted to see how the story branches).If you've played everything else and are looking for something a little different. I highly recommend this gem.Edit: One thing I forgot. No support for 21:9 ultra widescreen monitors. At that resolution the UI is cut off on the top and bottom. After I changed my desktop resolution to a 16:9 ratio (1920x1080) it worked fine. That's the only bug/problem I encountered.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Alpha Protocol is one of the few games I would label as a jack of all trades. The game lets you live out an adventure in the life of a secret agent, providing ample opportunities to play as you see fit. The gameplay varies playthrough to playthrough, and allows you to complete a level with either heavy firepower or the more difficult and rewarding stealth approach. It falls short in that while it does provide a huge variety of ways to play the game, the parts that you do end up picking lead up to an average to mediocre third person shooter. The storyline is very similar to Mass Effect as in you pick dialogue choices which effect the story later on. It isn't actually too bad if you enjoy the sort of over the top Bond-esque action adventure. This game is good for those who enjoy a non-linear first person shooter, or those that are fans of the Splinter Cell franchise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												Although critically panned for the most part, Alpha Protocol is one of the most pleasant suprises in my gaming library. The AI needs work, the level design is not the best, and the writing can sometimes be simultaneously frustrating and awesome, but the game shines in its true ability to make you think about the decisions you make. They have more than an aesthetic impact in Alpha Protocol.  Your actions don't simply replace one NPC with another in some cutscene. They effect the gameplay in large ways and as far as I can tell have a strong impact on your experience of the story as well. The game is rough and needs polish but I don't regret this purchase one bit.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Alpha Protocol is an incredibly peculiar blend of unbelievably awesome and utter crap. Think of it as James Bond by way of Mass Effect. Unlike Mass Effect, however, choice actually matters. This is one of the only games I can think of that provides a genuine reactive storyline: Literally every choice in the game alters the story in a profound sense. "No two playthroughs will be alike" gets bandied about, but Alpha Protocol is one of the only times where that's actually true. As per the usual, Obsidian puts every other RPG developer to shame as far as the "RP" part goes.Unfortunately, that's really all there is to recommend it. The production values are passable, but far from outstanding. The protagonist's voice in particular grates, and while there are options to customize your appearance, they are so limited as to not even be worth the time.Where the game really falls flat, however, is the gameplay. The level design is dull, the shooting is weak (particularly in the early levels), and the stealth system is a joke. Easily the worst parts of the game are the boss levels, which, unless you spec a very specific way, range from near-impossible to just tedious. Unfortunately, this means that for the most part, non-combat builds will have a very, very hard time progressing past the Taipei sections.Ultimately, whether or not Alpha Protocol is worth your money depends entirely on your patience and how much mileage you can get out of the story. I'd say it's worth at least one playthrough, as the story, while not great, is entertaining, and the reactive storytelling is a beauty to behold. However, this one is to be avoided if mediocre gameplay is a turn off. I'll recommend it, but with reservations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												This is the first game I've heard deemed a "classic" that I hadn't played around the time it came out where I still ended up enjoying it. The style reminds me of if Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory was an ARPG. It definitely went for the cool Hollywood feeling over realism but it doesn't go over the top.The characters all felt unique and learning about them and trying to persuade them to do things your way really grabbed me in a way I find hard to explain. It felt like what I said and how I approached things actually mattered. You have your usual bunch of options on how to handle /most/ of the game. There are spots with bosses that require you to take the conventional beating-the-snot-out-of route, but for the most part you're free to sneak past people rather than knock them out or kill them. Gun selection isn't great; you've got pistols, shotguns, submachine guns, assault rifles, and aside from better/worse stats here and there they all feel mostly the same. It never bothered me that much.Around the end the upgrades felt kind of overpowered, especially stealth. I might as well have been a ghost. I guess that's kind of the point of a high stealth stat, though, so whatever.This being a PC port shows at times (those sniper rifles!) but I didn't notice it for the most part. A boss near the end of the game proved really difficult because the sniper rifles handle like garbage and that was practically the only way to deal with him.There are a few bugs. One of the bosses ran into a wall and I could beat him with melee attacks while he didn't fight back. In another part Mike exploded into some otherworldly mass of polygons that would've given Lovecraft a wet dream. Again, nothing too terrible. I found these two bugs more funny than annoying.The story isn't spectacular. It's pretty stock. You'll likely see where most of it's going if you're familiar with the genre. It held up well enough though.I'm decently impressed, which, admittedly, is a rarity for me. 7/10, well worth the money.

												Polarised with reviewers, Alpha Protocol is a game that is meant to be played with skill focus in mind. Your starting abilities are poor, including weapons (the common complaint of reviewers). content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Game overview:  A less serious Splinter cell with phenominal voice acting and hilarious hijinks. Add in dialogue choices that affect missions, who you can trust, and ultimately the game experience, as well as skill levelling (similar to Mass effect) and a wide variety of beautiful missions (Moscow, Taipai, Rome). Oh, and the secondary character of Steven Heck is icing on the cake.Problems with the game: AI can be wonky at times. Animations are unpolished. Game is unbalanced to the point of hilarity. There is also a level that almost requires two skills to be able to complete it (TV Killed the Radio Star). Completionists will hate that you can not hit 100% on some dossiers due to branching dialogue/action choices that you make.Bottom line: If you find it on sale for $5, give it a whirl

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												The Steam desc for this game does not really describe this game well. This is an espionage RPG where you are a Micheal Thorton and you are employed by a secret agency named "Alpha Protocol". Any more would be spoilers, but I would describe this as a sort of James Bond kind of experience. I always have fun with this game overall. The story is interesting and the character are very well made if not a bit predictable sometimes. Also, there is a lot of talking in very short spans of time, but you can skip all the dialog if you want. The game is definitely designed to be played stealthed, but you by no means have to. The stealth is pretty standard, with a few interesting skills in the stealth skill tree to spice things up. The other tree's are pretty basic and can even be boring, but the upside is that those trees cost less AP to go through then the stealth tree. The UI for this game is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's wonky and odd to deal with and the crosshair does not accurately display where your shots are going. The camera is also way too close to Thorton all the damn time. Honestly, other than that I had a lot of fun with this game though I would pick it up during a summer sale or something as it's pretty old, and $20.00 is probably a little much for this game.

												When this game came out, the general review from official venues were negative, highlighting the awful gameplay. But I have to say this is such an underrated game; I actually had fun playing it despite the laughable gameplay and enemy AI (the worst aspect that stands out imo). The story is typical spy action thriller one would easily find in a silver screen - but this is a video game. The story is actually great (I was suprised, too). Mind you, it's quite typical since it follows the spy genre pretty close. This game is pretty fun and it's not bad. Highly recommend it to those who enjoy story in games!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												If you're into stories involving secret organizations, spies and an international conspiracy then this game might be for you. The story is where this game shines if it's your thing, it's just a shame that the gameplay itself is somewhat a letdown.GameplayYou would expect from a game about spying that you walk around sneaking around silently killing your enemies similar to the Hitman games. Unfortunately it's pretty hard if not impossible to finish a level without ending up shooting everyone with your machine gun. It's much easier to just start shooting everyone, the game doesn't leave you much of a choice most of the time. You can also use martial arts but it's simplified to hitting one button at the right time, there is no way to block punches which can suck because there's one level boss that runs at you with a knife and the only thing you can do is run away.Speaking of bosses, they feel out of place, for a game about spies you suddenly stand in front of a heavily armoured guy that shoots bullets with pinpoint accuracy. They require a lot of bullets to take down and it's too easy for you to die. I've had fights where I died a few seconds after the fight starts. At the end of the game the bosses are just ridiculously overpowered and the game stops being fun while the rest of the game is actually pretty easy. I tried it on normal difficulty as a recruit and I never felt challenged.StoryThe story is good, although sometimes it felt too much like "USA: world police" where you as a patriotic secret agent have to single-handedly save the world by going to several places in the world, killing everyone you meet. The conversations in the game are good and you're often given choices that affect the progress of the game. You are given choices on how to respond while being talked, the moment they stop talking you respond, it sounds smooth but it means that sometimes you're given a choice on how to respond to a question while they're asking it and the moment they finish there's no time to select your choice. Also the choices you're given are vague, you can select "honest", "agressive", "avoid" and sometimes some other choices. I don't know what my character will confess when I select honest and I don't know how agressive he will be or how he will avoid the question.GraphicsThe characters look good but don't expect facial animations like LA Noire, they're quite the opposite of the spectrum, graphically the game looks good if you don't expect the latest graphical fidelity. Because of this the game runs good on older systems. If you're not a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ you won't mind it.ControlsThis game is an obvious console port and you feel it in the controls, melee combat is one button, navigating through menus can be unresponsive to key input, I've had times I constantly closed my load-out menu while I just wanted to go back a screen, in the game you also have to hack certain devices like finding 2 strings of characters in a list, one string you control with your keyboard and the other with your mouse and a lot of times you try to navigate your mouses string, which is hard to do because the sensitivity is very low and when you click it on the right place you accidentally move your mouse and the game counts it as a fault. If you make a mistake while hacking the alarm goes off and the enemies know where you are. Aiming with your weapon is ok, there are certain places you can use a sniper rifle but it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to control it, it's very floaty.I can't recommend this game, it has some good ideas but with everything it tries to do there are problems, you can make choices that matter in the story but sometimes you don't have the time to hear the question completely before choosing your reaction. Sneaking around is fun but it always ends up with you shooting everyone with a machine gun. Hacking can be pain, The story is the best part if you don't mind the "USA nr.1" attitude everyone in the game seems to have but even then  the whole story seems too far-fetched with a typical evil corporation trying to cause a cold war so they can profit from it. During the last cold war the world leaders were all ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ their pants constantly and the earth got almost destroyed several times. There's a reason why it ended, even politicians knew it was going to end badly for everyone if the cold war lasted.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												Alpha Protocol is one of those games that I have a kind of hate-love-relationship with. On one hand, this game has fantastic voice-acting (especially compared to some of the stuff thrown at gamers these days), a non-linear, thrilling story, interesting, complex characters, and a lot more. Some of these points are so strong that there are not even a handful of games able to compete with Alpha Protocol in those regards.However, on the other side, Alpha Protocol has it's bugs and flaws. The controls are, at best, mediocre, and sometimes to be considered an atrocity. The overall graphics are sub-par considering what the Unreal Engine 3 is capable of. Despite this, UE3-typical issues like textures that are loaded far too late are still noticeable.All in all, the story of Alpha Protocol is a sad one. Not because it's bad - no, in fact, I really do recommend this game to everyone looking for a thrilling espionage-action-game - but because it was confirmed that there won't be a sequel.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												I honestly wish I could put a thumbs up AND a thumbs down. For one thing, there are so few games like this with both action and story-driven dialogue and your choices ACTUALLY MATTER.  The characters are nice and the dossiers and information is well done. The romanceable characters are pretty varied with a nice well-balanced ending. The hacking and lock picking system was unique and well-balanced. Unfortunately, SEGA+Obsidian = bad game. Let's just throw that out there. From what I've read this game was released in 2010, but it feels much older- like a pre- deus ex human revolution game. The cover system needs a lot of work and the skill tree and boss fights- eh. I'd mention enemy AI, but that's not the problem so much as the enemies will occassionally just stand blankly or shoot in the opposite direction of you (still trying to figure that one out).  The dialogue does that thing where you have like half a second to read and decide and some of those decision are very diifficult. I dislike this about this game and TellTale franchise and...a lot of story games these days. Lastly, the save/check points are few and far between and figuring out exactly when to save is frustrating. JIT does auto save checkpoints, but when they're like 30 minutes to an hour between why bother repeating? I did it once when I mispressed an important decision. I was very unhappy ;(. That said, I refuse to throw this game under the bus mostly because everyone else already has. I will gladly climb under that bus and enjoy this game over and over!
